PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note 2689
particularly that:Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies

PARA.TAB: Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia as our head of State and as in duty bound will ever pray. God save The Queen.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Michael Baume (from 80 citizens) and Senator Campbell (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: World Heritage Listing of the Nullarbor Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned oppose the attempts by the Federal Government to World Heritage List the Nullarbor Region.
In doing so, we condemn the State and Federal Government for failing to consult with the residents of the Nullarbor in relation to the listing proposal.
Further, we affirm the excellent record of pastoralists, highway operators and the local communities in protecting the heritage and environmental value of the region.

PETITION.TITLE: Antarctica: Huskies
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that there is no scientific evidence which shows that huskies are:
1.A threat to Antarctica's fauna including seal and penguin colonies.
2.Linked to disease among other animals in the region.
3.Disease carriers because of a failure in the strict quarantine methods used when introducing a new dog.
4.Inferior to fuel driven vehicles in terms of efficiency of transport and impose greater damage on the environment compared to fuel driven vehicles.
Australia's signature on an international agreement will end a significant Australian tradition of using husky dogs in Antarctica by requiring the removal of all huskies presently in Antarctica.

Recognising that since 1898 huskies have supported Antarctic expeditions, have continued to be of value to scientists carrying out research and are an intrinsic part of the Australian presence in Antarctica your petitioners call upon the Government to reverse its decision concerning the huskies in Antarctica and allow them to remain in Antarctica.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pay Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned residents of Tasmania respectfully showeth:

1.That the Minister for Communications institute suitable safeguards into the legislation concerning Pay TV so that the program standards that currently exist in relation to ordinary on-air transmissions should also apply to Pay TV;

2.That the Minister for Communications be aware that there should be some restrictions to the programs shown on Pay TV in the interests of community standards, the safety of people and in particular the protection of children.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1.We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL FLAG.
2.We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the Nation's history.

SPEECH.PARA: AVIATION FUEL REVENUES (SPECIAL APPROPRIATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

This Bill makes technical amendments to the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Act to enable reductions to be made to the avgas Excise and customs Duty rate while preserving the Civil Aviation Authority's revenue entitlement under the Act. The purpose of the amendments is to permit the phasing out of the collection of that proportion of avgas duty that is directly attributed to the Department of Transport and Communications's aerodrome cost recovery programme.

In August 1990 the Government announced its intention to transfer the remaining Commonwealth-owned aerodromes to full local ownership and to encourage aerodrome owners who are receiving funding under the Aerodrome Local Ownership Plan (ALOP) to accept full financial responsibility for their aerodromes.

As the number of aerodromes financially supported by the Government is reduced there is a corresponding reduction in Government outlays. The Government has given a commitment to the aviation industry to pass on savings through the progressive reduction of the rate of Excise and Customs Duty on avgas. This Bill will enable this commitment to be implemented.

The current rate of duty on avgas is 27.480 cents /litre of which 3.010 cents is attributable to aerodrome cost recovery purposes. The balance of the duty is attributable to cost recovering aviation functions carried out by the Civil Aviation Authority.

This Bill enables the 3.010 cents to be phased out while retaining the existing level of revenue entitlements that the Civil Aviation Authority has under the present Act. At the same time the amendments enable the Civil Aviation Authority with the agreement of the Minister to vary the amount of revenue it receives for cost recovery purposes from the duty. This preserves the intent of the arrangements under the present Act.

The Bill will allow immediate amendment of the Customs and Excise Tariffs to provide a 1 cent reduction in the avgas duty. A further 1 cent reduction in the avgas duty will take place when the combined number of Commonwealth Aerodromes and ALOP Aerodromes is reduced to 100. The final component of duty attributable to the aerodrome cost recovery programme is scheduled to be removed in June 1993 when the aerodrome transfer and withdrawal process is anticipated to be completed.
This Bill is a reflection of the tangible benefits which are flowing to the general aviation industry from the Government's aviation reforms, in particular its policies on aerodrome local ownership.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum for the Bill.
SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS AND TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: This Bill amends 28 Acts to update provisions in them relating to superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments are required as a result of the enactment of the Superannuation Act 1990 and amendments made to the Superannuation Act 1976, with effect from 1 July 1990.
The Superannuation Act 1990 provided for the establishment of the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme which was a new superannuation scheme for Commonwealth employees.
The Superannuation Act 1976 provides for the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme which is the former main scheme for Commonwealth employees.
The Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme was closed to new employees from 1 July 1990. That scheme remains open for existing members and to some former members who return to Commonwealth employment.
The amendments are of the following kinds.

Firstly, where the Acts presently refer to the Superannuation Act 1976 or parts of that Act or to aspects of the 1976 Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme, the amendments include corresponding references to the Superannuation Act 1990 and to the 1990 Public Sector Superannuation Scheme.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, where the Acts presently provide for the removal or retirement of office-holders on grounds such as incapacity, the amendments include references to the invalidity retirement requirements of the Superannuation Acts 1976 and 1990.

These requirements include that members of the superannuation schemes are not able to be retired on invalidity grounds unless the Board of Trustees of the relevant scheme has certified that the person is entitled to receive invalidity retirement benefits.

Thirdly, where the Acts presently provide for action to be done in accordance with superannuation arrangements approved by the Minister administering the Superannuation Act 1976, the amendments reflect the replacement of the provisions of that Act by the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990.

Mr President, the amendments to the Acts are proposed to take effect from 1 July 1990. This reflects the date of commencement of the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme and the changes to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and the Superannuation Act 1976.

Transitional or `savings' provisions are included in the Bill in relation to amendments to four of the Acts so that any action that might inadvertently have been taken that is inconsistent with the amendments will not be invalidated.
The savings provisions for:
the Australian Federal Police Act 1979;
the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984; and
the Public Service Act 1922;

SPEECH.PARA: are intended to protect the superannuation scheme membership of anyone who might inadvertently have become a member of one of the superannuation schemes when he or she should have become a member of the other scheme.

PARA.TAB: The savings provision for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act is intended to protect a redeployment and redundancy benefit that might inadvertently have been paid by the Corporation in a form similar to pension benefits under the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme to any member of the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme.
This Bill will have no new financial effects. It makes only consequential amendments that reflect changes that have previously been put in place.
Mr President, I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the Explanatory Memorandum for the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1992
The Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 and the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Bill 1992 are a package of measures that need to be read together.
BACKGROUND

When this Government took office in 1983, most people would look to the age pension as their main source of retirement income. Superannuation was the preserve of a few, mainly the wealthy, and a substantial proportion of concessionally taxed superannuation savings was dissipated well before retirement.
The reform of superannuation has been one of the great achievements of the Government.

Over its term of office, the Government has greatly expanded access to superannuation savings. In particular, award superannuation has fostered the spread of superannuation to large areas of the work force which previously had no cover.
The Government has also restructured the tax concessions for superannuation to make them more consistent with retirement incomes objectives, while still maintaining them at a generous level.
In addition, access to superannuation concessions has been made substantially more equitable.
These reforms have moved superannuation from being a concessionally taxed source of windfall gains for high income earners towards being a genuine retirement savings vehicle for most Australians.

When we came to office, 40 per cent of the work force had some superannuation cover; in 1991, the proportion was 72 per cent. On this basis alone, our reforms of superannuation are an achievement which the retirees of the future will value highly.

Despite these reforms, there is an ongoing need to ensure that as many Australians as possible have access to superannuation. There is also a need to increase the average level of superannuation savings for each individual, if these savings are to provide an adequate level of retirement income. Consistent with these goals, the Superannuation Guarantee Levy was announced in last year's budget.

The Superannuation Guarantee Levy represents another major step forward in the development of retirement incomes policy. It will lay the foundation for income security and higher standard of living in retirement for future generations of retirees.
The Superannuation Guarantee Levy provides:
a major extension of superannuation coverage;
an efficient method of encouraging employers to comply with their award obligations; and
an orderly mechanism by which employer superannuation support can be increased over time, consistent with the economy's capacity to pay.

The Levy will consolidate the reforms implemented since 1983, and will provide a coherent and equitable framework in which retirement incomes objectives can be progressed. It will ensure that by the beginning of the next century, virtually all employees will be accumulating substantial superannuation savings to help fund their retirement income.

The increased self-provision for retirement will permit a higher standard of living in retirement than if we continued to rely on the age pension alone. The increased self-provision will also enable future Commonwealth Governments to improve the retirement conditions for those Australians who were unable to fund adequately their own retirement incomes.

Lastly, self-provision will increase the flexibility in the Commonwealth's budget in future years, especially as our population ages and will increase our national savings overall, thus reducing our reliance on the savings of foreigners to fund our development.

In December last year an Information Paper was released for comment on issues raised by the operation of the Superannuation Guarantee Levy. The Government then undertook wide ranging consultations on the issues raised by the Information Paper. As a result of the consultation process, this package of measures contains some changes to the proposals outlined in that Information Paper.
HOW THE SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE SCHEME WILL WORK

The Bill, which applies from 1 July 1992, will encourage employers to provide a minimum level of superannuation support for employees. Where employers provide less than the minimum level of superannuation support, they will be liable for a superannuation guarantee charge.

The superannuation guarantee charge—which will not be a deductible expense for employers—will be used to meet the superannuation contribution entitlements of the relevant employee and will be used, as I discuss later, to fund administration costs.

I should stress that this mechanism is not intended to be the principal vehicle for the funding of employees' own contribution entitlements. It is intended, instead, to be an incentive for employers to meet their own obligations, and to be a support mechanism for employees where those obligations are not met.

In introducing the Levy, the Government has been particularly conscious of minimising the labour cost impact of the Levy on employers. We have designed the Levy to be a floor under existing superannuation arrangements. All existing employer superannuation support, that meets the provisions of the Levy arrangements, will count towards the minimum prescribed level of support.

The level of superannuation support an employer is expected to provide will depend on the employer's annual payroll. For the 1992-93 year, employers with an annual payroll in excess of $500,000 will be expected to contribute 5 per cent of an employee's earnings base to a complying superannuation fund. This percentage will increase over the next nine years to 9 per cent. Employers with an annual payroll of $500,000 or less will be required to contribute 3 per cent increasing on a slower transition schedule to 9 per cent.

An employee's earnings base will depend on whether the employer was providing superannuation support for employees on 20 August 1991. Employers who, on that date, were contributing to a superannuation scheme which has an earnings base, can continue to use that earnings base so long as it is not reduced. This will help minimise compliance costs.
In any other case, the employer will be assessed against an earnings base that the employer is required to use under an industrial award or a base not less than ordinary time earnings.

Superannuation support must be provided through a complying superannuation fund in order to be counted towards the minimum level of superannuation support. The fund can be either a defined contribution fund or a defined benefit fund. In the case of a defined benefit fund, the employer will be required to obtain an actuarial certificate specifying the level of employer superannuation support implicit in the benefits available to employees in the fund. For all other funds, the employer's level of support will be based on the actual contributions made to the fund.

The level of superannuation support will be measured on a financial year basis for the 1992-93 year. However, where an employer has provided insufficient superannuation support during that year, the employer will be able to make up any shortfall in contributions by 14 August 1993.

The Government has decided that from the 1993-94 year and subsequent years, employer support will be measured on a monthly basis. The employer will be expected to provide the minimum level of superannuation support either before or during the month (or within 28 days of the end of the month). However, if there is a shortfall in employer superannuation support, the superannuation guarantee charge will not be due until 14 August in the next financial year.
If an employer does not provide the minimum level of superannuation support, a charge will be imposed on the employer. The charge will be equal to the sum of:
the total of the employer's individual superannuation guarantee shortfalls;
an interest component; and
an administration component.

A superannuation shortfall for an employee is calculated by applying to the employee's salary and wages the percentage difference between the minimum level of superannuation support and the actual employer support.

The interest component is a proxy for superannuation fund earnings. The interest will be calculated from the commencement of the financial year until the time the superannuation guarantee charge is due to be paid.

The purpose of the administration charge is to recover some of the costs incurred in administering the tax. The charge will initially consist of a flat amount of $50 plus an amount of $30 for each employee in respect of whom the employer has a superannuation shortfall.
AWARD SUPERANNUATION

The Government has decided to support the inclusion in existing superannuation award provisions of the rates of contribution to superannuation funds required by the Superannuation Guarantee Scheme as they become operative.

The Government considers that, where there is no agreement between the parties to an existing award superannuation provision nominating a particular fund, the fund to which such additional award contributions are to be made should be determined by the relevant industrial tribunal looking to the best interests of the beneficiaries.

The Superannuation Guarantee Scheme is designed to encourage employers to provide a minimum level of superannuation support. It is intended to improve the position of those employees who have inadequate superannuation coverage. It is not designed to provide a mechanism for a general increase in superannuation support for those employees who are already receiving in excess of the prescribed minimum level.

The Government expects that increases in the prescribed minimum level would not result in additional contributions in cases where employers were already providing superannuation support at or above that level.
Of course, parties are free to negotiate levels of superannuation support above the minimum as part of enterprise agreement.

Many employers already provide such higher levels, often through a combination of contributions to industry funds and employer funds. In such cases, the Government expects negotiations between the parties on a case-by-case basis would determine the fund or funds to which Superannuation Guarantee/award contributions would be made. Any breakdown in negotiations should be referred to the relevant industrial tribunal.
EXEMPTIONS

Under the Superannuation Guarantee Scheme, an employer will not be expected to provide superannuation support for employees who are under 18 years of age and who are working part-time. Income earned by a person as a member of the Defence Force Reserves will also not be taken into account.
As a result of comments on the Information Paper, the Government has also decided to exempt:
employees who earn less than $250 a month;
employees who are aged 65 or over;
non-resident employees who are paid for work undertaken outside Australia;
resident employees who are employed by non-resident employers and are paid for work undertaken outside Australia; and

"prescribed employees" (to be defined in Regulations), ie employees who are overseas executives of international corporations who come to Australia on a temporary basis to establish a branch of the company or to join an existing branch in a managerial or executive capacity.
Accordingly, the previously announced weekly and annual threshold exemptions will no longer apply.
The revised exemptions are designed to ensure that virtually all employees receive superannuation support.

There will be a maximum limit of $80,000 per annum (indexed) on the annual earning to which the superannuation guarantee requirements will apply in respect of any individual employee. That is, the superannuation guarantee will apply to the first $80,000 of salary.
ADMINISTRATION OF THE SCHEME

The Commissioner of Taxation will be responsible for administering the Superannuation Guarantee Scheme. The scheme will be administered on a self-assessment basis with generally only those employers who are liable to pay the superannuation guarantee charge required to furnish a statement to the Australian Taxation Office. The statement and charge will be required to be lodged and paid by 14 August in the following financial year.
REDISTRIBUTION

Revenue collected under the Bill will be placed in the Consolidated Revenue Fund. An amount equivalent to the charge, less the administration component will be redistributed to a complying superannuation fund for the benefit of those employees in respect of whom the charge was paid. Employees will have a choice as to which fund these amounts go to.
CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS

In the Information Paper a number of amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act were proposed. These amendments were included in the Superannuation Guarantee (Consequential Amendments) Bill introduced on 30 April 1992.

The minimum level of support required by the superannuation guarantee will have to be compulsorily preserved from 1 July 1993. The Government has decided to extend this deadline from 1 July 1992, to provide time for schemes to amend their trust deeds where necessary. Employers will, however, remain liable to provide the minimum required level of vested benefit to all non-exempt employees from 1 July 1992.
FINANCIAL MARKET

It is estimated that employers will remit an insignificant amount of charge in the 1992-93 year and $17 million in subsequent years of which amount $15 million is expected to be redistributed for employees.
CONCLUSION

The Government believes these measures represent a major step forward in the development of retirement incomes policy and will lay the foundation for income security and higher standards of living in retirement for virtually all workers.
I present the explanatory memorandums for this Bill and for the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYMENT (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

This Bill proposes amendments to the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 ("The CERC Act") and the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991 ("The OH&S Act"). It also proposes technical, drafting and consequential amendments to other Acts.
The provisions of the Bill are explained in the explanatory memorandum. I propose to therefore confine my comments to the major amendments.

The main focus of the Bill is to continue the reform of Commonwealth employees' compensation arrangements in line with the recommendations of the Brown Review of the Comcare program. In this, it fulfils the Government's undertaking that this would be done in the present sittings.

The Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees ("The Commission") which operated as Comcare, was established under the CERC Act. Its purpose was effectively to manage the Commonwealth Public Sector Workers' Compensation System. The Commission's role in the prevention of workplace injury and disease through improved occupational health and safety practices and the rehabilitation of injured workers was emphasised.

In December 1990, Mr Ron Brown, a Management Consultant, was commissioned to carry out a comprehensive review of the Comcare program. The Brown review involved consideration of the effectiveness of the Comcare scheme and recommendation of policy and legislative changes needed to better achieve the Government's objectives.

The review acknowledged the success of improvements in workers' compensation arrangements and policy achieved by the commission since its establishment under this Government. Nevertheless it targeted additional areas where effectiveness could be enhanced.

In December 1991, the first step in implementing the Brown Review's recommendations was taken. The Commission was restructured as a regulatory body distinct from Comcare and with a separate chairperson. It is responsible for regulatory functions associated with the CERC Act and the OH&S Act. This includes determining compensation premiums.

Comcare was restructured as a service delivery body, headed by its chief executive officer. It is responsible for commercial administrative and service functions under the legislation, including providing support to the Commission.
This Bill deals with two important measures designed to implement other important recommendations of the Brown Review. The Bill covers:
The licensing of Commonwealth authorities to perform certain functions under the CERC Act in respect of their own employees under the supervision of the Commission; and
Improvements in relation to Comcare's financial arrangements.
I turn first to the proposed regime for the licensing of Commonwealth authorities.

In the CERC Act in 1988, provision was made for both Australia Post and Telecom to become self-administrators of the Commonwealth Workers' Compensation Scheme. This was for a two year trial period. Under these arrangements the two organisations were responsible for all aspects of the administration of the CERC Act for their employees.
The Brown Review recommended that these self-administration arrangements should end, and be replaced with a system of licences for self-insurance and in-house claims management.

This Bill provides for the implementation of that recommendation. It does so in a way that is consistent with preserving flexibility and increasing efficiency in the operation of the Commonwealth's employee compensation arrangements. But, at the same time, it will ensure that the licensed authorities operate under an appropriate system of regulation by the Commission. That system of regulation will, among other things, ensure consistency of practice between Comcare and the licensed authorities.

Commonwealth authorities will be able to apply to the Commission for licences under the Act. The Commission will have the power to grant or refuse applications, based on their consideration against criteria set out in the legislation. An application fee will need to be paid.
The new arrangements will allow the Commission to issue three classes of licence.
A class 1 licence will allow an authority to operate as a self-insurer. The licence will transfer to the licensed authority all or part of Comcare's obligation to compensate its employees.

A class 2 licence will allow an authority to determine its own claims. The license will transfer to the licensed authority, wholly or in part, Comcare's function of determining its employees claims under the CERC Act.
A class 3 licence will allow an authority to self-insure and determine the claims of its employees.
Licences are to be subject to a system of conditions set out in the CERC Act, as well as other conditions imposed on a case-by-case basis by the Commission.

The principal statutory conditions are to be requirements that licensed authorities comply with the CERC Act and pay their annual license fees. The conditions able to be set by the Commission will include conditions limiting the maximum liability for which a licensed authority may self-insure, or in respect of which it may make a determination. If a limit is imposed by way of a condition, then once exceeded, liability to make payments or to determine a claim, or both, will revert to Comcare depending on the class of license.
Another possible condition to which a self-insurance licence may be made subject is a requirement that the licensed authority obtain specified bank or other guarantees or other specified securities.

The Government recognises that consistency, equality and independence of decision-making are of paramount importance in these processes, particularly at the review stage. Accordingly, the Commission will be able to impose a condition on a licence that the reconsideration of claims determined by a class 2 or class 3 licence holder be carried out by Comcare or another authority.
To ensure consistency and equality of decision-making, licence holders will be obliged to comply with guidelines issued by the Commission.

In addition, the Commission will be able to give a direction to a licensed authority either generally or in respect of a particular matter or class of matters. Licensed authorities are to be required by the CERC Act to comply with such directions.
It is anticipated that, exercising its powers, the Commission will set performance standards to be achieved and maintained by license holders.

Because a licensed authority will be bound, as a condition of its license to comply with the Act, a failure to comply with guidelines or directions of the Commission will involve a breach of that condition. The Commission will be able to suspend a class 2 or class 3 license or revoke a licence of any class for breach of any condition. It will also be able to direct a licensed authority to comply with conditions of the licence. The provisions of the Bill also detail the effects of a suspension or revocation.
Under the Bill's provisions the current self-administering authorities, Australia Post and Telecom, will hold class 3 licences.
The second group of amendments proposed by the Bill, linked to the implementation of the Brown Review, concerns the financial arrangements under the CERC Act.
Comcare will be allowed to enter into arrangements under which it will provide and charge fees for agreed services related to the performance by Comcare of its functions under the CERC Act.
Also included are provisions under which Comcare will collect premiums under the CERC Act on behalf of the Commonwealth.

The Bill aims at simplifying the operation of the CERC Act by including a special or standing appropriation. There will be payable to Comcare the moneys necessary to meet undischarged liabilities for claims under the previous compensation arrangements. In addition, Comcare will also be paid amounts equal to the administrative costs attributable to these claims.
There will also be payable to Comcare the moneys necessary to discharge its liabilities for claims under the CERC Act and to cover administrative costs associated with those claims.

The amounts available to Comcare under this second head are limited to the amounts of premiums it has collected together with notional interest on such of those premiums as have not from time to time been paid out, less previous payments.

The Minister for Finance may determine the opening balances for the special appropriations and the rate of notional interest to be applied to the balance from time to time in the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

The Bill also makes provision for corporations in which the Commonwealth has a substantial interest to be brought under the coverage of either or both of the CERC Act and the OH&S Act by ministerial declaration. The Government's intention is that such coverage will not be mandatory. It is intended to be granted after consultation with other Ministers involved and at the request of the boards of management of the relevant organisations.

Part 5 of this Bill provides for the recovery of the costs of administration of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991. This will have two aspects—fees for certain services and general contributions.

The Commission will be able to enter into arrangements with departments and authorities under which it will provide and charge for agreed services. Comcare is to be given a similar power under the CERC Act.

The commission will also be able to estimate contributions that are to be payable by all departments and authorities covered by the OH&S Act. In this way each department and authority will contribute to the cost of administering the Act based on its own occupational health and safety record, and having regard to other specified matters.

This will provide departments and authorities with a financial incentive to improve occupational health and safety programs, and will assist in ensuring a safe and healthy working environment for commonwealth employees.

A two-stage process of review of estimated contribution will be available. Estimates will be reviewed first by the Commission and then, if the department or authority concerned wishes it, by the Minister. Departments and authorities will be required to provide relevant information and to pay interest on late payments.
Mr President, this Bill represents an important stage in the successful implementation of changes to the workers' compensation system based on the recent Brown Review of the Comcare program.
This Bill represents substantial progress in the Government's continuing reform of the Commonwealth Employees Compensation System.
Financial Impact Statement
The amendments proposed in the Bill are not expected to have a significant financial impact.
The costs of licensing, and of regulation of licensed authorities, under the CERC Act are to be recovered from those authorities through application and annual fees.
The standing, or special, appropriations proposed to be inserted in the CERC Act will take the place of annual appropriations and are limited in their scope.

The cost recovery arrangements proposed for the OH&S Act may result in some savings in annual appropriations to the extent that costs are recovered from non-budget dependent agencies. Costs or savings in respect of budget dependent agencies are dependent upon the annual budget process and cannot be quantified.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
STATES AND NORTHERN TERRITORY GRANTS (RURAL ADJUSTMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

This Bill amends several of the provisions of the current Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS) which was introduced in January 1989 following an extensive review. At the time of setting up this revised Scheme it was envisaged that it would operate in a more flexible and innovative way to address more adequately the changing structural adjustment forces acting in the Australian agricultural sector and to more closely match the requirements for assistance of individual farmers.

In the first years of the revised Scheme, the rural economy was generally buoyant but towards the end of 1990 it had become apparent that the sector was experiencing the beginning of a severe downturn and that a number of farmers were facing financial difficulties as a result of depressed commodity prices. This was to be the first real test of the adequacy of the Scheme. In Queensland and northern New South Wales the severe drought in 1991 exacerbated the difficulties being faced by farmers in those areas.

The Department of Primary Industries and Energy undertook assessments in April and October 1991 to determine whether the assistance measures available under the Scheme were adequate to meet the pressures placed on individual farming families.

It became apparent as a result of these assessments that additional measures would need to be introduced to assist farmers with long term prospects, but in financial difficulties, as a result of the downturn. The resultant changes to the Scheme augmented the existing measures which would assist in maintaining the basis for an internationally competitive rural base. Funding was progressively increased from $62.45 million in 1990—91 to $193.91 million for 1991—92 and at present some 10,000 farmers are receiving RAS assistance.

These variations, in conjunction with other initiatives such as the modification of hardship provisions under the Social Security Act have provided a safety net for those farmers facing severe financial difficulties.

There is provision under the Agreement to amend the terms and provisions available under the Scheme provided that the concurrence is sought from State and Territory Ministers. This provision has been particularly useful as it has allowed access to the assistance without delay. The first two amendments have been made by Agreement between the Commonwealth and the States and Northern Territory. It is now appropriate to bring these amendments before the Commonwealth Parliament.

The third amendment being introduced at this time is to formally extend the Scheme to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). Following self government, the Territory has assumed responsibility for program delivery. There has been very little demand for assistance under the Scheme by the Territory's farmers as there are only 230 farmers in the ACT of which approximately 25% would be assessed as being bona fide farmers under the criteria laid out in the Agreement. Under the current arrangements, New South Wales has been acting as an agent for the administration of the Scheme where there has been a need for assistance for ACT farmers. While there has been little demand to date, it is only equitable that those few genuine farmers in the ACT should also have access to the RAS.

The first initiative to be introduced was the new measure available under Part A of the Scheme entitled "Debt Restructuring with Interest Subsidies" or DRIS. Farmers, who have long term prospects in farming, but due to various reasons including low incomes, are not able to obtain further finance from their creditors, may be eligible for an interest subsidy on their existing debts. This measure was designed to improve farmers' cash flows. This provision has been applied with other measures available under the RAS, such as the support to obtain carry—on finance to meet the individual needs of farmers.

Following the Prime Minister's Economic Statement in February 1992, additional funds were provided which will assist some farmers to plant broadacre and sugar crops in the 1992 winter and 1992—93 summer crop planting seasons. The crop planting scheme is designed to support the provision of working capital for crop plantings and raise confidence in the broadacre industries. For this purpose broadacre crops have been defined as cereals, coarse grains, oilseeds, peanuts and grain legumes. Needy producers in the sugar industry are also included. These industries are in need of working capital.

Assistance for crop planting has been available since March 1992 under Part B of the Scheme. Support is in the form of a 75 percent interest subsidy on their commercial crop planting loans. Under the terms and provisions that have been agreed with the States, to be eligible for assistance the farm enterprise should be profitable in the long term, but unable to obtain sufficient commercial carry—on finance to undertake normal cropping programs. Assistance will be limited to a maximum $10,000 subsidy and can be used for normal crop planting expenses such as wages, seed, fertiliser, fuel and repairs.

In the development of a national drought policy, the provision of relief for farmers affected by dry seasonal conditions is provided under Part B of the Scheme. This component supports farmers in financial difficulties through causes beyond their control, to obtain carry—on finance through the provision of interest subsidies on commercial borrowings. Part B assistance was activated in 1991 primarily because of the severe financial hardship being suffered by many farmers as a result of the low commodity prices, but this situation was compounded in Queensland and northern New South Wales by the severe drought conditions in the latter part of the year. Under the arrangements for the current Scheme, funding for Part B has been shared equally by the Commonwealth and the States. In recognition of the difficulty of some States to provide matching funds, the Commonwealth agreed in October 1991 to alter the funding contribution. Under the revised funding arrangements for Part B, the Commonwealth will provide two dollars for each dollar provided by the States.

The Scheme has, in general, withstood the considerable pressures exerted by the downturn and drought. These new measures have contributed significantly to the effectiveness of the Scheme. They have complemented the measures already available under the Scheme as well as a number of other Commonwealth and state programs that have also been under similar pressure to support the rural sector through this crisis. Evidence suggest that 1991—92 will prove to be the lowest point of the adverse conditions in the sector and that 1992—93 will see a recovery.

The Scheme is currently being evaluated in line with Government policy of regularly reviewing the effectiveness of its programs. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will be reporting on the outcome of this review to the next meeting of the Agricultural Council of Australia and New Zealand at the end of July. The evaluation may recommend the need to further modify the Scheme in order to meet the primary objective of ensuring structural adjustment in the industry. The manner in which the Scheme has coped through the downturn will be closely scrutinised, in particular its effectiveness in assisting to modify the effects of future downturns in the farming in Australia.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1992
This Bill proposes to amend the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1988 to give effect to an initiative for schools announced by the Prime Minister in his February 1992 One Nation statement.
The Bill provides for an additional $15 million for capital grants for non-government schools for the 1992 calendar year.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
STATES GRANTS (TAFE ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

The States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Bill 1992 provides for supplementation for 1992 recurrent grants to reflect increases in price levels and also to appropriate funds for the increases for TAFE announced in the Government's November 1991 Statement on the Economy and Employment.

The Bill gives effect to the Government's decision announced in the November Statement to provide an additional $115m for post-secondary education in 1992. This is the initial stage of the response to overcoming the problems highlighted in the Finn Report on Post-compulsory Education and Training.

Whilst the proportion of young people remaining to the end of secondary school has virtually doubled in a decade, and student numbers at our universities have risen by over 50%, this is not the case for TAFE. While student demand for TAFE and training has continued to increase strongly there has not been the growth experienced in the other sectors. The budgetary priorities of State Governments, who have responsibility in this area, together with labour market conditions have limited training opportunities in the TAFE sector.

Discussions between the States and the Commonwealth the funding issues raised by the Finn Report are still in progress but this funding initiative, when taken together with other funding initiatives announced in the Prime Ministers "One Nation" statement, will contribute markedly towards setting funding for vocational education and training on a proper basis.

The Commonwealth is extending its original offer to the States and Territories on TAFE funding and is offering to take full funding responsibility for the development of a new and expanded system of institutes of vocational education. In the context of this offer, the Commonwealth will provide an additional $720m over the 1993-1995 triennium to fund growth in the system. However, this Bill is confined to additional 1992 funding and further legislation will be introduced in the Budget Session.
The effect of the changes is that the Bill provides for an additional $98.904m in recurrent funding and an additional $3.490m in capital funding taking the total funds available in 1992 to $475.307m.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1992

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988. The Act provides Commonwealth grants of financial assistance to the States, the Northern Territory and higher education institutions for the provision of higher education. This Bill provides increased funding for higher education institutions of $46.7 million in 1992, $29.7 million in 1993 and $9.5 million in 1994.

In accordance with the Government's cost supplementation arrangements, the Bill provides for additional funds over the 1992 to 1994 triennium to take account of movements in the Department of Employment, Education and Training's higher education salary and non-salary indexes.

The Bill also gives effect to Government decisions on higher education announced in the former Prime Minister's November 1991 statement on the economy and employment and in the Prime Minister's February 1992 economic statement. The Bill provides an extra $38.4 million in 1992, $21.5 million in 1993 and $15.7 million in 1994 for additional student places and for higher education capital works.

The Bill also provides for a technical adjustment of funds payable to institutions between operating grants and amounts payable via the Higher Education Trust Fund in respect of HECS student liabilities. The variations reflect an on-going adjustment to the level of funds available through the Trust Fund as estimates are adjusted to take account of actual student numbers. These adjustments do not affect the total level of funding available to the higher education system.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we adjourned this discussion some weeks ago, we were considering questions relating to the ADCNET program, the Australian diplomatic corps network program of computer procurement by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The Committee of the Whole will recall that there have been a number of questions raised about the tender process. The question principally that I was concerned with, both in the Estimates Committee and in the Committee of the Whole, was whether or not the awarding of the contract to HP was done in a manner to effectively exclude products from an Australian company, Labtam, in respect of terminals for the ADCNET program. The Government has recognised the need for departments to ensure, so far as is possible, that Australian and New Zealand goods and services are given a fair go. The tender document stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has directed Commonwealth agencies not to draw up purchasing specifications (including technical, performance and delivery requirements) so as to exclude A/NZ products which are suitable, or reasonably adaptable, to Commonwealth needs, or to evaluate offers in a manner which is biased against Australian and New Zealand suppliers.

The structure of the tendering process in this instance was considered by the Department to require a company that was tendering for the project to give the total solution. Because of that, the principal tenderers were all foreign owned companies. So far as Labtam was concerned, it was required to offer its terminals through Hewlett-Packard which, so far as the terminals were concerned, was one of its principal competitors.

PARA.TAB: Questions relating to that matter proceeded between the Department and me at Estimates committee hearings where I indicated, when discussion was foreclosed on this matter, that there would be a number of questions that I would want answered. I am grateful to the Department for addressing this particular matter in the detail which it has. I am not satisfied with the responses in a policy sense. I am not suggesting that there is any bias on the part of the Department whatsoever. I feel, however, that there is an inherent bias in the structure of the tendering process. We have a situation where an Australian firm, under this particular tendering process, was required to go through a competitor to have its terminals considered by those who were authorised by the Department to consider the network as a whole. It is impossible, in the Committee of the Whole, to go into the details of this.

So far as the Australian producer of terminals is concerned, it has been recognised by many people, both here in Australia and internationally, that its terminals rank amongst the best in the world. It is impossible to take forward these matters of the detailed considerations of the Department's responses in the Committee of the Whole. I understand that Labtam has put this matter before the Commonwealth Ombudsman and presumably that is where the matter can be considered in detail.

I appreciate the fact that the Department has addressed this issue and is taking extremely seriously the questions that I raised on the matter. However, it is still my view that consideration should be given to the tendering process to ensure that Australian manufacturers feel confident that their products can be taken on their merits and that they do not have to go through a competitor for the purposes of having their products considered for inclusion in such a major networking system.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Harradine for his remarks and, in particular, his graceful acknowledgment that there was no question of maladministration or inappropriate behaviour in the Department's handling of the tender matter, and his further acknowledgment in that context that the Department has fully and seriously responded to the particular concerns he raised. In turn, I acknowledge the remarks he has made about the underlying policy considerations that are involved in his concerns about this matter. I assure him that the Department and the Government generally will take very much on board the purport of those remarks and will see what can be done to give companies like Labtam, which are unquestionably effective, good Australian performers, a better chance in the future when major projects of this kind are involved.

—It is on the running sheet—`program 8 Austrade, relations with Taiwan, reservation Senator Hill'. So it relates to that as well.

—That is why I am seeking guidance. I am not so sure that it is limited to that.
—On the point of order, if it is a point of order, Mr Chairman—
—No, I am seeking guidance.
—I am being assisted.
—Senator Hill's reservation is about relations with Taiwan. Program 8 may be about Austrade, but the reservation is only about Austrade in so far as it bears upon Taiwan.
—That is quite correct.

—Then I might ask some general questions concerning Austrade and trade relations, and generally our relationship with Taiwan and how that might be affected individually. I ask the Minister whether or not he is aware of any approved migration schemes operated by Australians with regard to Taiwan.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Not as I am presently advised. There may or may not be such schemes, but I am not aware of anything as I stand here now.

—The Public Accounts Committee, when it did an investigation into the business migration program, was very critical of that program and the way in which it was administered, pointing out that on many occasions it was used as a scam whereby people would bring money in. There was no proof or check that the money would actually stay here; it could be moved out. Indeed, the scheme has subsequently been abandoned and a new one introduced. I wonder whether the Minister could inform me how many people came into Australia from Taiwan under that scheme?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —With the utmost respect, Mr Chairman, that is an immigration matter. It has nothing whatsoever to do with Foreign Affairs. It must be the case that our relations with Taiwan, as a matter that is properly the subject of discussion under Estimates Committee B, are to do with Foreign Affairs' relationship with Taiwan. It is not the relations with Taiwan as they are administered by other departments. I am simply not in a position to give that information, and it should be sought from other departments in an appropriate context.

—That is not quite true, of course, in that there is the question of our relationship with Taiwan whereby we do not have, of course, full diplomatic exchanges and we still go through the motions of saying that we have only trading relations and that they are conducted by the Chamber of Commerce and so on. So DFAT plays a very relevant part in this matter. I would have thought that it would have been quite within its purview, as it is concerned with business relationships—and that is the brief under which our representation in Taiwan exists, despite the fact, of course, that it has DFAT staff in that post. I ask the Minister again for any records that he might have.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that my Department simply does not keep records of that kind.

—In the light of that question, of course, we have on the record the fact that the then Minister, Senator Richardson, five years ago exercised directly influence in a ministerial area that was not his. Then, on 18 March this year, there was another immigration request concerning Mr Symons, Senator Richardson's good friend, who was trying to get a Taiwanese national, who was the son of an investor, into Australia. Of course, he was to come into Australia as a consultant. That well known company Multiplex in fact wrote and said that it wanted this particular Taiwanese person to come into Australia. As our only representation in Taiwan is a commercial one and it has to be dealt with by another post—and that post, of course, is the responsibility of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade—I wonder whether the Minister could tell me what records he has in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade relating to this particular matter on or about 18 March this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can do is advise Senator Bishop of the content in relevant part of a detailed letter which was sent yesterday to Mr Peacock, the Opposition spokesman on trade, by my colleague the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Mr Kerin), in which he responded specifically to a series of questions put to him by Mr Peacock. It might be helpful if I took this opportunity to read those questions and answers into the record, because they probably do address the series of questions that Senator Bishop has in mind here. I am reading the relevant part from Mr Kerin's letter of 26 May which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Point by point, you asked:
`Did Austrade provide any market advice or information to Mr Symons about business migration schemes in general or particularly about interest in such schemes in Hong Kong and Taiwan?'
Austrade informs me that it has no record or memory of providing any such advice to Mr Symons either in Australia or overseas.
`Did Austrade provide Mr Symons with contacts, introductions or other in-market services in Hong Kong and Taiwan (through the Australian Chamber of Commerce in Taipei)?'

Austrade informs me that its Hong Kong office holds no correspondence or records relating to Mr Symons nor has any recollection of contact. The office further notes that any matters concerning business migration would normally be handled by the Immigration Section of the Consulate, rather than by Austrade. The Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei has informed Austrade that it has had no contact with Mr Symons including through its Visa Service director who would be the most likely point of contact on business migration matters.

`Was Austrade provided with briefing on the matter by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, particularly in relation to Senator Kerry Sibraa's approach to the Australian Embassy in Washington for assistance for Mr Symons?'
Austrade informs me that neither it nor DFAT has any record or memory of briefings on this issue being provided to Austrade including by the Embassy in Washington.
`Was there any correspondence between Senator Richardson and the Australian Trade Commissioner in Hong Kong concerning Mr Symons' scheme?'
Austrade informs me that a check of the files in the Hong Kong Office through its correspondence tracker has not located any correspondence related to Senator Richardson or Mr Symons.

That pretty well exhausts the range of matters that Senator Bishop seems to be concerned with. My point stands that DFAT has no direct involvement in this. Austrade does have a potentially marginal involvement through its Hong Kong office, but in the particular context of the matter with which Senator Bishop is concerned, the answers are as I have just relayed them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder if the Minister would be so kind as to table that letter so that I can have the benefit of having a copy of it?

—It is a letter from Mr Kerin to Senator Bishop's colleague Mr Peacock and I think I would need to get the permission of either or both of them before I could reasonably do that. I have read in relevant part the extracts from it and I will seek their reaction to that.

—With respect, my memory is pretty good and I listened to what the Minister had to say. In terms of asking follow-up questions, I would like to see what is written. The Minister is the senior Minister in this portfolio, is he not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but there are conventions governing correspondence, including one so far as the Senator Bishop's own colleague is concerned, and I do not think it is appropriate for me to do that. I will get a photocopy masking out the relevant bits that I have just dealt with and get that across to the honourable senator as soon as I can.
—I find it a quite interesting distinction that the Minister is drawing between reading out somebody's private correspondence and letting someone have a look at it.
—Don't be tiresome. I am trying to be helpful.

—I am very pleased to hear that, but I am most interested to hear that the search was conducted concerning any correspondence or approaches by Mr Symons and/or Senator Richardson. I ask a further question as to what inquiries were made in this regard by Multiplex and any officer of Multiplex, as there is certainly an association there.
—What inquiries?

—The same inquiries the Minister carried out with regard to Mr Symons and Senator Richardson and their contact with the Chamber of Commerce in Taipei and the Hong Kong mission I would like carried out with regard to the firm of Multiplex concerning business migration.
—That can be done.

—I thank the Minister. Again, on the record we have the information that this Taiwanese gentleman was wanted in Australia by Multiplex and Senator Richardson applied to the embassy in Fiji. I imagine that records must be available as to why the inquiry was made through Fiji when we were dealing with a Taiwanese national. I wonder whether we could have particulars of that, including the correspondence written by Multiplex—I understand it was a letter written by Mr Ross McGibbon—and, similarly, the correspondence written by Senator Richardson.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —With the utmost respect, we have moved considerably away from relations with Taiwan. That is a matter that could and should properly be directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs or his representative in this chamber, who I am sure is equipped to respond to it. I will pass on the substance of Senator Bishop's inquiry to him. I think it is a question that should be directed in that context.
—The only problem with that suggestion is that it is the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade that is responsible for the visas.
—No, it is not.
—Is the Department responsible for the mission?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we are responsible for the conduct of missions, but visa issuing is a matter, if Senator Bishop has not quite caught up with the administrative arrangements of this country, that is done by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. There is usually a visa-issuing section within Australian missions overseas, but that is invariably staffed by DILGEA officers.
—Who report to?

—There is managerial oversight by the head of mission, who is usually a Foreign Affairs officer, of course, but there is in no sense policy responsibility for the visa decisions that are made. That is directly the responsibility of the Department of Immigration.

PARA.TAB: There tends to be constant confusion in the public mind on these matters. Foreign Affairs is responsible for passport issuing to Australians going overseas; but people coming into Australia, the meeting of entry requirements and the conditions on which visas are issued are matters for the Department of Immigration. Any questions about that should be directed to the Minister for Immigration, not to Foreign Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite well aware of the manner in which visas are issued. However, the point I was making is this: the people from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs are within the confines of the mission, the mission is headed up by a person from DFAT, and there is a sharing of information and files. If the Minister tells me that the two groups are kept entirely separate and that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has no knowledge of people who are applying for visas or is asked for no input, I find that most extraordinary. I would be interested if the Minister would tell me whether that is the case.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —It sometimes happens that a question is addressed to a Foreign Affairs officer for follow-up in some matters. As I indicated in the Senate yesterday, in the particular case of Suva, my understanding is that a Foreign Affairs officer was involved in relation to a visa matter to the extent that his advice was sought in getting some police information—wearing his hat as the local police liaison officer. So matters of that kind can arise.

PARA.TAB: With the utmost respect, if Senator Bishop wants to pursue that question, now is not the appropriate time to do so. We are trying to keep these Estimates discussions within proper bounds. The only basis for argument here is about relations with Taiwan. Even on the longest bow that one can stretch, a visa application made in Suva does not, on my understanding, have anything to do with relations with Taiwan. Mr Chairman, I ask you to rule accordingly. There are other opportunities to pursue that other matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand that the Minister does not want to answer questions in these areas. He is having what one might call a bit of a rough ride; it might get rougher. But the point I am making through you, Mr Chairman, to the Minister, is that because of the nature of our relationship with Taiwan, the question of visa entry is dealt with not in Taipei but by other missions, normally Hong Kong. On this particular occasion it seems to have been dealt with by Suva, and I want to know why.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Mr Chairman. I have asked you for a ruling as to whether this is a matter appropriately dealt with in this particular context. I have not got any further information in front of me anyway on which I could answer that question because I did not believe it was the kind of thing that was likely to arise in this context. I seek your ruling before I seek such information.

—In a circular way the matter does relate to relations with Taiwan. But I would perhaps suggest to the Minister and Senator Bishop that, if it is not within the purview of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, it is probably best pursued elsewhere.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman—I note your point. I think we have to say that indeed this is within the purview of DFAT because of the very nature of our relations with Taiwan. The Chamber of Commerce is the vehicle that is used to have a de facto mission in Taipei. It is, de facto, the responsibility of DFAT.

PARA.TAB: There is, as I said, no facility within Taipei for the issuing of visas or for dealing with those matters. Although it is, technically, Immigration that issues the visas, there is great consultation between DFAT officers and officers of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, who fall under the jurisdiction and responsibility of the head of mission—who, of course, is a DFAT officer. As I said, these matters are normally dealt with out of Taipei in Hong Kong.

This particular request for a Taiwanese national to come to Australia was dealt with in Fiji and I want to know why. If Senator Evans tells me that he does not know off the top of his head, I will not be surprised because we often get answers of that nature. I am asking whether he can inquire of his Department as to why that is the case and what the record shows.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to why what is the case?
—Why the matter was dealt with in Fiji and not in Hong Kong.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding, to the extent that I can answer this with such material as is now in front of me, is that the question arose in this way because a Taiwanese person applied to the Australian Embassy in Suva for a multiple entry visa to visit Australia to enable him to carry out some consultancy work in relation to his business dealings with Mr Symons in the Marshall Islands. Why he applied to the Australian Embassy in Suva as distinct from the Australian mission in Hong Kong or the Australian mission anywhere else, I do not know.

—Perhaps the Minister could tell me what was the outcome of that initial application for a multiple visa and whether or not at that stage there was an accompanying letter from Mr Ross McGibbon of Multiplex.
—I am not sure whether we are straying into another department here, but I will call the Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no information on that. It is a matter for the Immigration Minister. The outcome of any particular visa application, the documentation that may have been relevant to it and whether or not the answer is an appropriate matter to put on the public record for reasons of confidentiality or whatever, are all properly matters to be addressed to and responded to by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs or his representative, not me.

—In that case, I ask the Minister to ask his Department to search its files to see whether there is a copy of any correspondence from Senator Richardson concerning this matter and/or a letter from Multiplex. I ask that because of the way in which letters concerning Mr Symons and Senator Richardson have turned up in the Minister's files. I think there is good cause, and it would be in the public interest, that such a search be made.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to respond to a request to see whether there is anything in the files of Foreign Affairs relating to this particular matter. That is a specific request about specific material and specific files within my Department's control, so I am happy to respond to that. I cannot respond off the top of my head, but I will seek that information and let the honourable senator know.

—At the same time, I wonder whether the Minister could cause a similar search to be made to see whether any grants were made by Austrade in respect of any of these people that we have been dealing with under the DIFF scheme or the EMDG scheme, or any other grant that may be available. I say that knowing full well that the Minister only became responsible for Austrade in November last year. However, he has been responsible for the DIFF scheme.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek your guidance again, Mr Chairman. Which people are we talking about? A Taiwanese applicant for—
—We are talking about a Taiwanese immigration scheme or other business operations that relate to Taiwan and Mr Symons.

—I am perfectly prepared to answer in another context—namely, in Question Time or if the occasion otherwise properly comes up—questions as to the nature of any payments that have been made under the EMDG scheme or DIFF to Mr Symons and companies associated with him and matters of that kind. I am perfectly prepared to do that. In the context of this particular Estimates debate, it seems to me, with the utmost respect, that we are not now dealing with anything remotely within the realm of Senator Hill's reservation.We are talking about a business migration scheme that might have had one Taiwanese participant running it. We are not talking about a Taiwanese scheme as such. If Senator Bishop is asking me about something to do with Taiwan specifically, in relation to which there may have been some government grant, I am happy to seek the information, but that is not what I understand her question to be about.

—The real purpose of the question concerns the fact that the Minister made the comment that this concerned one Taiwanese person. We do not know that; in fact, we know very little. I am looking at program 8 of the appropriation. The objective is to increase the international success of Australian business. Under the derivation of program specific variation is the additional estimate of $145,000. That concerns an increase in salary payments, which is a pretty general appropriation.

PARA.TAB: The question I am asking the Minister relates to Austrade's activities in not only business migration schemes but also any business undertakings involving Taiwanese nationals and Mr Symons. I ask the Minister to cause his Department's files to be searched to see what relevant documentation, correspondence or any other material exists in his files pertaining to Mr Symons, Taiwanese nationals and any business endeavours. In asking that, I would ask the Minister specifically to inform me whether or not he has all the records of Austrade or whether he is only able to search back to November of last year.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am perfectly capable of searching back all the records of Austrade, going back in time. I am perfectly prepared to answer in an appropriate context questions about EMDG or other grants to businesses with which Mr Symons has been associated. If Senator Bishop is asking me in the context of this particular debate to identify any particular business or firm in which Mr Symons has been associated with a Taiwanese national and in that context to advise her as to whether there has been any EMDG or similar grants, I suppose I can do so, but it is a long bow in the context of the jurisdiction of this debate. If there is information about Mr Symons being associated with a Taiwanese national in relation to a particular business, and if we have further information that a grant has been made to that particular business in which the two of them have been associated, or Mr Symons and any multiple number of Taiwanese nationals, I am happy to seek that information. I understand that that is how Senator Bishop is casting the question in order to bring it within the scope of this debate.

—Just so that we understand and do not limit what I am asking, pursuant to the reservation of Senator Hill concerning program 8 of the PPS notes—a requirement for an additional appropriation for Austrade—I am asking the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to cause a search to be made in his Department for any documentation relating to Mr Symons and Taiwanese nationals as it may pertain to any business enterprise at all. I do not want it to be limited to the granting of a grant; I want to know whatever correspondence he has from Mr Symons concerning Taiwanese nationals. I feel that, because this matter is so much in the public interest, it would be quite inappropriate for anyone to try to claim commercial-in-confidence. I ask the Minister to conduct that search and to report back to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —If we have anything in our files departmentally or in Austrade to do with Mr Symons—can Senator Bishop get the pronunciation of that name right, please, after all this time—and Taiwanese nationals—
—What makes you an authority on how to pronounce it, Gareth?

—I think Senator Richardson is an authority on the subject—that has been established—and that is the way he pronounces it, so I think that ought to shut Senator Crichton-Browne up, with the utmost respect. If we have anything at all in our system about Mr Symons's association with Taiwanese nationals in any context whatsoever, I would be perfectly happy to put that on the record, subject to normal FOI public interest considerations. Senator Bishop, with all the cheek in the world, cannot pre-empt anything about commercial confidentiality because those considerations will always be relevant. I will certainly see what information there is.

—I add to that that even the Minister has to admit that this matter has now been dragged screaming into the public interest, despite the fact that he is unwilling to investigate the matter at all and despite the fact that his answers to the Senate on the way he has disclosed a knowledge or lack of knowledge leave many questions to be answered. They will not be asked here; they will be asked in a different way. I am foreshadowing that the public interest in this matter is overriding any of the things that the Minister may, in ordinary circumstances, like to try to say would protect the information from FOI or, indeed, inquiry from the Senate.
—The question is that the report be agreed to in relation to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. That being the case, the Committee will turn to the Department of Finance.

PARA.TAB: We will follow the running sheet. Are there any matters that honourable senators would like to raise on the running sheet before we get to the heading called `General'? It seems to me that if we are looking at particular questions it is probably worth while mentioning them within the context of the subheadings that follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I think we have to put something on the record concerning the things that Senator Evans told me a few minutes ago. You will recall that we had a great to-do about the letter from which he read—
—I raise a point of order.
—I am speaking to a point of order. Senator McMullan may reply when I finish.
—What is the point of order?

—I am making it. The point of order is that Senator Evans declined to make a letter available to me because, as he said, the letter was a private correspondence between Mr Kerin and Mr Peacock. In fact, Mr Peacock released the letter onto the public record yesterday.
—That's fine.
—It is not fine. Senator Evans stood there and said that he could not do it. He had a box full of advisers. Does that mean that he is still not on top of his Department?
—Order!
—Have a glass of Largactil.
—Would you please withdraw that!
—I did not hear what was said.
—That statement by Senator Faulkner was quite unparliamentary and I ask him to withdraw it.
—Order! I did not hear the interjection because I was speaking at the time but it has been objected to and I think that Senator Faulkner has withdrawn.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I have heard Senator Bishop's fulmination on this subject, purporting to be a point of order which it manifestly was not. I simply say for the record that I was not aware that Mr Peacock had put that correspondence on the public record.
—And none of your advisers?
—Order! Senator Walters, you do not have the call.

—To the extent that it has been put on the public record, I am happy for the whole letter to be made available. It is hardly necessary to make it available to Senator Bishop because she obviously has it, but I am happy for it to be incorporated in the text of Hansard at the relevant point if that is thought to be helpful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point of my point of order was that—
—It was not a point of order.
—Order! I have given the call to Senator Bishop.

—The point that I wished to raise was that Senator Evans stood there and told me that this matter was a private correspondence when in fact it was on the record as at 26 May. He had a box full of advisers. He is now trying to tell me that it is okay to have it on the public record when somebody else has done it. The point is that he is demonstrating yet again that he is not in touch with or on top of his Department, or else he deliberately misled this Senate again.
—Order! The Department before the chamber is the Department of Finance.
