—I have the letter and I would like to—

—Order! The matters that are to be raised now are in relation to the Department of Finance. I asked whether there were any matters before the subheading `General' on the running sheet. I suggested that if there were they could probably be taken with the other matters. We will go to the heading on the running sheet called `General'.

—Mr Chairman, on a point of order: with respect to the matter that Senator Bishop has raised, could I suggest to you that she has raised a very relevant point. The Minister misrepresented the situation when that Department was being debated. I think Senator Bishop has very properly and correctly raised the matter now before we start with the Department of Finance, despite the fact that technically—I accept, technically—we had finished with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Before we had started on Finance, a matter arose which showed that the Minister misled the Senate on this matter. Senator Bishop has every right to raise this in the interests of the Senate and, indeed, in the interests of the Minister.

—The point is that I had put the question that the report be agreed to in relation to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and it was accepted. If we are going to go back to that, that decision will have to be rescinded.

—Mr Chairman, I wonder then if I could move a rescission motion in order that the letter may be put onto the record. I received the letter after we had voted on that motion. It was brought to me by my colleague Senator Walters.
—I think that the best course of action might be for you to seek leave and I will take your comment as seeking leave. Is leave granted?
—What has Senator Bishop sought leave to do?
—If you had been listening, you would have heard.
—Can I make it clear why I am requesting, given we have the boofheaded interjection?
—Oh, excuse me! Mr Chairman, on a point of order—
—No, I am speaking. We have had four interjections that are out of order. I am seeking clarification of that for which she is seeking leave.
—Order! Senator McMullan, that was an uncalled for statement. I would ask you to withdraw it.
—I beg your pardon?
—The term that you used, `boofhead', was uncalled for. I ask you to withdraw it.
—If you ask me to withdraw it, Mr Chairman, I withdraw it.
—Stand up and withdraw it then.
—Order! The honourable senator has withdrawn. Senator Bishop, I would be grateful if you could just indicate again what you are seeking leave for.

—I am seeking leave very simply because Senator Evans misled the Committee by saying that certain correspondence was private correspondence between Mr Kerin and Mr Peacock when in fact the letter had been put on the public record yesterday by Mr Peacock. Quite clearly, with the great plethora of advisers, Senator Evans cannot simply plead ignorance and I would like the letter on the record. I seek leave at this point to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Hon Andrew Peacock MP
Opposition Spokesman on Trade
RG 49
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Andrew

It seems sensible to address in writing some of the issues raised by you about the Export Market Development Scheme (EMDG) over the past few weeks, and in particular to address the specific points raised in your press release of 20 May about the EMDG and questions relating to Austrade's broader involvement with Mr Symons.
Point by point, you asked;
"Did Austrade provide any marked advice or information to Mr Symons about business migration schemes in general or particularly about interest in such schemes in Hong Kong and Taiwan?
Austrade informs me that it has no record or memory of providing any such advice to Mr Symons either in Australia or overseas.
"Did Austrade provide Mr Symons with contacts, introductions or other in-marked services in Hong Kong or Taiwan (through the Australian Chamber of Commerce in Taipei)?

Austrade informs me that its Hong Kong office holds no correspondence or records relating to Mr Symons nor has any recollection of contact. The office further notes that any matters concerning business migration would normally be handled by the Immigration Section of the Consulate, rather than by Austrade. The Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei has informed Austrade that it has had no contact with Mr Symons including through its Visa Service director who would be the most likely point of contact on business migration matters.

"Was Austrade provided with briefing on the matter by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, particularly in relation to Senator Kerry Sibraa's approach to the Australian Embassy in Washington for assistance for Mr Symons?
Austrade informs me that neither it nor DFAT has any record or memory of briefings on this issue being provided to Austrade including by the Embassy in Washington.
"Was there any correspondence between Senator Richardson and the Australian Trade Commissioner in Hong Kong concerning Mr Symons' scheme?
Austrade informs me that a check of the files in the Hong Kong Office through its correspondence tracker has not located any correspondence related to Senator Richardson or Mr Symons.
"Was Austrade also directed by the Prime Minister to search its files for any information relevant to the Symons Affair? If not, why not?

Austrade was asked by my Office to look for information relevant to the Symons affair, as well as being prompted by your press releases and Freedom of Information requests to conduct a search on its own behalf. A direct request from the Prime Minister was therefore unnecessary.
"What other companies involved in the Marshall Islands technology park and educational scheme also received EMDG grants related to the project?

This question appears to be based on a misunderstanding on your part, in that Austrade has already made clear that neither Mr Symons nor Feedtech Pty. Ltd. has received EMDG monies related to that project. Austrade informs me that it has no record of an EMDG being awarded which is in any way related to this project in the Marshall Islands.

Having answered the specific points raised in your press release, let me now address a more general issue relating to the EMDG Scheme with which the coalition parties seem to be having some difficulty.

The EMDG scheme provides taxable cash grants based on eligible export development expenditure already incurred: ie. quantitative and evidentiary rather than qualitative and discretionary criteria are the basis for payment.
Those quantitative criteria are rigorously applied to EMDG applications by Austrade's Investigation Officers in much the same way a tax return is assessed by the Taxation Office.

Because the criteria are quantitative rather that qualitative there is no margin of improper external influence. Eligibility criteria are either met or they are not: end of story. This also ensures that the scheme can be administered efficiently and effectively at a cost of about 1.3 per cent of grant funding.

I trust I have gone some way towards correcting the confusion which seems to prevail in Opposition discussion of this issue—confusion which I might add did not seem so prevalent in the Opposition's support for the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill (No2) which followed a thoroughgoing review of the EMDG Scheme and was enacted in December 1990 after debate in both Houses.

Your colleague, Mr Ian McLachlan, the Member for Barker, in speaking to the EMDG Bill, referred to it as `a piece of quite complex legislation enacting complex changes to a scheme which involves a plethora of eligibility criteria, rules and definitions.' (Hansard, 14/11/90)
In your press release of 19 May 1992, only 18 months later, you refer to your `call for a review and tightening of the eligibility criteria for Export Market Development Grant EMDG) awards.'

The Coalition supported that legislation. It had no concerns about the eligibility criteria being loose or unsatisfactory at that time—in fact, based on the Member for Barker's comments, it is reasonable to assume that at least some in the Coalition found the eligibility criteria too stringent and restrictive.
Your recent `call for a review and tightening of eligibility criteria' sits a little awkwardly with this position.

In light of this, the deep concern your comments have aroused among the many Australian businesses who benefit from the EMDG Scheme is an unnecessary and disturbing development. I am sure you are aware of this, as many of the letters I have received on this matter over recent days have also been copied to your Office.

All are concerned that the `review' you are calling for will limit the effectiveness and efficiency of a scheme that they value very highly. One writer even claimed that he had information that the scheme was going to cease operation as of July 1 this year. As you know, these fears are totally unfounded and are based upon your campaign which is largely politically motivated.
I seek your cooperation in quelling these fears and enabling the companies involved to concentrate on what they do best developing export markets.

A clear statement for you reaffirming the Coalition's support for the EMDG Scheme and indicating any further Coalition policy intentions in this area would be one way for you to inform all those concerned about where they stand.

This would be especially valuable to our exporters in light of your comment that `The Opposition has promised to put a broom through Austrade' press Release, l9/5/92) and in light of the Fightback! proposal to reduce funding to Austrade by $70m over two years.
I look forward to your cooperation in this matter.
I have also enclosed two background papers on the EMDG Scheme in general and the Scheme as it was applied to Mr Symons for your information.
Due to public interest in this matter I will make my reply to you available to the media.
Yours sincerely
(Signed J. Kerin)
John Kerin

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first item on the running sheet is Appropriation Bill No. 5. It is dealt with on page 5 of the report of Senate Estimates Committee B. It is also dealt with, I think, in the reservation. More particularly, it was the subject of a considerable amount of discussion during the hearings of Estimates B and that is why it is specifically mentioned on page 5 of the Committee's report to the Senate. The report reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee questioned the unusual precedent of introducing an additional appropriation bill which combined elements from appropriation bills already before Parliament with an additional amount of funds.
The Committee B report goes on to state:

The Department advised that alternative measures to introducing an additional appropriation bill, such as using the Advance to the Minister for Finance or not fulfilling contractual obligations, were considered. It was proposed that the AMF would have been placed under considerable pressure if requests from the three programs involved were received simultaneously, as was anticipated and, together with Parliament's expressed opinions on the use of the AMF, the view was adopted that it was preferable to be specific so that Parliament knew exactly the purpose of the appropriation.

That part of the Committee's report was based on the assertion by the Department and by the Government, through Senator McMullan, that there were contractual obligations that required payments to be made during the April and May period of this quarter for child-care relief and one or two other purposes. So the whole of the Government's approach and the whole rationale—the whole underpinning—for the extraordinary, unprecedented action that was taken in the introduction of Appropriation Bill (No. 5) was that there were contractual obligations that had to be fulfilled.If one reads the Senate Estimates Committee transcript, one would see that the essential reason that Senator McMullan gave was that there were contractual obligations.

PARA.TAB: My first question, given that papers were subsequently tabled and provided to the Estimates Committee—none of which, on my understanding, comprises anything remotely resembling a contract or a contractual arrangement—was why did Senator McMullan place so much weight on the contractual arrangement argument when, in fact, there are no contracts that have been provided to the Senate to verify the claim that he made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the Hansard with me to enable me to recall the relative emphasis that was given to `contractual obligations' and other reasons, although I certainly recall reference to contractual obligations, as well as other explanations. I do not have the terms, so I do not want to get into debate about the relative emphasis of each term because I do not question that. Even if it were said only once, there would still be a question as to why it was said. It remains my advice—not a matter of my personal knowledge or expertise—that under the two headings relating to urgency, that is, contractual obligations or normal expectations of people with regard to regular payments on which they may be relying, there are payments which arise relating to Appropriation Bill (No. 5). That was my advice. That is why I said it then. It remains my advice.
—I ask Senator McMullan to direct the Senate to the specific documents that he has or that the Senate may have that are of a contractual nature.

—I understand that the various contracts have already been provided, but if Senator Short is asking, `Can you point out within the documents that have been provided which aspects are contractual obligations which required action under Appropriation Bill (No. 5)?' I will give him that information subsequently. I cannot give it to him here. My advice is that it is contained within the documents already provided.

—The basic legal background to the question of contractual commitments is contained in the relevant Acts and agreements signed between the Government or its agencies and the clients. Job-training, child-care relief and residential elderly care are three programs that were the subject matter of Appropriation Bill (No. 5).

PARA.TAB: Let me draw Senator McMullan's attention to what I think we both agree are the more legal documents. In each document there is the term `the Minister may provide funds' under a certain payments schedule. In other documents it says that `subject to the availability of funds' the payments will be made, and so on. The handbooks issued in relation to some of these programs—I am looking at the child-care relief handbook—and the associated guidelines seem to go beyond the Act and the agreements that have been undertaken as a result of the Act. But the legal underpinning of the handbooks, the guidelines and the agreements must be the Act of Parliament. The Act of Parliament does not, on my reading, contain a mandatory provision for the payments in the time period that the Government said was required.

I come back to this point because I think it is of fundamental importance, given that the Government took an unprecedented action in introducing a new Appropriation Bill which amended two Appropriation Bills it had brought before the Parliament just four weeks earlier. That is an extraordinary procedure for which there surely must have been quite compelling reasons. So far, those compelling reasons do not seem to have been advanced to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short raises an important question. I think anyone listening would probably find it very arcane and detailed and obscure. Nevertheless, I recognise that there is an important underlying principle about accountability. Because I regard this as an important matter, I will check and get a written response to Senator Short if there is anything to add. My understanding is that the legislation authorises the Minister to enter into contracts and, once a contract is entered into, authorised by legislation—although the details of it may not be specified in the legislation—the contract is binding on the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: I accept the relevance of the questions that are raised. If there is information to be provided over and above that which I have given, I will provide it to Senator Short. If, for example, there is a suggestion that the guidelines go beyond the authority of the Act, I will check on those things, because they should not do so. They may be authorised by the Act to do things beyond the Act, but they cannot do things which are not authorised by the Act. I will check on those things. If there is a problem, apart from advising Senator Short, I will draw it to the attention of the responsible Minister. My understanding at the moment is that the Department of Finance is satisfied that these things are being done in accordance with the law and that the appropriations were warranted, according to the criteria I outlined before.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listeners to this discussion might think it is arcane and obscure. I do not think it is, and I am glad to see that Senator McMullan recognises the importance of the subject. What we are talking about here goes to the whole core of proper financial administration and management. It goes not just to the legality of it—that in itself is surely a matter of great significance—but as well to the Government's administration and its competence in managing its program.

PARA.TAB: On 26 or 27 February the Government introduced two Bills—Appropriation Bills No. 3 and No. 4—in the normal due process of additional estimates and additional appropriations. That is proper, accepted practice. It did it on the basis of its best understanding of its financial, revenue and expenditure requirements until the end of the financial year. That is the way things are normally done. Within four weeks of having done that, the Government said that it was forced to come into this Parliament and say, `We got it wrong only four weeks ago. Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4 do not really do the trick. We got that wrong. We have to amend them before they have even been considered properly by the Parliament, and we have to introduce another Bill'. Apart from the legalities we have been talking about, that smacks of gross financial incompetence. It is a point the Government is bound to respond to because it is typical of what appears to be happening at the moment in the financial administration of this country.

Two weeks ago the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, admitted that there was now going to be a Budget deficit for this year of $9.3 billion, when only three or four weeks earlier—despite the discussion, which Senator McMullan will recall, that we had in Estimates Committee B about the forecasts and the Budget estimates—the Government had been sticking very dogmatically to its forecast deficit for the year of $6.8 billion. Within three weeks it was forced to make an admission that it was $2 1/2 billion out. Even that $6.8 billion, which was announced in the economic statement of 26 February, was a further blow-out of an estimate that had been given as pretty firm by the new Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, in January, just a month earlier, that the deficit for this year was going to be $5.3 billion.

That one in turn was a forced admission from him, after severe questioning by the Opposition and every economic commentator in Australia who follows these matters, that the original Budget estimate of $4.7 billion was not going to be achieved. That was the Budget estimate last August. It has now had three revisions: in January to $5.3 billion; in February to $6.8 billion; and on 11 May to $9.3 billion. Heaven only knows how accurate that figure is going to be. That wrong forecasting, and the Government's admissions that it was wrong, smack of financial incompetence of the highest order.

What I am putting to Senator McMullan is that the response the Government has made, following us raising this question of the need for Appropriation Bill No. 5, simply confirms the view of the Opposition, and, I am sure, of the wider community, that the Government has lost control of and cannot forecast its financial situation, which has enormous impacts right across the financial markets, right across business, right across the whole scope of the economy. Now Senator McMullan has come into the Senate and said, `I'll have another look at it'. I put it to him frankly that that is not good enough. He should have had all those answers weeks ago. This was due to be debated two or three weeks ago, and still he does not have the answers he should have had then, if not in the Estimates Committee when this was raised.

I ask another question in relation to that. Senator McMullan raised and put great weight on the contractual obligation side of the matter as a justification for Appropriation Bill (No. 5). Therefore, could I ask why, when the Minister for Finance introduced Appropriation Bill (No. 5) in the House of Representatives, he did not mention contractual obligations as one reason for the Bill?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is ridiculous, of course, to say that I should know why somebody else did not do something. That is nonsensical.
—He is the responsible Minister.

—I am not saying whether he did it or not is not important. I am saying that it is nonsensical to expect me to know what was in his head when he made a decision at some other time and why he did not say something. There are millions of things he has not said and I do not know why he did not say any of them.

PARA.TAB: There are two points within all that windy rhetoric. One is that the deficit is larger than was predicted. That is true and is on the public record. Time and again Senator Short has put his views about why that is the case. The Minister for Finance, the Treasurer and others have responded. We will not advance the expeditious handling of Estimates by me entering into it, other than to confirm the views which they have expressed. So let us get on with the question.

The reason we were bogged down in a bit of detail about contracts is that Senator Short raised what was to me a new question, to which I was trying to respond, concerning the obligations which were entered into being beyond the power of the relevant authorising legislation. To the best of my knowledge, that question has not been raised before—certainly not according to the material that I have before me at the moment. If it were true, it would be an important point and therefore I undertook to pursue it. I did not have the answer because the honourable senator was raising something with me which had not been raised before. This is not actually directly relevant to the Department of Finance. However, it does relate to this appropriation and I am happy to pursue it. As the honourable senator would know, the legislation and the contracts to which he is referring would actually be the responsibility of other departments. Rather than hide behind that, let us pursue it and see whether it is accurate because if it is accurate, it is important.

The core of the question is that if Appropriation Bill (No. 5) had not been passed, hardship would have been caused to many individuals, companies and charitable organisations. It would have been irresponsible not to do so, and that is why we did it. That should be put on the record. This point has not come up today because we have been pursuing the legislative underpinning of the Bill. But, fundamentally, without it unnecessary and unwarranted hardship would have been caused. Therefore, we introduced the Bill and it would have been irresponsible not to have done so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly accept the hardship point. My question is: why was that hardship point not recognised adequately when Appropriation Bill (No.3) and Appropriation Bill (No.4) were introduced three to four weeks earlier? Why was it that the Government did not realise the problem it had until after the introduction of Appropriation Bills No. 3 and No.4?

PARA.TAB: What it boils down to is that, had the Government got its act right so far as its financial forecasting, administration and management were concerned, all of this would have been avoided. Appropriation Bills (No. 3) and (No. 4) would have provided the necessary amounts, unless there were contractual obligations which made that impossible because of the time involved in Senate and other consideration of the Bills. As I say, the necessary supporting evidence has not been presented to the Senate to say that those legal obligations were there.

With that as a background, I point out that on 30 March Senator McMullan claimed that almost all the amounts were due and payable on 1 April, which was only two days later. I think that was in relation to child-care. Yet, in fact payments could not be made, as I understand it, for at least seven to 10 days later, based on the time needed to obtain royal assent and other due process. That seems to me to mean either that the pressing need was not as pressing, or that it was going to be met from other sources.

I note that the Advance to the Minister for Finance was very heavily used for child-care purposes in March. An amount of $32m was utilised out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance in March. That is a very heavy usage. How much of the child-care obligations were proposed to be met via the Advance to the Minister for Finance? Had the Government been aware of that proposed use for the Advance to the Minister for Finance when the Minister made the statements that he did?

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding, and the information I have before me, is that there are payments with regard to child-care fee relief from the AMF in April. If they were made—and that is not immediately clear to me on the information in front of me—they were to be subsumed within Bill No. 5. Therefore, the Advance would have been compensated for that. The payments were anticipated in April on this document I have, which I think is very similar to that which was before me on the night of the discussion in question.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, I do not think there is any contradiction between the two positions. If payments had to be made prior to the Bill being passed, an adjustment would have been made after the Bill was passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to get it clear. Were all recipients of grants for child-care fee relief paid in full on 1 April?
—That is a matter for the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. I do not know the answer to that question. There is no particular reason why we would know that.

—Without having the document precisely in front of me—at least, I have not picked out the exact line—my understanding of the payment arrangements for child-care fee relief is that the payments are made quarterly in advance on the first day of the quarter. My question is whether that happened on this occasion.

—Given that my advice is that all that information would be in the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services—which has not yet been dealt with so it may be better to pursue it then—the information available indicates that, as Senator Short has indicated, some money was forwarded to be paid out in child-care fee relief and that other claims awaited the passage of Bill No. 5 before the money would have been transferred to the Department. In terms of explaining what were the implications for the Department's capacity to meet all its payments, that would depend upon information in the possession of that Department. So I cannot answer the question comprehensively.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Short has indicated—and I think we have the same documents—there was a payment from the AMF to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services for child-care fee relief of $32m in April, and that which was anticipated might be required was, on the figures available, $67m. It is not clear from these documents whether the Department of Health was able to meet all its obligations on 1 April with the $32m. The Department would know that rather than the Department of Finance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding, from advice I have received, is that all recipients of child-care fee relief grants were not paid on 1 April. Some were paid in part and were told that the rest would be paid later. If that is the case, why could not this whole messy debacle have been avoided and more payments delayed so that the normal due process, the parliamentary procedures that we all expected to be followed when Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4 were introduced, could have proceeded and proper parliamentary and financial management procedures adhered to?
—For the patently obvious reason that they would still be waiting for their money now because we still have not passed the other Bills.

—With respect, that is a totally inappropriate response. The other Bills are in the process of being passed. There is still, as I understand it, money in the Advance to the Minister for Finance. There could have been a readjustment of payments so that people were paid within the quarter on which the payments were due, and this procedure was not necessary.I come back to my earlier point: if the Government had had its act together as a government and as a financial manager when it should have, namely, at the time of the introduction of Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4, this very messy and very sorry debacle of financial administration and incompetence would never have arisen.

—I apologise for taking up time because we really ought to be getting on to other things as this is a boring reiteration. So that that statement does not remain on the record unchallenged, can I say briefly that the fundamental question is this: should we have allowed for these people to go unpaid—which, in the event, would have had significant adverse consequences on people in need—because we thought we could depend upon the Senate passing the Appropriation Bills quickly? We clearly would have been entirely unjustified in drawing any such conclusion, and history has borne us out.

PARA.TAB: Even if we had been able to meet the payments from the Advance to the Minister for Finance—and evidence was produced previously to indicate why we could not and the reason why, if we had not passed Appropriation Bill No. 5, problems would have arisen in that regard—I would have thought that that would have been a better ground for criticism.

I do not want to rehash all this stuff about adequate financial management. We have had that debate lots of times. The Opposition has its view and we have ours. It is a waste of time reiterating it. I just indicate that I do not share the Opposition's view, but that is not surprising to anybody. We could not justifiably leave the people in need unpaid. It was much more appropriate for them to be paid in accordance with an appropriation passed by the Parliament than from juggling the Advance, even if the resources had been available, which they were not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to pursue this any further either because I have really made the points I wanted to make. It is quite obvious that the Parliamentary Secretary will not admit that the Government got this one wrong in its preparation of the additional Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4. I cannot let him escape without saying that the point he has just raised is not the point at issue. There never was any intention on the coalition's part to cause any hardship in this matter. Indeed, we have said consistently throughout that we are not opposing these Bills.

PARA.TAB: I again put on the record that this situation need never have arisen had the Government's financial management, planning and coordination between the Department of Finance and client departments operated in the way that taxpayers and clients would reasonably expect, that is, that there be efficiency in the management of taxpayers' money and the funding of programs. If there had been efficiency, the Government would have known its requirements when Appropriation Bills (No. 3) and (No. 4) were introduced; an Appropriation Bill (No. 5) would not have been necessary.

Therefore, without pursuing this matter beyond this point, I reiterate that the point of criticism of the Government is that it got its financial planning wrong when it introduced Appropriation Bills (No. 3) and (No. 4) in February and that it has used very spurious reasons to justify the subsequent requirement of Appropriation Bill (No. 5).
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Is there anything else in `General'?

TALK.START.PARA: —The second matter is the assessment of the Fightback package. Senator Bishop and myself entered a reservation on this matter and made the following comment:

SPEECH.PARA: Officers of the Department were questioned on their involvement in the analysis of the Fightback document carried out by the Department of Finance. Witnesses before the Committee revealed that the Department had a standing brief to give Ministerial advice on matters which may be of budgetary significance. This implies that any Opposition policy is open to political scrutiny by the Department. This would compromise well meaning officers of the bureaucracy and is therefore a matter of concern.

This concern is well illustrated by the fact that the Department undertook no similar analysis of the Government's One Nation Statement. The failure so to do raises grave fears for the political neutrality of the Department's analyses.

We have had considerable discussion of this in Estimates Committee B. I do not want to traverse all that ground again. In light of the discussion that we had, and in the knowledge that the matter would be raised again in the Committee, as we are doing at the moment, I ask Senator McMullan whether he has had another look at this matter since we debated it in Estimates Committee B to satisfy himself of the reasons why the Department did not undertake an analysis of the Government's One Nation statement in the same way that it undertook a critical analysis of the Opposition's Fightback proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that the officers from the Department of Finance who appeared before the Estimates Committee in early April very adequately dealt with the propriety of their actions and of the approach that was taken with regard to the analysis of the Opposition's package. It is absurd to suggest that the role of the Department of Finance with regard to a government proposal would be the same as its analysis with regard to any other. For example, all the expenditure proposals in One Nation are subject to continuing analysis by the Department of Finance like any other Government expenditure proposal, as Senator Short well knows. He is very well informed about those things. Unlike some of his colleagues, he would be aware of that role and would understand it.

PARA.TAB: The Government's costings of those things, based on the advice from, amongst others, the Department of Finance, are public and available for scrutiny by others. That is as it should be. Proposals that come from elsewhere which have potential Budget implications—whether they are from the Opposition or from significant community groups, industry or whatever—are assessed by the Department of Finance on a quite separate basis because they do not emerge from the normal processes of the Department; they come from outside and, therefore, are subject to a quite different sort of scrutiny. Inevitably, and without any cause for surprise, alarm or concern, that is the normal course of events. It could not conceivably be otherwise. I think the question was, have I thought about it any more? The answer is no, I was satisfied on the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would Senator McMullan agree that the analysis of the Fightback proposals by the Department of Finance attempted, at least, to be detailed and was designed, amongst other things, to look at the distributional impact of Government proposals on individuals in the community?

—My recollection of the comments of the Department of Finance on Fightback is that they were substantially about the budgetary implications and alternative assessments of budgetary implications. Any detailed discussion of distributional consequences is fundamentally the responsibility of the Treasury.
—We will be pursuing those matters when the Department of the Treasury comes up. Could I have from Senator McMullan in a little detail precisely what the Department of Finance's analysis comprised?
—It is all on the public record.
—I assume that Senator McMullan is referring to the documents that were tabled by the Minister in early December; is that correct?
—Yes.
—They purported to show loopholes in the Opposition's costing of its Fightback proposals. Is that what Senator McMullan is talking about?
—Without getting into a debate about whether they purported to do it or actually did it—which is a matter we could debate on some other occasion—yes, they are the documents I am talking about.

—Concerning the analysis that was done by the Department of Finance of the expenditure proposals, is it a fact that, virtually without exception, the differences of view on the costs of the coalition's proposals were based on different underlying assumptions made in relation to the background rather than on any technical fault in the analysis; that, in the end, the comments of the Department of Finance were based essentially on different assumptions to those used by the coalition?

—I do not regard that as an Estimates committee matter. There is a document on the public record. The basis for the relative merits of it—the analysis of it—is a matter for appropriate public debate, but not here. However, if there was disagreement about the underlying assumptions as the basis for the disagreement about the revenue implications, one should not underestimate the significance of that. That is not something to be brushed aside as an irrelevant consideration. It is often overly optimistic assumptions which bring what appear to be otherwise sensible assumptions undone.

PARA.TAB: I am not saying that Senator Short was implying that; I want to make sure that the record is clear. The role the Department of Finance plays rigorously within the Government is to review departmental proposals to ensure that the assumptions are sufficiently rigorous and take sufficient concern for their implications for revenue. It would not be surprising if that were the case because that is a fairly standard function about which many departments express concern from time to time when they have disagreements with the Department of Finance. In my experience, the Department of Finance nearly always wins. History tends to vindicate the Department's judgments very often.

I do not want to get into a debate about the nature of the documents. I do not think that that is an Estimates matter. The fact that they were developed and the debate we had about how much it cost to do it are matters for an Estimates committee. What is in the documents is for political debate in other forums.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to this part of the consideration of the appropriations for the Department of Finance, I do not have any additional questions to ask on the assessment of the Fightback package under this general section but I understand that my colleague Senator Bishop does. She is unavoidably detained in a Public Accounts Committee meeting at the moment. Assuming that we do not finish consideration of the Department of Finance before her return from that meeting, I wonder whether I could seek Senator McMullan's indulgence to come back to that aspect later on if necessary, despite the fact that we might now move on to other programs.
—I say, with a marked lack of enthusiasm, yes.

—Senator Bishop and I expressed a reservation about program 2, resource management framework, relating to the netting of Reserve Bank fees and charges. We expressed our concern that the Department of Finance had not implemented the legal advice it received some time earlier, which found that its practice of netting Reserve Bank fees and charges was in breach of the Constitution. That was a matter that had been raised in a report by the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: I want to test this one out a little further in the light of the discussions we had at the time of Estimates Committee B. We have now received—I think we may have received it in the course of those discussions—correspondence in relation to this matter between the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Finance going back to June and September 1987. Yet it was only in the past few months that the fact that the Department of Finance was in effect acting unconstitutionally was discovered, or at least recognised. That was done essentially as a result of an audit by the Auditor-General.

As I said, during the Estimates hearings Senator Bishop and I expressed our concern that the earlier legal advice that had been received—that was back in 1987—had not been implemented. I ask Senator McMullan whether the Department could give us any reasons additional to those that were discussed at the time of Estimates Committee B as to why it took so long—in effect, four or five years—for that unconstitutionality to be recognised and the necessary changes implemented?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is really nothing to add. It was fairly comprehensively covered at the time. It was brought to light, as we indicated at the time, when the Auditor-General picked up this legal advice that was not being implemented. Senator Short recalls the details of the different advices that had been received by different parts of the Department at previous times. Once it was drawn to attention, it was corrected. It was obviously appropriate that it should have been corrected. Obviously it should have been done earlier and it has now been corrected.

—Now that the matter has been corrected, no further action is of course required. I again put on the record the concern of the Opposition that it took an inordinately long time, a period of years, before the unconstitutional actions and practices that had been adopted in this rather technical matter were recognised and, once recognised, the necessary changes implemented. It seems to be an extraordinary length of time. I again put on the record our concern that that was the case.

PARA.TAB: I am again forced to say that it is yet another example of the concerns that we on this side of the chamber have about the adequacy of the financial administration that is occurring at the moment. It is of lesser moment, though, because there is a lot of technicality in it, but it is another example of the reasons why we are concerned about the financial administration that is occurring under this Government. I just put that on the record. I do not expect a comment.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Giles)—If there is nothing on program 4, we move to program 5, Specific Payments and Receipts Activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop and I again entered a reservation on the work of the Commonwealth task force on asset sales where we reiterated our concern that the task force on asset sales continues to have very little success in implementing the Government's asset sales program. We stated that the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation sale is still to be resolved and that, although some of this may be due to factors beyond the task force's control, the Government's direction of how particular asset sales are conducted needs to be clarified. They were the comments that were contained in Senator Bishop's and my reservation in the report of Estimates Committee B.

PARA.TAB: I want to follow that up a little today. Fortuitously, there is an interesting article in the Australian Financial Review today, which Senator McMullan may or may not have seen, entitled `Making heavy weather of the airlines sell-off'. A lot of the comments made by the author of that article, Libby Moffet, reflect the concerns that we have expressed on numerous occasions here, in Estimates committees and elsewhere about the work of the asset sales task force and the difficulties it seems to have in consummating sales of assets and the government business enterprises. Has there been any further development since we met in Estimates Committee B in relation to the proposed sale of Australian Airlines and Qantas?

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the Estimates Committee meetings, I am advised that the expressions of interest in both airlines have closed. Those expressions of interest are being assessed. I am also advised that arrangements are being made in Sydney and Melbourne to make further information available to those people who made the expressions of interest so that they can develop those further into firm bids. I think that was indicated at the Estimates Committee as the next stage and that is progressing in accordance with the timetable we advised at that time.
—Are you at liberty at this stage to say how many expressions of interest have been received?
—No, I am sorry, I am not.
—In relation to the sale of assets of ANL, the shipping line, could Senator McMullan tell me again whether there have been any further developments since we met in Estimates Committee B?
—I am not aware of any; not so far as I know.
—As I understand it, the Government is proposing the sale of certain of the assets of ANL rather than the sale of ANL itself; is that correct?

—As Senator Short will see, the people from the task force are not here so I have checked with the responsible people from Finance. Our understanding is the same as Senator Short's, but if there is anything further I will provide it to him. Should I inadvertently not be informing him correctly, I will let him know.

—Why are the members of the task force on asset sales not here? A specific reservation was lodged and I presume it was known in advance that this matter was going to be considered in the Senate today. I would have thought that it would have been automatic that they would have been here. I ask why they are not here.

—In the normal course of events they would have been here. The expectation was that Finance would come on last night. A very important meeting had been scheduled for this morning which involves the officers, on the assumption that the officers would have been required here last night. We have tried to get as much briefing as we can. I know only the bare outlines of the meeting but if it is as has been explained to me, I think it is appropriate that they need to be at the meeting. We tried to schedule the meeting to meet the requirements of the Senate but yesterday's debate was a little unusual, as Senator Short will recall, and that led to this problem arising.

—If the meeting is this morning—and I think it is unlikely that we will finish the Department of Finance by lunch time—I would hope that members of the asset sales task force could be available here before the conclusion of consideration of the Department of Finance estimates. If we have to move on to other programs, as undoubtedly we will, we may again require Senator McMullan's indulgence to come back to that. Can I have an assurance from Senator McMullan that members of the task force will be available this afternoon?
—You certainly have my assurance that I will do everything I can to make sure that that is the case.

—In that case I will defer my further questions on the asset sales task force until then. I notice that my colleague Senator Bishop is now back from her other important meeting and it may suit the convenience of the Senate to go back to those earlier questions which she had on the assessment of the Fightback package.

—I want to ask questions with regard to the role of departmental officers in constructing a model for the specific purpose of testing the Fightback package, as we began to explore earlier. We were very keen, as taxpayers' money had been spent—
—I raise a point of order. I think that was the Treasury. This is the Department of Finance. The modelling question was about the Treasury, I think.
—No.
—I am sorry.

—Just to help Senator McMullan, let me tell him that, under the reservation signed by Senator Short and me, officers of the Department were questioned on their involvement in the analysis of the Fightback! document. He may recall that the Department of Finance officers advised us that they were dependent on the use of the model that had been built by Treasury officers and that they had a standing brief to give ministerial advice on matters which may be of budgetary significance. Therefore the Opposition policy was examined by Department of Finance officers as well as by Treasury officers. We were very concerned to see whether there had been even-handedness by the Department or whether there had been a political bias. We endeavoured to get an answer as to whether officers of the Department of Finance had done an analysis of the Government's One Nation statement in a similar manner to the way in which they had conducted the analysis of the Fightback package.

PARA.TAB: I wonder whether Senator McMullan would tell us now for the record whether or not the Finance officers did carry out an analysis of the One Nation statement similar to the one they carried out of the Fightback package. A simple yes or no will do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short asked that question and I answered it.

—We are playing games again. I have been at a meeting of the Public Accounts Committee dealing with a very important issue, the introduction of the new legislation concerning the Australian National Audit Office. For that reason I was unable to be in the chamber. I know we have a problem because the Senate rules that committees ought not to sit while the Senate is sitting, but that is a joint committee and, as such, there is a dilemma between rulings of the House of Representatives and the Senate. So I note Senator McMullan's very clever, `too smart by half' answer, that he has already answered the question. I wonder whether somebody who is present could possibly tell me what he said.

—Madam Chair, I am sorry about this. The situation is that I am quite happy to cooperate but Senator Short asked leave to conclude dealing with that section so that we could deal with extra matters that Senator Bishop wished to raise. I was happy to cooperate, and so we stopped dealing with this section and went on. I am simply saying that that is the point at which we stopped. Senator Short asked the question. I said then, as I think I said to the Estimates Committee—I do not think I added anything extra but perhaps I did—that of course One Nation was analysed by the Department of Finance, as all government expenditure proposals are analysed by the Department of Finance, and the Government's costings based on that advice, amongst others, were made public and have been subjected to scrutiny by independent commentators since that time.

PARA.TAB: It has always been the case that the analysis of government expenditure proposals is conducted through a different process from that used to analyse all other proposals, emanating from any non-government source—whether it be the Opposition, an independent commentator, an interest group or whatever—by definition, because all proposals as they are developed within government are subject to the constant review and analysis of the Department of Finance. That is its primary task although, as Senator Bishop and, before her, Senator Short correctly said, there is an ongoing brief to the Department of Finance to assess matters of public debate which may have budgetary implications.

So there was a Department of Finance assessment of proposals that came forward for consideration for inclusion in One Nation in the course of the officers' normal activities. That was part of the normal government decision making process. The outcome of those deliberations, which is—I do not want to mislead people so I have to be very careful—the Department of Finance advice and such other advice as was received by the Cabinet, came on the public record in the publication of One Nation. That is the normal process. It is what always has been done. It was done again on this occasion in the normal course of government policy development.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a classic answer of obfuscation. In answer to my question, Senator McMullan, it could have been said five minutes ago that the answer is no. An even-handed analysis of the One Nation statement and the Fightback package has not been conducted. They were in fact—by your own admission—subject to different types of analyses. So having got no for an answer, I will ask this question. For the purposes of the analysis of the Fightback package by the Department of Finance officers, did the officers use the special model built by the Department of Treasury?
—I think we said that during the course of the Estimates Committee hearing too. The answer then was yes; the answer now is yes.

—Thank you. Just so that everybody who reads the Hansard understands: did the Department of Finance officers use the same model built by the Department of Treasury officers to analyse the One Nation statement?
—Can the difference between that question and the one before be clarified?
—The one before related to the Fightback package, now I am asking about the One Nation statement.

—I will just have to qualify the answer in one way, because one part of that information will have to come from the Department of Treasury. Finance's relationship with the Department of Treasury was the same, so it would have used Treasury's model in the same manner. What I cannot say at this stage—but will say when the officers of the Department of the Treasury come here—is whether the model had in any way been refined between the two stages. I do not know that. It is a matter which is not—as far as I know—a secret, so I will ask when the Treasury officers are here. But, so far as the Department of Finance is concerned, the process was the same in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —When that interesting word `refined' is used, I presume that means changed. Could the officers be asked how it was that there was a different prediction for inflation for one package from the other, if the same information base was used?
—That is a question for the Department of Treasury and I am sure it will be asked of the officers. I think it already has been.

—I am using that as being indicative of the statement that we made in our reservation, that the Department of Finance undertook no similar analysis of the Government's One Nation statement as it did of the Fightback package. We stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure so to do raises grave fears for the political neutrality of the Department's analyses.

Could the Senate be informed please, Senator McMullan, as to whether or not exactly the same analysis was done of the One Nation statement, using the Treasury model, as was done of the Fightback package?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Bishop actually misunderstands, because the principal use of the Treasury model in the analysis of any program is primarily the responsibility of the Department of Treasury. It is a tool which from time to time the Department of Finance has to use. So the essential question needs to go to Treasury, but my understanding is that, so far as the Department of Finance's use of the model was concerned, it was exactly the same.

PARA.TAB: We do not want to be definitive about something that we do not know at this stage concerning whether the model was in exactly the same condition or whether it was changed. I do not imagine it was, but all econometric models are constantly under review with regard to assumptions and parameter changes and things, for reasons which would be understood. So that is the only qualification I would make about that and, with regard to the nature of the analyses overall, I do not have anything to add.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McMullan for that. I am interested in the `time to time' in which the tool was used. I am quite well aware of the demarcation, if you like, between the two departments. It is how the tool was used from time to time in which I am interested. It was said in your earlier answer that the two policies were treated differently; I am simply trying to pin down precisely where the difference is.

PARA.TAB: Just for the sake of people who are reading the Hansard but are not used to such terms as `econometrics' and all sorts of flowery in-terms: very simply, a model is nothing more and nothing less than a simple set of equations which are put into a computer program for speed and for accuracy. I think that is about the best working model we can use in layman's terms. It will be most interesting to know whether the parameters, that is, the way in which those series of equations were put together, were changed and/or different for the testing of the One Nation statement as distinct from the Fightback package.

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that on each occasion, whenever a reference was required to econometric models, the same process was gone through and the same model was used. That is subject to the qualification I made before, that Finance does not know whether there has been any development of the model at any particular time; it simply uses the then existent Treasury model. Subject to that qualification, as far as I can ascertain, the process was the same.

—That is a pretty hefty qualification, Senator McMullan. I think what you are telling me is that the officers who are advisers to you in the box today are not officers who actually use the model. Could we establish that?

—Although that is true, that is not the point. The point is that it is the Treasury model, and the appropriate point to review whether the equations, assumptions and parameters of the model are exactly the same now as they were on some previous occasion, or were the same in February as they might have been in November, is when the Treasury comes forward and not now.

—(12.28 p.m.)—The reason I asked the question, to establish that Senator McMullan's advisers are not the people who used the model, is simply that if it had changed I would expect any competent officer who was using the model to know. So, quite frankly, all the honourable senator's speculation as to whether it was changed or different is not really relevant to the answer. He could have said, `These officers do not know and we will have to find out from Treasury if you do not have the relevant Finance officers available'. That would have done.

—But it would have given exactly the wrong impression. That is why I did not give that answer. It may have suited the honourable senator but it would not have given an accurate impression of the situation. The situation is that the Finance process, as far as I can ascertain, was exactly the same. That was the subject of the honourable senator's question and that is the answer. Other matters need to be pursued with Treasury.

—That is exactly why I made the comments before: Senator McMullan's words were, `As far as I can ascertain'. All he can ascertain is from the advisers who are sitting in the box next to him. None of them used the model, therefore they are not in a position to give him any advice based on any expertise or answer any of the questions that I have been asking of him. Therefore, to give the impression that the thing is the same, when he simply does not know, is to mislead the Senate. We have had plenty of examples around here. We do not need any more.

—That is obviously not a question. It is a little tirade of abuse but we are all used to that from Senator Bishop because she abuses people regularly. Senator Cooney expressed it somewhat more politely yesterday and I respected him for doing so. I was being particularly careful to inform the Senate precisely. The reason I put in qualifications—which have so irritated Senator Bishop—is to be absolutely certain that the information I give to the Senate is accurate, because I think that that is important. We are all human and we may make mistakes but it is important that all of us try to give the most accurate information we can. That is what I was doing; that is what I am doing.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, the question was: did the Department of Finance treat these two proposals in the same manner with regard to modelling? The answer to that question was, and remains, yes. These officers are capable of providing us with that bit of information and they have. I do not know whether we are subsequently going to find out from Treasury that the tool that was used in the same manner was in any way slightly varied. I will know that when we get to ask questions of Treasury. I do not take lightly the suggestion that in some way or other the Senate was misled. It is being advised as accurately as I am capable of so doing. To make that sort of abusive attack is not a correct interpretation of what I was saying, and I reject it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, Senator McMullan has a very curious understanding of the English language; the distinction between criticism and abuse is great indeed. If he referred to Senator Cooney's speech yesterday, and if he chooses to read the one previous to that when we were dealing with a censure motion of Senator Richardson, he would see that as well as being able to discern that I am capable of being extremely critical when it is necessary, Senator Cooney also paid me some very nice compliments. I would recommend those to Senator McMullan as well but I would not expect him to manage to find them by himself. That is why I have referred him to them.

PARA.TAB: I want to go back to the very precise point that I was making. Senator McMullan stood there and purported to tell us that on the advice of the people in the box next to him the treatment of the two statements was the same, except for a `minor refinement'—that was the first phrase—and `a slight alteration' which was, I think, the second phrase. The fundamental point that I want to have on the record is that the advisers sitting in the box have not the faintest idea whether the parameters, the equations—or anything else in the model—were changed for the purposes of treating the Fightback package and treating the One Nation statement. Yes, we can quite accurately determine that when we come to Treasury. But at the moment, as I said, it is wrong for Senator McMullan to try to say that there was no difference, when he simply has no knowledge of it and when the advice that is conveyed to him is such that he can answer, `I do not know'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason that I am not advising now has nothing to do with the Department of Finance. I keep saying that in so far as these Estimates are concerned, the answer is, yes, the treatment was the same. It may be that in some other place the treatment was different; it is a question to be asked at that time.
—Are there any further matters in relation to these general matters?

—We need to understand that we will have more questions on this area when we do come to the Department of Treasury. I think we have to acknowledge that the Department of Finance played an important role in the analysis of the Fightback package, just as it did when it was in the care and control of Senator Walsh when he was the Finance Minister, when he attacked the economic action plan, using Finance officers quite improperly to do so prior to the last election. We are concerned that people are aware of the fact that this Government, this Executive, is choosing to politicise particular officers within departments and that we find that unacceptable.

—If there are no further matters in relation to that general section we will move on. I understand that programs 2 and 4 have been dealt with. Program 5 is to be deferred until this afternoon. We will move to program 7, which is a subject of some reservations, Australian National Audit Office.

—One of the matters which I and other senators are particularly concerned with is the independence of the Audit Office. The whole thrust of the Public Accounts Committee report entitled, The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament, was to ensure that the Auditor-General was independent, and could fulfil his fundamental task of being the link between the administration of government policy and the Parliament. In other words, his task is to see that taxpayers' money is properly spent, and accountable to the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: From time to time we find many areas where we are indeed concerned at the way in which the Executive tries to fetter that independence and, indeed, to limit his mandate. We expressed in that report concern that there should be an audit committee of the Parliament established which would break the power that the Executive presently has to limit the function of the Auditor-General by limiting the financial resources made available to him. The Committee report was very strong on the point that an audit committee could break that nexus and make the Auditor-General truly independent.

On the question of mandate, we were drawing attention, in respect of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, to the fact that the question of mandate should be fully recognised. That means that the auditor for government business enterprises, as well as government departments and other agencies, should always be the Auditor-General. He has the power to use the private sector by way of contract. That is being done, and most successfully done, but at the end of the day it is the Auditor-General who is the auditor for that enterprise. At every stage we are concerned about making the Auditor-General truly independent and truly appear to be independent.

However, something has come to my attention which worries me greatly. I would like the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) to tell me whether it is true. I understand that the Australian Labor Party is building a new building opposite the National Press Club here in Canberra, and that the major tenant of the Australian Labor Party will be the Australian National Audit Office. If that is true, it is a scandal. I would ask, right at the beginning: is it in fact true that it has been negotiated that in this building, on which the Australian Labor Party cannot be spending less than some $80m—and I would love to know where the money is coming from, and perhaps that is the real reason for the amendment to the disclosure provisions coming through—the Australian National Audit Office is to be a tenant of the Australian Labor Party?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know anything about it in my capacity as Parliamentary Secretary. I do not know whether the officers do, but it is my understanding that that is correct, yes.

—Mr Chairman, to say that I think that is a scandal is to put it mildly. It is absolutely appalling that someone so important to the question of scrutiny should be the subject of a tenancy to a political party. I would ask that all documents, negotiations, letters, and terms and conditions relating to the payment of lease be tabled in the Senate so that they can be there for all to see. I would suggest that, when we are looking at legislation that is to come in to replace the Audit Act, there should be some provision made to prevent this scandalous affair whereby the Australian National Audit Office—or, indeed, any department of the Government—can be a tenant giving rent and income to a political party. I ask that all those documents be tabled in the Senate: leases, negotiations, quotes, tenders—the lot.

—Firstly, I make it clear that there is nothing unusual about government departments being tenants of political parties. There have been government tenants in McEwen House for as long as I can remember—I think since it was built—quite correctly and quite appropriately; I do not have any disagreement with it. Let us put that in perspective. It has been the case, I would have thought, probably for 20 years. I may not be correct about that, but it has been a long time and, as far as I know, it is still the case. It is some time since I checked that it certainly has been the case. With regard to the Auditor-General and the Audit Office and their tenancies, I will refer that question to the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis).

—Mr Chairman, I would be very pleased if the Parliamentary Secretary would do so. As I have said, the Public Accounts Committee has been at great strength and at great pains to point out that the Auditor-General must be truly independent. The Auditor-General cannot be seen to be truly independent if he is a tenant of a political party, let alone the political party that is in power and an Executive that tries to limit his function. Not only have things got to be done correctly in this world; they have got to be seen to be done correctly.

PARA.TAB: On the question of scrutiny and the powers of the Auditor-General, he has to be above temptation, above suspicion and above being pressured. To have his office in a building owned and operated by the Australian Labor Party is simply not acceptable. So I would ask Senator McMullan, when he has referred the matter to the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), to come back to this Parliament and inform us in a very short time as to whether or not all that documentation will be tabled in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say I think the conspiracy theory really is abounding here. I do not think there is any question that the Auditor-General would be put into any building if he felt there was the slightest likelihood that it would be any impediment to his integrity or independence. I am sure the Senate would share with me its confidence that he would make sure that was not the case, and whatever happened he would continue to operate in that way. But I will refer the question and make sure the terms of it are referred accurately. I will refer the Hansard comments by Senator Bishop to the Minister to make sure that all the points she raised are drawn to his attention, so that he can respond.

—The Parliamentary Secretary is trying to dispel the importance of this issue by saying it is a conspiracy theory. Let me say on the record that we have plenty of evidence of the way in which this present Government behaves. We have all the evidence of Mr Symons and his affair. We have the evidence of Senator Richardson sitting on the board of 2HD in Newcastle, and sitting at the same time in a Cabinet meeting and deciding the ad bans policy as it applies. That ad bans legislation—that is, the abolishing of freedom of speech—makes us all dependent on the way in which a particular radio or television station, or commentators employed by them, portray our policies of the day.

PARA.TAB: Here, with the Labor Party owning the station, is the Minister sitting in on the deliberation of the legislation which is going to affect the ability of all political parties to have their word heard, and he tells me that we must pay no heed to the possibility of a conspiracy. I am afraid that with Senator Evans's behaviour yesterday, his poor performance today in saying that he could not let me have a letter because it was not on the public record—when it had been released by way of a press release yesterday—this Government's record on truth and disclosure is not good. Therefore, I do not want, in any way, shape or form, to see the Audit Office put at any risk by being in a building owned and operated by the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up the time of the Senate. There is obviously no question there for me to respond to. I simply reject that series of loosely connected assertions. They have nothing to do with these particular sets of estimates, so let us get on with the business.

—Do I understand that the Parliamentary Secretary is therefore disputing the facts as I set them out? Is he saying that Senator Richardson was not a director of 2HD? Is he saying that he did not sit at the Cabinet meeting and discuss those matters? Is he saying that the ALP does not own the radio station? Is he saying we are not subject to the whim of the commentator employed by the owners of those radio stations? Is he saying that Senator Evans this morning did not say that he could not disclose a letter because it was private? Is he saying it is, in fact, not on the record? Which particular fact is he taking exception to?
—The conclusion.

—My conclusion is very simply this: this Government has shown itself to be unworthy of any trust at all. To put the Australian National Audit Office within the confines of a building owned and operated by the Australian Labor Party, which has shown itself to behave in a shabby fashion, quite frankly, will not satisfy the rest of Australia.

—I can only reiterate something which I have had cause to say before. Quite often one finds that people who constantly see conspiracies and who think that they are looking through a window at other people's motives, are often looking into a mirror and seeing their own reflected. This is simply a tedious waste of time. Fortunately, it cannot go on much longer, because it has nothing to do with the Department of Finance estimates that I have undertaken to raise. I do not think any of the facts that have been raised warrant the—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I will not have it on the record uncontested that somehow I am besmirched by the behaviour of the Labor Party, which Senator McMullan tried to do by saying that I was looking in the mirror and seeing my own faults. I will not have it, Senator McMullan.
—Another abuse of the Senate process.
—Order! That is not a point of order; that is a point of view. It now being 12.45 p.m., I shall report progress.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, I inform the Senate that the Governor-General has made a number of changes to ministerial appointments. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list of Ministers, showing the offices they now hold and representation arrangements in each chamber. The list also shows the names and titles of Parliamentary Secretaries.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: [THE DOCUMENT IS OMITTED FROM THE DATA BASE, SEE HARD COPY PAGES 2732-3]

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Foreign Minister. I refer to the Minister's revelation in Question Time yesterday that his Department has a file note of a conversation on 6 April between the Minister's adviser and a departmental officer in which the Minister's adviser was told of rumours circulating in the Marshall Islands that Senator Richardson had been in contact with the President and possibly other Cabinet Ministers in the Marshall Islands. That is a file note for 6 April saying that the rumours were that Senator Richardson had been in contact. I ask: when was the Department advised by its post in Micronesia that Senator Richardson had been making these calls? On what dates and under what circumstances did the Embassy in Pohnpei report the existence of these rumours? What calls did the Embassy in Pohnpei understand had been made, and when?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I offered Senator Hill the opportunity to look at the file note in question on a confidential basis, pending an opportunity for me in turn to evaluate it for its releasability under FOI criteria. Senator Hill has not taken advantage of that opportunity which I gave to him. If he had he would have had on the face of the document the answer to certainly at least part of the question he has just asked.
—Why should he have to do that on a confidential basis?

—Because I was giving him an opportunity to take a look at it before I had had time to look at it for reviewability on FOI grounds. Since yesterday I have had time to review the document on FOI grounds and I am perfectly happy now to table an abbreviated version of that document. I am also happy to allow Senator Hill to look at the original version and see for himself the nature of the omissions that have been made. In short, they are two. There is a second page to the document which relates to a totally separate commercial matter which is manifestly commercially confidential. There is one part of the note in question that has been blacked out because it relates to an essentially personal consular matter. I am perfectly happy to make available the rest of the document. If I can pass it across to Senator Hill, he can look at it right now.

PARA.TAB: The document in question is a handwritten file note dated 6 April. It notes a phone call to the officer in question, Mr O'Leary in my Department, from Mr Peter Stanford, who is our Ambassador to Micronesia and the Marshall Islands, based in Pohnpei. The document, on its face, summarises the telephone conversation and, in particular, the circumstances and the nature of the arrest of the individuals in question.

The dirty bit on which all honourable senators opposite have been salivating appears about halfway down the page. I summarised it yesterday; I will now read it in full if those opposite have their seatbelts on and their cold mops ready. The really dirty bit—the real bit that they have been waiting for—reads as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Suggestion that Richo has been ringing members of Cabinet and President seeking leniency.
Suggestion that Richo has been ringing members of Cabinet and President seeking leniency.

That is the line that appears in this particular file note. Notice the status of this document. It is a file note recording a telephone conversation from our Ambassador in Pohnpei, who in turn is reporting what he has heard that day from the Marshall Islands. He has heard official news that people have been arrested—Australian citizens—in circumstances that are manifestly of interest to the Department, as these things always are, and he is reporting a rumour that has been circulating that day in Majuro—a `suggestion that Richardson has been ringing members of Cabinet and President seeking leniency'.

PARA.TAB: The Ambassador is reporting it on the basis, I am able to further advise the Opposition, of his contact with an Australian official based in Majuro and someone close to the Government. The rumour is one in the terms expressed. The rumour is that what Senator Richardson was doing was ringing not just the President but the President and members of Cabinet—more than one phone call. The other substantive thing in the rumour is that what was involved was not a mere request for denial of a passport to be overturned to enable him to prepare his defence but, rather, seeking of leniency. But rumours—these sorts of things—have a life of their own. That is why they are rumours. That is why courts distinguish between rumours and evidence.

What actually happened is that Senator Richardson's account—which the Opposition has heard from him publicly, first, in his public statement of 28 April; secondly, in this Parliament on 29 April and on a number of days subsequently; and, as to my part in it, also in full in the Parliament on 29 April; and, further, in Senator Richardson's account that he gave in his report to the Prime Minister on 18 May—is quite different from the terms of that rumour. There were not multiple phone calls but one phone call only to the President—a short phone call in circumstances which are fully described on page 6 of Senator Richardson's report, as well as in other places.
