There was a short phone call in which Senator Richardson made clear he was holding himself out not as a member of the Australian Government but as a private citizen, doing so on behalf of a family connection, and not seeking leniency, not seeking in any way a reaction to the substantive matters in issue, but simply addressing the question of the passport.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: it is important in listening to the answer—
—What is the point of order?
—The point of order is this: would you ask the Minister to clarify whether or not he is asserting that there is evidence that the file note is less believable than Senator Richardson?

—On the point of order, Mr President: this is becoming a bit of a habit. It may be a habit but it is not a point of order. Senator Hill asked a question, which is being answered. To seek clarification of both the question and the answer is not a point of order.
—Order! There is no point of order. Could I also point out that there are too many interjections, which makes it very hard for me to hear whether there will be a point of order or not.

—So, Mr President, that is the nature of the document about which Opposition senators have been getting so excited, but not excited enough, apparently, to seek access to it when it was offered to them yesterday. They would much prefer to spread innuendo and suggestions that there is some sort of further smoking gun here.

PARA.TAB: The point is that the matters in issue in this particular material are all of those that have been in the public domain for a very long time now. They are fully explained by the circumstances. They have been fully dealt with in the context of Senator Richardson's report and fully dealt with, of course, in the context of Senator Richardson's resignation.
Those are the circumstances in which this particular communication was made. That is the content of the communication. There is nothing new in any of this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Certainly I thank the Minister for the document that he has tabled. It is quite informative in that it mentions not only Symons and Finch but also the US and, Mr President, you will be pleased to hear, you as well, followed by the words `political connections'. They got that one right: there are very good political connections in this country. I particularly ask the Minister: what action did the Department take to follow up this very unusual revelation to the Department that Senator Richardson, according to rumours, had been phoning the President of this country and Cabinet Ministers concerning the matter of leniency? If in fact the Department took no action to follow it up, was that because the Department learnt through the office of the Minister that the Minister had already authorised Senator Richardson to call the President?
—The action the Department took to follow it up was to ring my senior adviser, Mr Kupa, as this note says on its face.
—Who advised what?

—Mr Kupa took on board the information in question, but he knew that no further action was at that stage required because he knew what the basis of the rumour was. He knew that the basis of the rumour was that there had been a phone call from Senator Richardson.
—He knew you had authorised the call.

—The reason he knew that is that I had told him straight after I had had the conversation with Senator Richardson on Friday, the 3rd. I had told him I had had a conversation with Senator Richardson, who had a relative in a spot of bother; that Senator Richardson, at the request of the relative's defence lawyer, had wanted to make a call to the Marshall Islands; that Senator Richardson had rung me to ask in diplomatic protocol terms whether there would be any particular problems about that and I had responded in the way that I have already spelt out at nauseous length on the public record on 29 April and do not propose to bore the Senate with again.

PARA.TAB: I communicated the fact of this conversation to my private secretary for his information so he would know what was going on. I was overseas in Japan from Sunday, the 5th until later that week—I think Thursday, the 9th. It was on Monday, the 6th that this particular phone call came through. My private secretary knew what it was about, he knew the context in which the call would have been made, the basis of it, so no further action was required of him. What he omitted to do was to tell me that there had been this communication from the Department, so I did not know that any of this was in existence until all of this subsequently emerged in the circumstances that we have discussed previously. I have been told that I was overseas until 12 April, not 9 April. I am not sure about that, but I will check it out.

The Department's obligation was to treat the thing as a consular matter thereafter, which it did, and that is why material has started accumulating on the file. To the extent that there was some political dimension to it, my Department's responsibility was discharged by in effect advising the ministerial office, which it did. The ministerial office happened to know the true circumstances of it, and under those circumstances no further action was necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It relates to a matter of real significance. I refer to the resignation of the Prime Minister of Thailand, General Suchinda. What is the Australian Government's current assessment of the political situation in Thailand? Further, what is the Government's evaluation of recent developments in that country?

—The political situation in Thailand is obviously still very fluid at the moment. The political parties remain deadlocked over the formation of a new government. A new Prime Minister is yet to be named. The constitutional tribunal is expected to meet today, 27 May, to consider the validity of the royal decree which gave amnesty to all parties involved in the violence in Bangkok last week, the handling of which issue is obviously of crucial significance to the whole political future of the country as well as to the reaction of other countries such as Australia. We are hopeful about the prospects for a peaceful solution. The resignation of General Suchinda was obviously a positive step which could well prove to be not just significant in resolving the current crisis but also a major development, a watershed perhaps, in the evolution of the Thai democratic process.

PARA.TAB: We also very much welcome the recommencement two days ago of parliamentary processes under which parliament moved quickly through two readings of Bills relating to amendments to the constitution. A key amendment was for the Prime Minister to be an elected MP in future. Also, the state of emergency was lifted.

The horror which we all felt as the details of the violence became clear in the course of last week was, I assure the Senate, wholly shared by me. The fact that I did not make public comment about it was simply because I was overseas, badly out of communication in terms of the evolving events, and needed to be fully apprised of the scale of it and the responsibility for it, because of the policy consequences that flowed from that analysis. I say now for the record that I was absolutely appalled by the violence.

I am further appalled by the fact that there is now compelling evidence that a great deal of the death toll was a result of deliberate actions by a number of senior Thai generals. The size of the death toll is still unclear. Latest figures suggest that there are as many as 589 people missing on current compilations and, unhappily, it does seem reasonable to assume that a very large proportion of those—if not all—are, in fact, dead. We would hope and expect that there will be a satisfactory formal accounting for the events which took place and there are already strong pressures within Thailand itself to that end.

Our formal response was made very clear by the Prime Minister last week. He expressed the horror we all felt. He announced a review of the bilateral relationship, the cancellation of Australian Defence Force participation and the Night Panther exercise. The Thai Ambassador has been called in, our Ambassador has made representations and Mr Kerin announced last week that all ministerial and senior military visits would be deferred pending that review.

Finally, our future responses will naturally be informed by events in the coming days which we will be following very closely. We have conducted an initial review of bilateral relations. We will continue to defer for the time being ministerial and senior military contacts. We are keeping the full range of official contacts with Thailand under detailed review until the situation clarifies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to his advice to the Senate yesterday that a departmental officer, Mr O'Leary, had faxed to the Minister's office on 6 April documents relating to Mr Symons's contact with the Australian Embassy in Washington. We now have a copy of the file note that refers to the fax having been sent. I also refer to the fact that yesterday the Minister said that his senior adviser, Mr Kupa, had no recollection of seeing any of the faxed documents and that his office had no record of the faxes. I remind the Minister that he filed a statutory declaration by Mr Kupa to support Mr Kupa's claim in some way. Of course, in doing that he attacks the credibility of Mr O'Leary. I ask the Minister: what inquiries have been undertaken in the Department to verify Mr O'Leary's claim that he had, in fact, sent the documents? Is there not a record in the Department of the faxes sent? Is there not a record in the Minister's office of faxes received, such as a fax log? What opportunity has been afforded to Mr O'Leary to substantiate his claim that the faxes were, in fact, sent?

—So far as the departmental records are concerned, it does appear that the faxes were sent because there is a fax cover sheet in existence, together with what is called a confirmation report. That is the technical line of data which appears indicating that a particular series of pages have been sent at a particular time. All of that is consistent with Mr O'Leary's file note. I have only one copy of this, but Senator Hill is welcome to look at it if he doubts me. There is no doubt that the departmental record at that end of it suggests these faxes were sent.

PARA.TAB: What is missing is any comparable material at our end of the process. A technical file log would be printed out and would be available in these situations. The difficulty is that routinely every month these things are destroyed. That did happen to be destroyed routinely, I am told.

TALK.START.PARA: —What!

—Do not get excited about this. Contemplate the context in which you are getting so excited. This is material that, on the face of it, was of no particular significance at the time it was received. It was of no particular significance to me because I knew that Senator Richardson had an involvement in this; he had told me about it and I had understood the nature of it. I had been asked about him and approved his going ahead in the way that he wanted to in circumstances that I have previously described.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition can get positively orgiastic over there with excitement about this, but the truth of the matter is that in the particular context in which these events were occurring this was pretty small beer information and not the kind of thing that would justify any particular excitement. In the normal course, if faxes go astray, they are followed up at the departmental end or at our end. And faxes do go astray; they get misfiled or gathered up and put in the wastepaper basket when they should be routed somewhere else. In this situation, the Department did not follow up to see what had happened to the material in question and, of course, there was no follow-up at the office end.

All of this has been explained by my particular officer, in whose integrity may I say publicly that I have complete confidence. I do not simply rely on statutory declarations to earn my confidence. I have absolute confidence in his integrity and his efficiency. It just so happened that in this particular case some faxed documents went astray. There is no mystery about what those documents were; they are attached to his statutory declaration, which was tabled yesterday. It is publicly available. There are no missing documents in that sense. Those opposite can see for themselves the significance or lack of significance of them. It is just one of those situations that can occur in the best run offices from time to time where documents went astray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. One wonders, therefore, the purpose of the statutory declaration.
—Oh, God!

—What would the purpose be, then? Am I to correctly interpret the Minister as now saying that he accepts that his personal office was made aware of the matters concerning Richardson and Symons and the American connection as contained in the relevant minutes that he accepts were now sent to his office?

—My office accepts that there was a telephone conversation on the date in question at which my office was formally advised of the fact of the arrests and some of the surrounding information. The nature and extent of my adviser's recollection of that conversation are very precisely articulated in the statutory declaration.

PARA.TAB: It is just because those opposite are such a mob of miserable cynics both in what they are likely to believe about him and what they are likely to believe about me that I thought it might be appropriate—it would not be necessary for reasonable and decent people, but for that lot it is—to put the matter beyond doubt by asking my officer in question to put the matter into a statutory declaration. I do not disbelieve anything he said—I believe that he is being absolutely honest—but one has to adjust one's standards to the lowest common denominators in this business. So in order to persuade those opposite that there is a bit of decency and integrity around, because they will not otherwise believe it, I did ask for a statutory declaration to be prepared. The content of that declaration speaks for itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to an analysis of Australia's services sector published by the Bureau of Industry Economics this month? If so, can the Minister advise how important that analysis indicates Australia's service industries are to the economy? Further, could the Senate be advised of what the economic outlook is for these industries?

—The recent publication of the Bureau of Industry Economics industry brief on the services sector of May 1992 makes it clear that the services sector is playing a vital role in providing new jobs in Australia and in contributing to the improvement in Australia's balance of payments. It is a fact that job growth in Australia in the last year has been particularly strong in two—and I single out two—of Australia's service industry sectors, in spite of the recession. Those sectors relate to community services and recreational and personal services. In the latter case, the employment growth was 6.4 per cent through the year.

PARA.TAB: The recreational services sector is overwhelmingly conducted in the private sector and is weighted towards small business activity. I imagine that Senator Colston has a particular interest in this sector because he is a Queensland senator, and tourism plays a major role in the sector. It makes a significant contribution to Australia's balance of payments. It occurs on both sides of the balance of payments account. Foreign tourists coming in is the equivalent of increased export earnings and Australians holidaying in Australia rather than overseas is import replacement expenditure.

The BIE report about which Senator Colston asked me shows that the economic outlook for the services sector as a whole is good. The survey of business expectations conducted by the National Australia Bank in the March quarter indicated a fairly bullish approach to an increased demand for services, with 68.1 per cent expecting demand to increase and firms expecting profitability to improve through the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —It all happened in spite of your Government.

—Senator Macdonald interjects. There are always difficulties for industries such as this and sometimes there are clouds on the horizon for them. For example, a consumption tax is a cloud on the horizon for these industries. The Australian tourism industry would be particularly penalised by a consumption tax.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections from both sides of the chamber.
—The industry would be particularly penalised by a consumption tax because, firstly, it is largely composed of small businesses which pay little payroll tax and, secondly, it deals—
—That shows your ignorance of the tax package.

—Senator Short talks about my ignorance of the tax package. His problem is the community's ignorance of it and his incapacity to sell it. He is one of the principal salesmen who walked the streets of the electorate of Wills trying to sell it. Look at how he did. There was no comfort for the Opposition—this bright alternative—or us in the Wills by-election.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the tourist industry would be penalised because it deals largely in services and in food and refreshments. In that sense, the industry stands to gain little from a proposed abolition of the wholesale sales tax. The Treasury analysis of the Opposition's version of a consumption tax shows that the Australian tourism industry would be hit with price rises of between 8.4 and 11.4 per cent.

Many Australians other than those in the tourist industry and in service industries generally have not yet realised how widespread and heavy the impact of the Opposition's proposed tax on services would be. I tell Senator Short that they will realise it in the next few months. The detailed Treasury analysis shows, for example, that electricity charges would increase by 10.65 per cent, gas charges would increase by 7.6 per cent, postal and telephone service charges would increase by 8.14 per cent, urban transport fares would rise by 6.5 per cent—the Opposition's spokesman in Queensland had something to say about that, but we will come to that another time—and dry cleaning and shoe repairs would rise in cost by 10.5 per cent.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bishop

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I quote your ruling on 26 November 1991 when, ruling on a point of order, you said:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . questions to Ministers must relate to subjects within their ministerial responsibilities. It has also been ruled consistently by me and by former Presidents that a question that invites a Minister to comment on Opposition policies is out of order. . .
Clearly the Minister's answer is related to Opposition policies, on which he has no knowledge at all. I would ask you to uphold your ruling of 26 November 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In reply to the point of order, I think the Minister is beginning to debate the answer, but he is not being helped by constant interjections.

—Mr President, as you have correctly ruled, it is not a point of order. One always gets points of order when people find facts unpalatable. They have to get used to it. Every service used by a household would increase by up to 10 per cent, perhaps more, as a direct result of the imposition of a consumption tax.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The Minister is quite clearly flouting your ruling. I ask you again to uphold your ruling of 26 November.
—Order! I said that the Minister was beginning to debate the question. I am sure that he will conclude shortly.
—Take note of that, John.

—I am getting help from Rumpole Junior over there. I was just making the point that all the services provided to households, including television repairs, washing machines, plumbing, electrical services and so on, would increase.

PARA.TAB: The point of Senator Colston's question, of course, related to the document produced by the Bureau of Industry Economics. I gather that Senator Bishop did not hear the question, otherwise she would not have indulged in that ridiculous interlude. It followed from the Bureau of Industry Economics industry brief on the services sector. I want to place on record the damage which would be done to the high growth areas of the Australian services sector—a cloud on the horizon for a growing and important sector of Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to Senator Richardson's defence of the assistance he and his office gave to Mr Gregory Symons's business activities as a normal execution of his responsibility to help constituents. Firstly, does the Leader of the Government agree that the prompt, frequent and unquestioning help given to Mr Symons went well beyond normal constituency duties and would not have been available to constituents who were not relatives or mates—for example, agreeing to expedite immigration requests before they had been lodged, much less delayed or refused? Secondly, does the Leader of the Government agree that for Senator Richardson to provide a reference on ministerial letterhead, rather than his senatorial letterhead, and to do so without seeking any documentary evidence or making any independent background checks, does not fall within his ministerial responsibilities and is a form of largess which is open to abuse? Finally, does he agree that this affair demonstrates the need for a code of conduct for Ministers to discourage cronyism?

—I think the parliamentary process would be debased in Australia if it were known internationally that we had a code of conduct to discourage cronyism. I am not keen on advocating that as a solution to this problem. With respect to the first part of the question, Senator Coulter quoted Senator Richardson in part. He asked me whether this was a normal execution of constituency duties. Let me make it quite clear that Senator Richardson, in terms of his actions, has made it clear on a number of occasions that he regarded that as part of a constituency duty.
—Anything goes for him.

—Senator Alston makes that comment. All sorts of value judgments can be made about these things, but that is the point I am making. In so far as the use of ministerial letterhead is concerned, Senator Coulter asked me whether the writing of letters of that kind falls within a Minister's responsibilities. Sometimes it does; on many occasions it does. All Ministers, both in this country and overseas, from time to time write letters of endorsement. I am not making any judgment about the letter which Senator Richardson wrote; other people have made that judgment. All Ministers make judgments about these things and write letters. It is done both here and internationally. I do not see any objection to that at all. Of course, Ministers have to exercise due care in the way in which they do that.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. We know what Senator Richardson has said about this. Does Senator Button, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, regard this behaviour—I refer specifically to the issuing of the reference without, as we know from Senator Richardson, fully checking out the bona fides of Mr Symons—as becoming of a Minister?

—In respect of all of these matters, Senator Richardson has made a judgment and adopted a course of action which, of course, led to his resignation as a Minister. I do not see that after the event judgments by everybody here—even amongst this most judgmental lot opposite—add any value to that decision. Senator Richardson has made a decision about that matter. Those opposite might try to pursue the decision for as long as they think they can get a little mileage out of it—
—What are your standards, if any?
—Senator Baume should not ask that question. I have never written phoney articles in the newspapers under fraudulent names. I have never been a partner in Patrick—

—I raise a point of order. Mr President, you have the clearest possible powers, in terms of relevance, to direct a Minister to answer a question. The question was, `What view do you and the Government take of Senator Richardson's activities?'. If the Minister is now saying, `It is a matter for Senator Richardson' then he ought to make it clear that he is saying that the Government has no view, no standards and no levels of propriety. I direct you to order him to make it relevant.
—Order! There is no point of order, but I think that the chamber would be helped if there were not so many interjections from both sides.

—In answer to Senator Coulter's initial question I said that in doing things such as writing references for people, Ministers should exercise due care. I said that and I think that that is a proper standard. If those opposite do not mind—they being like the witches of Salem, led by a particular group in the middle, indulging in a frenzy about these issues—it is not for me to join their lot, thank you very much. I would not want to be associated with them in any way.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Today is the second anniversary of the 1990 elections held in Burma to elect a National Assembly in which the National League for Democracy, led by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, swept to a landslide victory but has been prevented from taking office by the repressive SLORC regime. Can the Minister advise whether the SLORC, under the new Chairman, General Than Shwe, firstly, is any closer to handing over power to a democratically elected National Assembly; secondly, is any closer to convening a national convention in October this year; thirdly, has released any more political prisoners; fourthly, has honoured the agreement for repatriation of Rohingya refugees from Bangladesh; and, fifthly, has stopped Burmese Army attacks against the Karen National Union forces near the Thai-Burma border? Further, does the Minister have reports about the well being of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi following the recent visit by her husband, Michael Aris? Lastly, if there has not been any significant improvement in these matters by the SLORC, will the Australian Government impose economic sanctions against the Burmese regime?

—There have been a number of recent developments giving some cause for hope that we may be entering a new era but as yet those signs are still few, and far between, insubstantial and incomplete. What has happened is that, firstly, there have been decisions made to convene a meeting of political parties by late next month and a national convention by October. We will have to wait and see whether that happens according to that timetable but that, at least, is a healthy development.

PARA.TAB: To answer the second question, there are no indications that processes are under way or have commenced to bring about actual democratic reform.

As to the question of political prisoners, more have been released, with the current total standing at 110. While that is welcome and very much overdue, it has to be said that the pace of release is still extraordinarily sluggish, with possibly 2,000 or more political prisoners still awaiting release.

As to the repatriation of the Rohingya refugees, that, regrettably, did not commence on 15 May as had been agreed and the suffering of those people continues. We understand that that is due to the failure of the Burmese Government to provide adequate preparations for the safe return of the refugees in question. On the eastern border, the cease-fire between the Burmese Army and the Karen National Union forces does appear to be holding. We remain, however, cautious about the significance of that because, as I have previously stated, the onset of the monsoon could have been the key factor in that particular Burmese decision. As to the condition of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, all I can say is that, as has already been seen from public reporting of a statement recently issued by her husband, she is in good spirits and good health despite almost three years in detention.

The Australian Government has been keeping under review, obviously, the whole question of implementing economic sanctions against Burma. We are getting very close to the point at which we will have to make a decision whether to go further down that particular path on the assumption that what has happened is simply cosmetic and insubstantial or whether rather to accept what has happened as a series of steps in the right direction. It is just too early at the moment to make that decision.

We are in active consultation with a number of other countries around the world and in the region that have a close and intense interest in this. All I can undertake sensibly to do is not to set timetables or specific criteria but to say that we very much want to maintain the international pressure on Burma, we very much want this process that has apparently commenced to be made real and substantial and followed through, and we will do whatever we can to ensure that in the weeks and months ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister a supplementary question. In view of his comment that he will keep under very close review the issue of whether economic sanctions can be laid against the Burmese regime, can the Minister give me an indication of whether, by the end of June when the Senate is due to rise for this session of parliament, he will be able to indicate to the Senate whether it is an appropriate time to consider the question of economic sanctions?

—I certainly imagine that by then we will be in a better position to make a substantive judgment of the kind that is required. But obviously I do not want to make any specific commitment or set any specific timetable. It is a matter of doing what is sensible in all the circumstances and that depends on the judgments we make as the events unfold.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask the Minister whether he has checked whether his Department had any further communications with his office between 6 April, when we know there was Mr Kupa's conversation—and we now know that apparently there was an acknowledgment of the faxes that were sent through the Minister—and 7 May, when the Minister denied in the Senate having any knowledge of Mr Symons's dealing with the Australian Embassy in Washington. In other words, what communications were there on this matter between the Minister's office and the Department for that period of one month?

—We have no recollection of there being any communications during that period. There was, obviously, some discussion in the context of the answer that I put down on 29 April in relation to the question that was asked of me about my role in Senator Richardson's telephoning. But, beyond that, I do not have any recollection and my staff do not have any recollection. I do not think there was any communication and I do not think the Department has any record of any communication for that whole period up to 7 May when I was asked another specific question by Senator Bishop.
—I ask a supplementary question. In view of the lapses of memory which we have been learning about in this matter, I ask the Minister—
—Is this Greinerism? He couldn't even remember his own name.

—It is a very strange state of affairs, is it not? The note says faxes are sent, cables are sent. Yesterday the Minister came in here with a statutory declaration from his private secretary to say, `I did not get any of them'. It is a very strange set of affairs. I ask the Minister: will he now check his recollection with the departmental records and confirm for us tomorrow whether or not, from the departmental side, there were communications on this matter during that period of one month?
—I will certainly check that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade in his own capacity and as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development. I refer to the 1990 census figures for China, which show that for every 100 boys under two years of age there were only 89 girls. Will the Minister concede that the missing female millions were victims of the PRC's one child per family population control program? Could the Minister explain to the Senate why and on whose advice AIDAB currently has a delegation in China for the purposes of increasing Australian aid, directly or through UNFPA, for that barbaric program?

—It is very much Senator Harradine's judgment that the Chinese population program is barbaric. Other judgments differ in that respect, including the judgments of the human rights delegation, led by Senator Schacht, that went to China last year and that actively explored this issue, with the particular involvement of Senator Bourne, who I know took a particularly active role in exploring that issue. She might welcome the opportunity to contribute to the debate on this matter on some further occasion.

PARA.TAB: We have made it very clear on innumerable occasions that we do not support, in China's population program or anywhere else in the world, coercive population practices or practices of a kind that could produce sex imbalances of the kind that Senator Harradine refers to. We support the provision of family planning information and services as a basic human right while rejecting, as I have just said, the use of coercive practices of any kind.

There is a lot more that could be said about this policy. It has been said on innumerable occasions in the context of Estimates committee hearings and debates in the Parliament. I simply say that I remain personally very firmly committed to the population policy as a crucial component in our aid program and as a very important element in development strategy, but that I will not pursue that particular commitment at the expense, ever, of allowing Australian aid to be associated with coercive practices. We will do our best to use whatever policy leverage we have to stop those practices in any context in which we find ourselves. It is a matter for detailed analysis and debate and argument, not for assertion, as Senator Harradine knows, because we have had this debate on about 100 previous occasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. We know of the Minister's conversation with Senator Richardson on 3 April. We now know that the Department had the prospectus in relation to Symons's business. We know that the Department had the memorandum from Symons to Senator Richardson—the one that Senator Richardson said he did not receive—which details the scheme. We now know that the Department had the correspondence from Washington and the memos between Washington, Pohnpei and Canberra. In addition, we now know that there was the telephone call to the Minister's office on 6 April and that faxes were forwarded from the Department to the Minister's office. Despite the fact that this must stretch all bounds of credibility, I ask the Minister: in those circumstances, does he stand by his answer to the Senate of 7 May that, `I am not aware of any such dealings at all', that is, between Symons and the United States?

—Absolutely—for all the reasons I spelt out yesterday. Moreover, the premises of Senator Hill's question are not accurate. The Department, at least the Department here in Canberra, did not have the memorandum from Symons to Richardson that came to light on 15 May. That was in Washington, not here in Canberra, and it came to light only as a consequence of the investigation, the follow-up, which I myself directed occur after the question was raised here on 7 May. The Department did have a copy of Senator Sibraa's letter and some associated material of the kind that we have been talking about. That is true—on 7 May.

PARA.TAB: As to the prospectus and quite a lot of voluminous documentation relating to the Marshall Islands scheme, that was sent down by bag in the week or two after the arrests took place and the consular issue began, and has arrived in more recent days within the Department. I am not sure whether or not that was around at the time. But once one gets involved in a consular matter of this kind, demanding and requiring departmental resources, there is quite a lot of documentation associated with it. But there is nothing in particular to suggest that there was any great significance about any of this until everybody got excited from the latter part of April onwards; and certainly nothing to suggest any involvement of my Department.

I might just mention the fact for the record—we pulled out these figures in the context of all the anxiety about leaks the other day—that the Department produces some 180,000 original classified cables each year. Together with the number of copies of each that are prepared and distributed, that results in something like 22 1/2 million new documents a year being produced in relation to cables alone. It is also estimated that my Department produces or receives in Canberra each year in the form of originals and copies over 13 million other classified documents not being cables. From my experience, a fair proportion of that sort of material flows through my office.

It just happens to be the case that at any given time there are 100 or 200 significant issues running, all with documentation of one kind or another. The fact that in one particular corner of the Department there may be some material in existence relating to one particular matter of no obvious substantive significance so far as public policy is concerned, should be in itself an indication of the way in which this particular matter was treated and an explanation of the way in which what might otherwise be inexplicable failures to recall things or to seek access to documents and so on actually occurred. In the real world that we inhabit there are many, many other preoccupations and many, many other documents competing for attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the circumstances where the Department knew a great deal about the matter, in the circumstances where the Minister's adviser knew about the matter—and I note again that the file note makes reference to the US connection and to you, Mr President; it states that `my notes', which include that, were communicated to the Minister's adviser—in the circumstances where Senator Richardson obviously knew and in the circumstances where you knew, I ask the Minister: is he in fact claiming that he has been some sort of victim of a conspiracy of silence in this matter?
—We are all victims, Mr President, of second-rate theatre.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to my question on notice No.1721 of 30 March in which I asked the Minister:

QUESTION.PARA: How much finance has the Commonwealth contributed to the (NSW) MBA Apprenticeship Scheme?

Does the Minister agree that his answer that `the NSW Master Builders Association group training scheme has never been funded by the Commonwealth' for administrative costs is seriously deficient in that it does not mention Commonwealth funding to the NSW Master Builders Association under other headings? Is it correct that the NSW MBA group training scheme received a total of $2,197,739 through CRAFT between 1988-89 and 1991-92? If the answer to this question is yes, would the Minister explain why he provided a seriously misleading answer by omitting the disclosure of payments under CRAFT? Finally, is the Minister's statement that no audit reports were requested by the Commonwealth still correct? If in fact no audit reports were requested, why were they not, since we now know that the Minister's earlier answer was wrong and that the Commonwealth in fact did contribute funds to the NSW MBA group training scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler is referring to a question he put on notice to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training on 26 February and to which the Minister for Employment, Education and Training replied in writing on 30 March this year. I take it from Senator Spindler's question that he is saying that, in his view, the Minister has not correctly replied to the questions he put. I am advised that that is not the view of the Minister. However, since Senator Spindler has now articulated further questions, I will refer those to the Minister and reply to the honourable senator's inquiries in due course.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. As

QUESTION.PARA: documents, including your letter, Mr President, to Mr Lamb in the United States and communications between Washington, Pohnpei and Canberra, were faxed to the Minister almost immediately after Question Time on 7 May, why did he not then come back immediately after into the chamber and correct his answer in which he said that he was not aware of any such dealings between Symons and the United States? How could he yesterday use the excuse that he needed to communicate with the United States to see whether that was the case when the documents that he had before him by fax clearly indicated that action had been taken by his Department to facilitate Symons? What did he seek to hide by that? Why did he not keep the Senate properly informed?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill's inability to use or understand the English language is rivalled only by those in the press gallery who wrote this morning that there was evidence of my having misled the Senate. The truth of the matter is that one can mislead only on the basis of one's state of knowledge or one's state of mind, one's state of understanding, at the particular time that one is making the statement which is alleged to constitute the misleading question. At the time that I answered the question—some time between 2 p.m. and 3 p.m. when I was asked whether I was aware of any dealings between Symons and any of our missions in the United States—I said I was not aware. That remains the case: I was not aware.
—You knew at 4 o'clock.
—By the time I went back to my office after 4 o'clock, I became aware, as I said yesterday, that there may have been some dealings.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—If those opposite do not have any respect for me, they should at least have a little bit of respect for the English language. I became aware at 4 o'clock, on the basis of being shown Senator Sibraa's letter of introduction seeking a meeting between Symons and Mr Lamb, that there may well have been such a meeting which occurred as a result of that letter of introduction.

PARA.TAB: I did not know at that time that such a meeting had occurred. I worked on the assumption that Senator Sibraa himself was unlikely to know. It was a matter of checking with Washington. At that stage, at 4 o'clock in the afternoon, it was 2 o'clock in the morning there. It was not the right time to be checking for Washington even if something manifestly important was involved, which I have to say did not seem to be in the total scheme of things.

Early the following morning, Friday, 8 May, an officer of my Department, a Deputy Secretary, rang Mr Lamb in Washington. By that time it was out of office hours again in the cycle of things in the United States, and he got onto Mr Lamb at home, but he did clearly establish from Mr Lamb that such a contact had taken place—an entirely innocuous contact, I emphasise, because the substantive significance of all this seems to have been totally forgotten in the excitement of the chase that such a contact had occurred.

I became aware of that early in the afternoon, I think it was, on Friday and I asked at that stage for a memo to be prepared and the other actions to take place of the kind that I described yesterday, by which time the Senate was up. I knew that, with her normal indefatigability, Senator Bishop was likely to raise the issue again when Parliament resumed. I wanted to be in a position to answer the question fully. I would have given a supplementary answer to the Senate explaining that when Parliament resumed had the issue not blown up in the way that it did. I asked that it be followed up. The thing was totally self-explanatory, and that is the basis on which it proceeded.

To suggest that this in any way constitutes a misleading of the Senate is to disgracefully abuse the English language. I hope that not just the Opposition but others who are contemplating the significance of all of this will pay some respect to language.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. There is no doubt that as a result of his failure to return to the chamber upon receiving this further information, Senator Evans wished to leave a misleading impression. There is no doubt about that at all. One also does not need much imagination to know who he was seeking to protect. On the following day, the 8th, he clearly desired the Prime Minister, you and Senator Richardson to be better informed than the Senate and prepared and forwarded a memo. I ask him whether he will table the memo in the Senate now in order that the full Australian public might know what he thought ought to be communicated to his three colleagues.
—Happily. Senator Hill has not asked me before about that one. There is no secret about that. I will find it somewhere and pass it over.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Access to Taxation Records by Inquiries

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time yesterday Senator Coulter asked me a question about the Western Australian royal commission and the Taxation Office. I was unable to answer one part of his question at the end of Question Time, which was: `How many tax records were disclosed to the Fitzgerald inquiry? Was it less than 100?'. The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that the total number of requests for taxation information was 110.

—I wish to clarify a statement I made in my answer on 7 May 1992 to a question asked by Senator West on shipping services. In my answer I referred to arrangements under which savings in port costs in South Australia were required to be passed on directly to shippers. I said that an agreement to this effect between the Australian, New Zealand and Europe Container Services, or ANZECS, and a group of South Australian shippers had been registered with the Trade Practices Commission. I have since been advised that the arrangement in question has not been registered as such by the Trade Practices Commission; it is in fact recorded in a document that has been placed on the Commission's public register.

—Yesterday Senator O'Chee asked me certain questions relating to a search of Mr Gregory Symons's file in the bankruptcy registry in Sydney. I was able to table certain documents in the Senate yesterday and have faxed further documents to Senator O'Chee today.

PARA.TAB: As to the situation which led to the inability of the search clerk acting on behalf of Senator O'Chee to get access to those documents, I am still awaiting a full report from the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy as to that particular matter. I explained to Senator O'Chee why I was not able to get a full report on that matter by Question Time today, although I had hoped to. As soon as we get it I will make it available to Senator O'Chee and, if the Senate is sitting, I will table it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds extraordinary.
—No, it is not. It is just a simple matter.

—During Question Time Senator Hill asked me to check departmental records to see whether there was any evidence on those records of any communication in the period he identified between 6 April and 7 May relating to this particular matter. A full set of departmental documentation is here in the chamber; it has been checked by my officer since the question was asked. I am able to say that there was only one such communication during that period. It was on 21 April. It was a fax about the arrest and the conduct of the forthcoming court case. There was an accompanying cable about that same consular situation which was specifically marked for my officer's attention. The content of this document did not in any way address the question of possible connection or contact between Symons and any Australian mission in the United States.
—Can we see a copy?
—Subject to the normal ground rules that I have identified about confidentiality bearing upon the conduct of the court case. I have made it clear that I have to run all these documents through—
—For heaven's sake, don't ask us to believe you have blacked out a couple of sentences of some document.

—I do ask Senator Walters to believe that. I have asked the Leader of the Opposition to come and have a look at the document and satisfy himself. Is that not good enough for Senator Walters? It is not second-rate theatre that we are being subjected to at the moment; it is fifth-rate theatre.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that there is no documentation other than that which represents any communication between my Department and my office and that certainly conforms with my recollection. It may be that during that period there were one, two or more cables sent from Pohnpei addressing particular consular matters and things of that kind which did come to me in the context of other cables. I have no particular recollection of it. That remains the case. There was no communication other than the one I have mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Chamarette asked me a question concerning a nuclear test claim case. I am advised that Mrs Smith, through her solicitors, has applied for legal aid from the Commonwealth. The request is being considered under the public interest and test case scheme and Senator Chamarette will be familiar with paragraph 18 of the guidelines made by the then Attorney-General, Senator Durack, in March 1981 and tabled in the Senate at that time. Requisitions were delivered to the solicitors on 14 May to which they replied on 19 May but without furnishing the information sought. The matter is receiving priority attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) during Question Time, in particular the last question that he answered to Senator Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon in Question Time we have not seen theatre, as Senator Evans would wish us to believe, but the debasement of the parliamentary process. Quite frankly, a very simple question remains unanswered in any way, shape or form that can be in any way considered satisfactory. It relates to the question I asked the Minister on 7 May when I rose after Question Time, according to the Hansard, at 3.54 p.m. to take note of his answer. Senator Evans rose at 3.57 p.m. to answer my taking note of the answer and the time on the top of the faxed document is 3.53 p.m.

PARA.TAB: In other words, any staff who did not get that document over to the Minister in this chamber forthwith are not behaving properly. If the Minister says he did not see it until he got back to his office after 4 p.m., he then had a number of hours—until five minutes past 11 that night—to come into this chamber and say that this documentation had been received.

The Minister has offered no explanation at all. He has simply offered in his defence that it was 2 o'clock in the morning in Washington and he could not ring Washington. It was not necessary for him to ring Washington in order for him to inform the Senate that, in fact, the information he had given us during the course of his answer could now be illuminated. He had that knowledge at the same time. It was available to him. He deliberately chose not to come back into the Senate. When Senator Hill said the Minister misled the Senate by omission, he was quite correct.

This morning we saw another example of it. During the appropriations debate in the Committee of the Whole we had a little dissertation about a letter written by Mr Kerin to Mr Peacock. The Minister read out parts of the letter and said that I could not have the whole letter because it was private correspondence. Subsequently, I got the letter and discovered that Andrew Peacock had published it. However, the part that the Minister neatly did not care to read out to me during the time he was answering me was the last paragraph of Mr Kerin's letter where he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Due to public interest in this matter, I will make my reply to you available to the media.

In other words, the Minister had the letter in his hand. He was quoting a letter which he had purported to read yet he said it was not a public letter, it was a private letter between two members of Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Minister sits there and tells us that he did not mislead the Parliament. He sits there and has the hide—the audacity—to tell us that he can answer questions put by Senator Schacht about Myanmar with great recall and attention to detail, but as to the running of his own Department, that documentation has been in his Department since 6 April. He now digs up a further document dated 21 April and tells us that not one of his staff has told him anything about it at all.

The Minister expects us to believe that nobody told him about a note he has handed to us which says `Political connections—Sibraa letter', and which talks about Graham Richardson and seeking leniency from Cabinet Ministers and the President of another nation. Does he mean to tell me that if somebody had been seeking leniency from the President of Myanmar he would not have been told? Is there something special about the Marshall Islands? Quite frankly, the Minister is not credible.

Mr Kupa has made a statutory declaration—and I presume that that is Mr Kupa sitting in the advisers' box. I can only suspect that Mr Kupa made that statutory declaration to look after his own back. If I had been in his position, I would have, too. Quite clearly, the Minister could have come in here and misrepresented his position as he has misrepresented all other things. I would very much like Mr Kupa to tell us whether the Minister asked him to sign this statutory declaration or whether he did it of his own volition. I would be most interested if, in the end, the Minister would allow him to tell us exactly the situation in which he signed it.

The Minister's credibility on this issue is simply non-existent. Document after document is turning up. It is like extracting teeth. We are getting them one at a time. We are getting document after document which show that he ought to have known. One cannot but draw the conclusion that the Minister did in fact know, because I cannot imagine that he would have incompetent staff around him who did not keep him informed. If he has, he deserves to go for simply not paying attention to his duty as a Minister.

We all know about the Minister's temper. We have been tempted to put an ashtray on his desk because we understand that that is one of his favourite weapons. I do not know which one got the gash across the eye and had to go to hospital for stitches, but I understand that he was rewarded so he was quiet in the end. So I ask the Minister: how is it that we can believe—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Bishop sought leave to take note of an answer to a question.
—In particular.
—No, an answer to the last question.
—I said all questions in particular.

—If she is going to say `in particular', she ought to be more precise. Her request was to take note of the answer to the last question. She may want to turn this into one of her general smears, which she always does under parliamentary privilege and never outside—this brave Senator Bishop, the scourge of public servants!—but it is not appropriate that she should do so in respect of the motion which she has moved.
—Mr Deputy President—
—I have a point of order on the floor at the moment. Actually, Senator Bishop did not move to take note of a document.
—It was the answer to the last question.
—She had not in fact so moved. But that sometimes happens in this chamber, so I accepted that it had been moved. I am not quite sure what the point of order was—
—Relevance.
—Relevance, yes. I ask Senator Bishop to continue, but there is probably a point with regard to relevance.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. When I sought leave, I sought leave to take note of Senator Evans's answers and, in particular, the last answer in Question Time. It was broad-ranging leave that I sought—and papers. The point that has to be made is that there is ample evidence that the Minister's own office knew all about this matter as and from 6 April. There is ample evidence in the form of file notes, faxes and cables. Looking at the file note, perhaps the Minister might care to tell us what the cables—
—Question Time is over.
—I am not asking now; I am placing it on notice.
—You blew it.

—Blewett was the name of the former Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. There are two cables. One looks like OPM-1558-1557-1556. We would be most interested to know what is in those cables. We would also be most interested to know what has been blacked out in this file note. The serious point is that the Minister has tried to tell us, with an amnesia-led defence, that he at no stage was made aware by any of his advisers or anybody in his office that this matter involved a senior Cabinet Minister who was seeking to intervene in the affairs of another nation. I am sorry, but that is not believable.

PARA.TAB: The other point that is most important is that the Minister keeps telling us we cannot have documents because they relate to evidence that may concern the trial in the Marshall Islands. That is a matter for the Marshall Islands. The content of those cables is a matter for us. There is no sub judice rule covering evidence as it applies to another nation. This is Australia and Australians want to know what is in that documentation—all of it.

When I asked the Minister yesterday to table all the documents as they were first sent to him, he carefully overlooked that part of my supplementary question. Senator Hill has asked for all the documentation to be made available. In the public interest, the interest of the Australian people, we are entitled to see it. To try to say that it is relevant to a trial in a foreign nation and therefore cannot be seen is just not acceptable.

The Minister's record is this: he had, by his own words, the opportunity to come back into this chamber on 7 May and tell us that he had received information immediately he left this chamber from his own office on matters that were pertinent and inquired about at great length in this place during that day. He has given no explanation at all as to why he did not do that. The question of whether he wanted to speak to Washington is irrelevant to that point. The point is that the Minister chose to deprive the Senate of information that it was entitled to have. He can say if he likes that he considers that to be satisfactory ministerial behaviour. I do not think the rest of the chamber will agree with him.

When I was speaking earlier I asked that we be enlightened by Mr Kupa as to whether he decided that he was going to draw up that statutory declaration to protect his own interests—and, as I said, if I were him, I would have—or whether the Minister instructed him to draw up that statutory declaration. I think it is most important that we are informed how that statutory declaration came into existence. The Minister has many questions unanswered. This matter will not disappear. It is a matter that we will pursue until we see all the documentation, until we know the truth of this matter and until we know how far the tentacles of this sordid affair really reach.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —All that speech really amounts to is the fact that Senator Bishop does not personally think much of my credibility. Well, I do not think much of her charm. That makes us even. But it is equally not to the point so far as the standards of integrity and honesty required of people in this place are concerned. I understand those standards. I have met them in this instance, as I always do.

PARA.TAB: As to particular questions about the availability of other documents, I made it perfectly clear in answer to Senator Hill yesterday that I was prepared to treat his generalised request for the tabling of documents as equivalent to an FOI request—that we would tabulate all the material that exists in the various categories which I described yesterday, we would make judgments about its releasability according to FOI criteria and we would release that as expeditiously as we possibly could. That undertaking holds. I said that I would prefer Senator Hill to articulate what he wanted with a bit more precision. But if he is unprepared to do that, just as he was unprepared to look at the document I offered him a chance to look at yesterday, that is fair enough; we will go ahead and do it anyway.

It has to be understood that this consular material relating to the private or legal affairs of people is properly subject to scrutiny on the grounds of ordinary confidentiality principles and ordinary principles of common decency, whether Senator Bishop is prepared to accept or acknowledge their existence or not.
As far as the question of the statutory declaration is concerned, I have already answered that question in Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said we wanted to hear from Mr Kupa.

—Mr Kupa does not have the right to speak in this chamber. Mr Kupa has given me a note in his own words and I am happy to table it if those opposite want me to. It says, `You asked if I would be prepared to sign a statutory declaration. I had no qualms about doing so as the statement was accurate'.

PARA.TAB: I said in Question Time today that I had complete confidence in Mr Kupa's integrity and honesty. I was perfectly prepared to accept his account of what happened at its face value without requiring any statutory declaration. I also said at Question Time that I did not have any confidence that the miserable collection of cynics opposite would necessarily accept it at face value, without the reinforcement of such a particular process. On the basis of that—that those opposite are a miserable bunch of cynics—accordingly, I asked Mr Kupa to prepare a statutory declaration. That was what was done. He has indicated that in the words which I have just mentioned.

As to the prima facie credibility of what he says about not communicating that conversation to me, and my credibility in saying: no, the basic detail of it as he remembered it was not communicated to me, and that is a perfectly credible situation when we remember the facts. Firstly, both he and I were perfectly aware that Mr Symons had been arrested in the Marshall Islands—this consular news which the Department was passing on was not new. We were aware of it. I had become aware of it in Senator Richardson's conversation with me on Friday, the 3rd.

Secondly, it was not news to me that there was an alleged political connection in this. As a result of my conversation with Senator Richardson, I knew very well that Senator Richardson was, from Friday onwards, intending to ring the President of the Marshall Islands in order to make a representation to him on the particular question of the passport. When this information was communicated to Mr Kupa on the Tuesday, it was not news to him and he knew that it was not news to me, so there was no particular reason for him to go out of his way to communicate it to me.

No doubt, he would have communicated to me if I had been sitting there, as I normally do, in the next office. But, as I have already said, I was overseas from the previous day until the 12th—a full week. Given that there was nothing new in any of this, nothing that required any action, nothing that was at odds with our understanding of the situation, it was manifestly the kind of thing that did not require to be communicated to me.

Another consideration, as I tried to explain at Question Time, is that there are invariably one or two other things happening in ministerial offices, particularly one as busy as mine, when things such as this come along. If they do not have any particular substantive significance on their own terms—they may acquire it later on—

TALK.START.PARA: —Like having a Minister phoning the President of another place?

—Elmer is not listening; he never does; he never will; but never mind, I will cope with that with such fortitude as I can command. When situations such as this, which are simply not of themselves of great substantive significance, which do not involve new information and which come along at a time when there are literally hundreds of other things of real significance going on around us and the officers concerned, it is not altogether surprising that recollections fail or things fall between the cracks.

PARA.TAB: That is what happened on this particular occasion so far as that communication on 6 April was concerned. It is a perfectly credible response, not only from me in terms of me describing my own state of mind and state of knowledge throughout this period, but also so far as my office is concerned. It does not demonstrate either neglect or inefficiency. It certainly does not demonstrate any dishonesty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek clarification of a matter. I asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) whether he would table the memo which he said he forwarded to the President of the Senate, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Senator Richardson on Friday, 8 May. The document that he has tabled is a memo purportedly from Deputy Secretary Smith to the Minister's Private Secretary, Miles Kupa. I ask: Is that the memo?
—Yes.
—So there was not any covering note or other comment from you that went to the relevant Ministers or the Prime Minister?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said yesterday, I asked my Department to prepare a memo summarising the circumstances, and in particular summarising the conversation with Mr Lamb. I asked my office, when that memo was prepared—which I had not had an opportunity to even see myself—to take it around to the particular destinations that I mentioned, describe the context and follow up in any way that was necessary during my absence overseas. That is the particular document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The paper that was tabled today, the file note of a conversation from Mr O'Leary to Mr Kupa on 6 April, is a report of the Australian Ambassador's telephone conversation of that date, 6 April, in which some quite alerting, fluorescent statements are made:

SPEECH.PARA: RMI—
that is, the Republic of the Marshall Islands:
—two people arrested
That is the first point that is made. It continues:
—potential for public comment and Pohnpei sensitivity.
Later on, the actual matter of the arrest is referred to as:
fraudulent business migration scheme likely to be charged with forgery conspiracy.
Then there is a blacking out; we do not know what that is. The next point is blacked out. The following comment is that a senior Cabinet Minister is directly involved:
a letter of intro. from Sen. Richardson tabled in Court.
The handwriting below that is indistinct because it was added after the primary note. It continues:
suggestion that Richo has been ringing members of Cabinet and the President seeking leniency.

Already there are at least two fluorescent matters. It is a serious charge involving Australians. There is a potential for public comment. This is the Department telling the Minister's office, the Australian Ambassador is telling the Minister's office through the Department, that there is a potential for public comment and that Senator Richardson is involved in at least two ways: he has been ringing around and his letter of introduction is in court in the Marshall Islands.

PARA.TAB: The next point is that `File 337/4' is `relevant'. That file was tabled yesterday and contains all the matters relating to Senator Sibraa's request for an introduction of Symons to the Australian Embassy in Washington. With regard to that file—in which reference is made to Kylie Oakes, who is the officer who sends such messages in the Department—the file note says: `

SPEECH.PARA: re Symons and Finch—re US Sibraa etc—political connections
Then there are the references at the bottom to which Senator Bishop has referred:
Two cables O.PM 1558, O.PM 1557, O.PM 1556 of Friday

Then there are some words with regard to Peter Byrne and some other people. Miles Kupa's name is mentioned again. They are all in this note of the conversation. As I have said, there are some fluorescent matters there which say that this is not just an ordinary matter—this is not just an ordinary arrest. It is not only a consular matter; it is a matter that involves political connections in Washington, involves the President of the Senate, involves a senior Cabinet Minister and is likely to lead to public comment. The very first thing to be alerted to in the file note is that this matter might blow up into a public controversy in Australia.

PARA.TAB: This was communicated to the Minister's office on 6 April—one month before 7 May when Senator Bishop asked the Minister what he knew about this man Symons. The Minister said—he cannot have it two ways—one month later that he had no knowledge. However, when he is giving his defence as to why his officer Mr Kupa, who is advising him here in the chamber, did not, as it is alleged from his statutory declaration, bring it to his attention one month earlier despite these fluorescent references, he says that he did not bring it to his attention because he already knew that on 3 April—three days before—Senator Richardson had rung him to ask his advice before he rang the President of the Marshall Islands.

So Senator Evans `understood' the matter. He understood from Senator Richardson's telephone conversation that this was a sensitive matter. It was about business migration, it was about Symons and about people being arrested. He knew the political sensitivities. He therefore uses that knowledge, personally derived from Senator Richardson, as the excuse for why his principal adviser in his own office did not bring this file note of some dynamite or, as I say, fluorescence to his attention. Senator Evans cannot have it both ways. If he claimed that the reason it was not brought to his attention, if it was not, was that he already knew about these things, why did he not give that answer here in the Senate on 7 May when he was asked? He did not give that answer. He gave the answer, `I have no understanding of the matter'.

There is one other matter to which I wish to refer. It arises as a result of the lack of credibility of Senator Evans in this whole matter over these last few days. There is no independent evidence that Senator Richardson ever spoke to Senator Evans. No note has been given by Senator Richardson; no note has been given by Senator Evans. There appears to be no witness to this conversation. One possibility is that it never happened.

When this file note is received by the Minister's personal adviser and when it is communicated from our Ambassador in the Marshall Islands—when it is received by the responsible officer, O'Leary, in the Department—they do not have any knowledge that three days earlier, so it is alleged, there was a conversation between two senior Cabinet Ministers about the propriety of that Minister, Senator Richardson, ringing the President of the Marshall Islands or other Cabinet Ministers of the Marshall Islands either to ask for leniency in respect of his cousin Symons or to ask that his cousin be able to defend his case by returning to Australia and that his passport be given back. They are the two versions of the story we have received. Originally the story was that there was a request that his passport be given back; now we hear that the rumour is that he was asking for leniency. We still do not know which one of those is true.

In any event, I put it clearly that over these last two days, after some maybe 30 questions to the Minister and literally the greater part of three hours of him answering questions, Senator Evans has not been able to give one shred of evidence that there was in fact that conversation and, if there was the conversation, why there was no note of it and, if there was a conversation, why some note or advice was not given to the Department or at least to our Ambassador in the Marshall Islands.

Obviously it was a matter that was sufficiently important for Senator Richardson to ask the advice of the Foreign Minister about the sensitivities of the Marshall Islands, yet not of sufficient importance in the mind of that Minister to bring it to the attention of our Ambassador and representative who, it was clear, was going to be in for quite a deal of at least consular and possibly public controversy with all of the US connection and so on. There are not only New South Wales senators but also South Australian senators in this chamber. I put it to Senator Evans that most of this chamber has seen his lack of credibility in the answers he has given over the last two days and that he has not satisfactorily addressed these matters.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented and I seek leave to make a short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented, first of all, in the suggestion being made that I have lied to the Senate on all those numerous occasions on which I have said that I had a conversation with Senator Richardson on 3 April. I might have wished that I had no conversation—that thought has often occurred to me since—but I did, and I told my senior private secretary about it immediately afterwards, although there was no independent witness to it. If it ever became necessary, I am sure another statutory declaration could be filed, although I am sure it is utterly unnecessary in the view of anyone but crazed conspiracy theorists for such a step to be taken.
—Was there a note of it?
—There is a scribbled bit of paper somewhere from me just saying `3/4—Richo rang', or something like that. There is a note in my file.
—Table it.

—I am not going to dribble out little bits of documentation here, there and everywhere. A conversation took place, with the substance I have described, and I do not mislead the Senate, then or now, and never will.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, Senator Teague says that I misled the Senate today in the sense that I cannot have it both ways. I must have known of the entire contents of this particular document, and in fact I said I did. What I said, and I just want to clarify it again for the record, is that I knew of two important matters that are referred to in this document. Firstly, I knew of the arrest of Mr Symons; and, secondly, I knew of the actual involvement of Senator Richardson so far as a phone call to the Marshall Islands was concerned. My senior adviser also knew of those two matters because I had told him about them. I did not know of the Washington connection until 7 May, and my senior adviser does not recall the Washington connection, other than in the circumstances which he has described in his statutory declaration.

To say that somehow I have got myself caught up in a contradiction is just to completely misunderstand or to deliberately distort the statements I have made in the Senate today. I repeat them for the record: I was not surprised to hear of these matters after the event—just a few days ago; I would not have been surprised to hear of them at the time had Mr Kupa described them to me because I did know of the arrest and I did know of the Richardson phone call. But I did not know of anything else, and I hope the record is now absolutely clear on that particular matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I wish to exercise my right of reply to the motion I have moved. A few matters have arisen from listening to what the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has had to say and also from having a closer look at the documentation made available yesterday and today. I note that this file note with the deletions in it has a side note that says, `Telephone call from Peter Stanford, 6.4.92'. I then went back to the statutory declaration sworn by Mr Kupa and I found a document which is a fax from the Federated States of Micronesia to Kylie Oakes. It is dated 3 December 1991. It says, `Subject: Australian Consultants to the RMI Government: Request for Assistance'. The opening words are:

SPEECH.PARA: Re your fax. . .
That means that there has been a fax from either Kylie Oakes or from someone within the Department. Where is that fax? The fax continues:
. . . we have no background on this matter here, nor was it raised with me during my visit to RMI last week.
The second paragraph is even more interesting:
We shall try to find out more about Symons and Finch and their mission in Washington, and will let you know when we do.

If Mr Peter Stanford undertook to make investigations about Washington in December 1991, presumably he followed that up. Where are the results of his investigations and can we have them tabled also? I conclude by saying that the comments made by the Minister as a result of my moving a motion to take note of his answers, in fact, leave more questions unanswered than there were before I began the exercise.

PARA.TAB: There is more documentation we need to see. I would be most interested to hear from Mr Kupa himself, and indeed from Mr O'Leary. I suppose the only way we can do that is to perhaps have the inquiry we first sought, or else—and we might examine this proposition—we could move in the Senate that Mr Kupa be heard by the Senate. The Minister has simply said that he had no knowledge at all of this matter when, quite clearly, early on in the piece, as a result of the investigations that Mr Stanford must have done, he must have found out about Senator Sibraa's letter. We have evidence from the Minister that he spoke with another Minister about calling a foreign government and the appropriateness of that, and that he apparently did not even ask his staff what was known about this matter; he did not even bother to inquire. If that is truly the way the Minister conducts his business, he ought to stand down, because that is not proper behaviour.

The alternative is that, if he did in fact ask, he must have been told and, therefore, he has simply not been telling us the truth when he said that he knew nothing at all.
