I find it very difficult to believe that a man who prides himself on attention to detail—right down to the point of writing a book about what a great job he has done—would not be sufficiently in touch with his staff to be informed about a matter which had all the inklings and alarm bells of a scandal. It had all the alarm bells of improper behaviour; it had all the alarm bells of, `Why the hell does my colleague Senator Richardson want to ring the Marshall Islands to intervene on behalf of a relative-cum-mate?'.

Did Senator Evans know, for instance, that Australia had no extradition arrangements with the Marshall Islands? He always tells us that his attention to detail is good, that he is so well informed and that he knows these things. That may or may not be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has that got to do with it?

—If a Minister of the Australian Government rings the President of another government to ask that a passport be given back to an Australian national, knowing that there are no extradition arrangements, we could end up like Christopher Skase. That is exactly the sort of alarm bell that would ring; that is exactly what Christopher Skase did. We see that every indication says that the Minister ought to have been informed. That is why I can stand here and say, as others have said, that it is just not credible to believe that the Minister knew nothing—selective amnesia. Then, on the day when he was finally put to the test and asked whether he would conduct an inquiry, whether he would find out and tell us, he said that there was nothing of substance and that he had no reason to look at that. He used his favourite word—`fulminate'.
—Very appropriate in your case.

—Very appropriate in your case, Minister. The better word for you, I am afraid, is `obfuscate'. The Minister finally was tested and asked to make that investigation, and immediately after that he actually got information and deliberately did not come back to this chamber—and, again, we have no sufficient answer as to why that was so. So he can understand why people are `sceptical', to use the word that the Minister uses to describe people who are sceptical about believing what he says. That scepticism is totally justified.

PARA.TAB: There are more questions that remain to be answered but, very specifically, I put on notice that we want to hear from Mr Kupa, by some means or another, and from Mr O'Leary. We want to see the fax that was sent from Australia to which this fax is a response. I want to see the result of Mr Stanford's investigations as to the mission of Mr Finch and Mr Symons in Washington—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the 3 April note of the telephone conversation.

—And the 3 April note of the telephone conversation; the one that the Minister said was crunched up and around the place somewhere. When we can see that information, the Minister can be assured that the matter will be raised again.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

The particular fax from Peter Stanford of 3 December which says `re: your fax' is a response to the document that is on the very next page, the fax signed, `thanks, Kylie'—that being Kylie Oakes of my Department—on 29 November, which fax covered the three subsequent pages that Senator Bishop can see there. They referred to the basic exchange between Canberra and Washington—not an exchange, but setting out Senator Sibraa's letter. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Harradine on 27 May 1992 relating to population control in China.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate may recall that I asked a question of Senator Evans about a very gravely disconcerting situation in China where for every 100 boys under the age of two there are only 89 girls. That, in fact, means that there are millions of missing females. That is the direct result of China's one-child family policy. I called that barbaric. I also asked the Minister whether he could explain to the Senate why, and on whose advice, AIDAB currently had a delegation in China for the purpose of increasing Australian aid to that program, either directly or through UNFPA.

PARA.TAB: The Minister did not address the latter part of that question at all. I would like a response to that, and I will deal with that in a moment. But, in his reply, the Minister said that it was very much Senator Harradine's judgment that the Chinese population policy is barbaric. He said that other judgments differ in that respect, including the judgment of Senator Schacht. That is true. But who is right?

The interesting part of Senator Evans's response is when he says that it is a matter for detailed analysis, debate and argument, not for assertions by me. That is absolutely correct. I have never said anything about the Chinese population control program that has not been able to be backed up by evidence—contrary to what Senator Schacht has done in his human rights delegation report, in which he repeated certain assertions without checking them and without having the documentation to check them. That documentation was in fact in my office. It was not provided to him by the Minister's Department or, in that particular case, by the individual, Dr Hull, who was contracted to brief the human rights delegation.

Senator Schacht repeatedly phoned AIDAB, trying to get it to send a mission to China. Senator Schacht is the one who has been doing that. I do not know whether the Minister has known that, but that has been the situation. I certainly agree with the proposition that we should oppose strongly becoming involved in anything that relates `to the use of coercive practices of any kind'. Those were the words used by the Minister in his answer to me.

I appeal to the Minister to look at the documented evidence and not rely upon the Hull document, which was contracted not by his Department but by AIDAB. I did some research on it but, not satisfied with that, I thought it was important to get a full response to the Hull document, and I have that response in my hand. It is from a China specialist in the United States, a former senior research specialist on China in the US Bureau of Census, Dr John S. Aird. He is an author, a person who has detailed knowledge of the situation. He sent a document entitled A Response to Recent Population Policy in China by Terence Hull, the AIDAB sector report 1991 No. 4.

This is a 72-page document with 198 footnotes, most of which are from Chinese sources. Anyone who knows anything about China would know that one does not take on face value what the Chinese authorities tell visitors such as the human rights delegation. One does not take on face value what they say to the world. But one does take seriously what they tell their own people in this particular area. Here is a document that uses those sources. I seek leave to table this document and to have incorporated in Hansard the one-page summary by Dr Aird on page 3 of the document.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Summary

The opposing arguments on the question of whether the Chinese family planning program is coercive do not really start from a common body of evidence. Critics of the program document their charges; defenders avoid coming to grips with the concrete evidence. Many defenders of the Chinese program, including family planners and some demographers, have value conflicts and conflicts of interest in the matter. Most have accepted the "population crisis" idea as established fact, even though it has been seriously challenged on the grounds that it is simplistic and unproven. Family planners want to identify with the evident success of the Chinese program. Some demographers are afraid to criticise it lest they lose their access to Chinese population data, research opportunities, and contacts with Chinese colleagues. Because of the resulting biases, the case put by defenders of the Chinese program is seriously flawed.

The Hull report tries to redefine "coercion" as narrowly as possible to dispel the coercion charge without meeting it head on. It accepts the Chinese cover story that coercion occurs only as a local deviation from government policy and is stopped whenever it is detected. But it ignores substantial evidence that coercion is encouraged from the top and that some forms of coercion have been openly commended by the central authorities.

The report argues that the adoption of a new round of provincial family planning laws since 1985 represents an attempt by the authorities to establish a "rule of law" that would prevent the local cadres from resorting to coercive measures. But the laws themselves contain no prohibitions against coercive tactics, nor have the Chinese authorities come up with a specific case of a cadre being punished for using coercion in family planning work. Besides, the domestic media make it perfectly clear that the purpose of the new laws is to tighten, not loosen, the pressures for compliance with family planning demands.

Hull follows Greenhalgh's lead in insisting that enforcement of family planning policies is becoming more lax because of changes in other aspects of domestic policy, including economic reforms. Both assume that family planning policies cannot be tightened if other aspects of policy are becoming more relaxed. However, the descriptive evidence suggests that the trend in family planning policy has been to tighten control since 1985, and the statistical evidence shows that numbers of family planning surgeries have risen since 1985 and that the total fertility rate, which had rebounded in 1986 and 1987, fell again in 1988, 1989, and 1990.

Hull argues that Australian support for the Chinese program will eventually moderate its extreme aspects, but that does not seem to have happened as a result of the United Nations Population Fund involvement that began in 1979 or the International Planned Parenthood Federation involvement that began in 1983. Neither organisation was in a position to exercise a moderating influence in view of their unstinting praise of the program and their unwillingness to recognise its coercive aspects, which the Chinese authorities have correctly interpreted as approval for the program as a whole. Despite their major financial and technical contributions, neither organisation seems to have any real leverage over the program.

Pervasive euphemisms, misstatements of fact, inaccuracies in interpretation, and misrepresentations of the positions of opponents bias the Hull report in favour of the Chinese program. The report is essentially a whitewash and does not constitute an adequate basis for decision on the part of Australian policymakers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tabled document authored by Dr John Aird will be appreciated by those scholars and policy makers who take the responsible view that academic and public policy interests are best served where openness and truth are not subjugated to a political agenda.

PARA.TAB: For some time now, as honourable senators will recall, ministerial and departmental responses to my questions on human rights violations inherent in the PRC's population control program have intrigued me by their mixture of evasiveness and dogmatism. I became concerned about this when it emerged that the Australian human rights delegation to China was so poorly briefed that it was unable to challenge the assurances of Sichuan Province family planning officials, which were then simply repeated in the delegation's report to Parliament. The delegation was not even provided with a copy of this Province's draconian family planning regulations at its briefing prior to departure.

I am also concerned that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade appears to have surrendered its human rights surveillance role in the population control area to AIDAB, which had contracted Dr Terry Hull to write a report on China's population control policies with particular emphasis on what he says are the controversial issues of social pressure and coercion.

On the basis of detailed information held in my office, I considered the Hull report to be less than helpful in the search for truth and an obvious promotion of the interests of the international population control bureaucracies such as UNFPA and IPPF. The action of UNFPA in allocating $US57m to the PRC Government's population control program just three days after the Tiananmen Square massacre still rankles. My concern was heightened when it became clear that the Minister was prepared to accept Dr Hull's report as a basis for Government policy and refused my request that AIDAB publish a more balanced and objective study.

Since it appears that there is a growing intolerance amounting almost to censorship of the views of those who would challenge the assertions upon which the current Government policy is based, I considered it necessary in the public interest to seek a scholarly response which even the ideologically blinkered might not ignore. The tabled document is that response. I challenge the Minister, his Department and AIDAB to ensure its distribution to those who have or will receive the whole report from AIDAB. I should like the Minister to tell the Senate why the delegation is in China and on whose advice that delegation is there at this moment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to Senator Harradine for not responding to the latter part of his original question about the AIDAB delegation in China. I will seek information on that from my colleague Mr Kerin, whose responsibility this is within my portfolio, and seek to put down an early reply. I welcome the contribution of Dr Aird to this ongoing debate and I am quite happy to see the document now in currency.

—I did not hear all of Senator Harradine's remarks; I was unaware that he was going to speak on this issue, which relates to the report of the human rights delegation visit to China last year and of which I was the leader. In preparing the agenda and itinerary for that delegation's visit, it was quite clear from all the members of the delegation that we wished to deal with the human rights aspects of the Chinese family planning program and population policy.

PARA.TAB: As a result, we spent two days in Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan Province, having extensive discussions with the officials responsible for running the family planning policy in that province, both at the senior level in the capital and in a village in the nearby rural area, where we talked with people who at a local level carry the policy through.

I must say to Senator Harradine that, until one actually visits China and gets some perspective of what a country with 1,100 million to 1,200 million people looks and feels like, it is a little hard to moralise back here in Australia on all aspects of their family planning program. For example, 110 million people live in Sichuan Province, the area of which is probably not much greater than the total area of Tasmania, a State in Australia that has half a million people. If Senator Harradine can imagine 110 million people living in Tasmania and what that would do to the quality of life in every sense of the word, he will start to get a concept of the Chinese obsession with family planning and living standards for their people.

In the questions we put to China's planning officials—and it is in our report—they made no bones about the fact that one of their major problems is female infanticide. They openly gave us the figures, which showed that in the previous year in Sichuan province, for every 107 boys registered at birth, only 100 girls were registered. So there was a disparity in that year. According to their figures, it was about seven. Clearly, by any demographer's analysis, that means that there is an imbalance. The figures should be much closer. As I understand it, the normal imbalance between male and female births is one or two—for example, between 100 and 101, or 100 and 102.

The planning officials openly admitted without hesitation the problem of female infanticide, particularly in rural and remote rural areas. They also openly admitted the problem of having to rely on abortion as a contraception means. They admitted that three years ago the number of registered births in the province was about two million and the number of abortions 600,000. They pointed out that, two years later, for two million births they had about 300,000 or 400,000 abortions—again a very high figure which under no circumstances were they happy with.

It was clear to us from talking to the officials and to the local people that the high incidence of abortion is a result of not having the facilities in the family planning process to provide decent mechanical contraceptive devices to all the population. This became clear when we went to the villages. The officials openly admitted that not everybody has access to condoms, the pill or IUDs and that, as a result, when women become pregnant there is pressure put on them to have an abortion. There is the social pressure of the community as well as psychological pressure. There is financial pressure put on them in that if they have two or more children they pay a financial penalty.

The officials admitted that people traditionally would rather have a son than a daughter. That puts female babies at risk of being killed. We raised a specific question that was raised by Senator Harradine and by the then Senator Olsen in a Senate Estimates committee hearing a couple of years ago: whether ultrasonic equipment provided by an Australian aid program was being used to determine the sex of children so that female foetuses could be aborted. The officials said that it was illegal under Chinese law. They do not want people to know the sex of the baby because they do not want an abortion to be carried out. They admitted that they have difficulty in stopping it occurring, that bribery takes place and so on, but that is the law they work under. It is an offence for a doctor or a medical official to give information to parents about the sex of the foetus. But they admitted that there are many gaps and difficulties in the historical culture of China—which favours male births—which make it difficult for all of this to be carried through.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the only place in the world either.

—No, it is not the only place. I know that Senator Harradine has had a long interest in this issue. He has raised interminable questions. He thinks that there is some sort of conspiracy in AIDAB or amongst the academics in Australia to somehow favour this dreadful program in China or elsewhere in the world. My view, and the view of the delegation, is that the issue that we should be looking at in terms of family planning in China is assistance in the area of women's health, because the contraceptive devices being made available to Chinese women put their health at risk. I have to say, after seeing some of the locally made IUDs that are provided, that they look more like a torture weapon to me than a contraceptive device. But they are all that they have available.

PARA.TAB: I would hope that in any family planning program in which we can assist China we can provide better information, technical facilities and devices so that women's health is not so adversely affected. One of the problems China has at the moment is the high number of abortions. If we provide better contraceptive devices and better educational information, in my view there will be far fewer abortions, and I am sure that would be in line with Senator Harradine's wishes.

I make no bones about the fact that since my return to Australia last year I have asked a number of questions of the relevant Estimates committee about pushing AIDAB to take a higher profile on family planning matters. I have asked questions about the need for us to substantially increase the funding under Australia's bilateral and multilateral aid programs to provide information and assistance to family planning programs in developing countries, programs that are not coercive but that are educational and supportive and, above all else, that give the women in the Third World, the developing world, the same right of choice as women in Australia have. That is the fundamental issue that should be dealt with.

Unfortunately, Senator Harradine's remarks and the issues he raises seem to indicate that he is less concerned about the health of women in the Third World than he is about the issue of abortion or coercion. The issue of coercion is important, and we should do everything we can to say to people that family planning has to be voluntary; that it has to be consensorial. If Senator Harradine can imagine 110 million people living in an area the size of Tasmania, then he will start having to make the judgment that he does not have many options about what he can do in regard to family planning and the size of the population.

The Chinese make it quite clear. They say, `If we do not adopt a very severe family planning policy, if you want us not to worry about it, what are you and the rest of the world going to do in the year 2020 or 2015, when there are two billion Chinese people living in the same area? Will you take 150 million people into Australia?'. It is a very good question to ask all of us who wish to moralise about their draconian policy. They have certainly put the shoe on the other foot. Would we take millions or tens of millions of Chinese immigrants to relieve the strain and pressure of the population on their country?

The Chinese say, `If you want a stable China, a country that has a future, where people can live with an expectation of an improved living standard, there has to be some sort of population policy whereby the country's economic growth can provide an increased living standard for the population. But if there is a population growth rate of 3 per cent or 4 per cent, the economic growth rates of China will not only be unable to provide an increased standard of living; they will not even be able to maintain the present standard of living, and the country will descend into economic chaos as more and more people fight over fewer and fewer resources'.

These are the fundamental issues that the Chinese Government is trying to come to terms with—a Government which I will criticise and have criticised on human rights issues across the board. As the Chinese reminded us endlessly, there is a human right in China: it is the right to exist. Senator Bourne heard that endlessly when we raised political, human and social rights. The only right is the right to exist. If there is no stability in China, there will be chaos and a lot of people will die of starvation or as a result of inadequate health and social services.

I note Senator Harradine's concern, but to raise this issue as though some untoward or misleading briefing has been given in the past to our delegation by AIDAB, or will be given to it in the future, is absolutely erroneous. We sought information from a range of experts before we went to China, including experts on family planning. This was most useful information.

TALK.START.PARA: —From whom?
—From experts who came and gave us briefing information.
—Who? Hull?
—Yes, Dr Hull was one of them, and from AIDAB Mrs Hull.
—Valerie Hull.

—Yes, Valerie Hull. Senator Harradine may think that Terry Hull and Valerie Hull are devils or demons incarnate, but in all of the discussions I have had with them I have found them to be humane, sensitive people who are dealing with an issue that most people in this country do not even want to know about. They ought to be given respect as professional officers, who are providing information that is sensitive to the issues of human rights and very sensitive even to the issues that Senator Harradine is concerned about. I do not think it does any good for Senator Harradine to imply that they are giving us, the Parliament, or AIDAB information that shows that they are not sensitive to human rights issues as they relate to family planning. That is absolutely erroneous.

PARA.TAB: I wish to say for the record that, in my dealings with Dr Terry Hull and Ms Valerie Hull, I have nothing but complimentary remarks to make about their performance. If anything, at times I have upbraided them by saying that they are too sensitive to some of the issues raised by Senator Harradine. I think he is being extreme in the way he puts his point.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?

—The fact is that Senator Harradine is implying that AIDAB or the Australian Government is partner to some of the more severe and repressive features of the Chinese family planning policy. That has not been the information that they have given us in briefings. However, I make it quite clear to them—and I have said this to Valerie Hull—that every time Senator Harradine asks a question on these sorts of extreme notions about family planning, I would double the family planning budget and the aid budget by another $1m. This is an area where we could be criticised because, out of a budget of $1,100m for overseas aid last year, we spent under $10m on both bilateral and multilateral aid for family planning around the world.

PARA.TAB: One of the fundamental issues that the world has to face is its population crisis. Australia is a developed country and a large continent with only 17 million people. If nothing else, we have a very strong moral obligation. We have the luxury of not being an overcrowded country and, compared with most of the rest of the world, we have a decent standard of living. We have a responsibility to assist those overcrowded countries which, as a result, are affected by poverty and low living standards. We ought to make a larger contribution to assist them in decent, consensorial family planning policies and not bark up Senator Harradine's tree by saying that this is some sort of devious plot to interfere with the rights of individuals. Senator Harradine has not done the overall issue of family planning any great service at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are making broad, unfounded allegations, as usual.

—I have sat through hour after hour of endless Estimates committees where Senator Harradine has asked question after question. The honourable senator has put on notice hundreds of questions. I suspect that one of the tactics is to have Valerie Hull in AIDAB spend all of her time providing answers to his inane questions rather than getting on with the proper work of providing information and developing decent, humane family planning policies for AIDAB to discuss with developing countries. I will conclude on the point that at the moment—and I hope Senator Harradine is correct—there is an AIDAB mission in China which is having bilateral discussions with their people about family planning.
—You know there is.
—If that is true, that was a recommendation in our report.
—Where?

—It was one of the recommendations of the human rights delegation report that there ought to be an upgraded bilateral program of family planning for Australia to assist the People's Republic of China. That is in the report. It was the unanimous decision of the delegation. All 10 members have, without equivocation, put forward that recommendation after seeing the conduct of the family planning program in Sichuan province as it affects women's health. That is our recommendation and I am glad that AIDAB has taken it up and is there. I hope it comes back with a proposal that there ought to be increased expenditure to provide better health services to women in terms of family planning.

PARA.TAB: That is the issue that Senator Harradine should spend more time being concerned about: the rights of women in the world to better family planning as a women's health issue, and not some berserk moral issue that he thinks he ought to impose on women around the world. I congratulate AIDAB and will continue to argue that it ought to be lifting its game and expanding its role in promoting decent family planning programs for women in the developing world. It is a humane policy which all members of this Parliament ought to support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In closing the debate, I wish to respond to some of the points made by Senator Schacht, none of which were based on any evidence whatsoever. He made assertion after assertion after assertion, which is typical of some of the people who have been promoting the view that the Australian Government should become involved in the population control policies of the PRC. That has not been my view all along. My view was to study the material and the evidence and not to take what the Chinese say to visitors at face value. That is what Senator Schacht has done.
—Read the report.

—I have read the report, and it is a disgrace. Page 47 repeats the assurances given to the delegation by the Chinese officials. The report says that compulsory abortion and compulsory sterilisation are strictly proscribed and contrary to policy. The officials of the Sichuan province told members of the delegation that.

PARA.TAB: Delegation members did not even have the regulations of the Sichuan province with them at that stage. Therefore, they were not in a position to challenge those assurances. Had they had those regulations, they would have seen that those regulations not only do not proscribe coerced abortions and forced sterilisations, they in fact prescribe them; they make them mandatory in certain circumstances. If Senator Schacht's delegation was aware of that, it should have then challenged the officials. It would have been able to report to us that this is how the officials dealt with those allegations and this is how they interpret those regulations.

This is a matter of basic human rights. Senator Schacht talks about moralising. It is a moral question; it is a question of right or wrong as to whether millions of females have fallen victim to the one child per family policy. Indeed, the most fundamental human right of all is the right to life. The millions of females who have become the victims of this one child per family policy do not seem to concern Senator Schacht.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the report, you fool.

—I have read the report. The report is a nonsense in respect of this because it simply repeats the assurances given to the delegation. Before he says anything more about it, I suggest that Senator Schacht study the document that has now been tabled and the document that has been authored by Dr John S. Aird.

PARA.TAB: Dr Aird does not see eye to eye with me on all matters. But his report is a scholarly exposition of the situation in China and a scholarly demolition of the Hull report. As Senator Schacht has said, it was principally Dr Hull who, in the family planning area, briefed the delegation. If Senator Schacht knew that the delegation was going to the Sichuan province, why did not Dr Hull provide the delegation with the full copy of the Sichuan province regulation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because he probably didn't have a copy, I presume.
—I had a copy in my office. Senator Schacht could have rung me and got it.
—Before we went?
—Yes, I did. I have had it there for some time.
—From Sichuan province?

—Yes, from Sichuan province. I have had it in my office for some time. In fact, it had been printed, although I cannot recall where—it may well have been one of the books or articles that were written by Aird.
—We brought back the official document.

—This is an official translation of the Sichuan province document. Yes, Senator Schacht eventually got it, but in the report he did not then refer to the coercive aspects of those regulations mandating abortion and sterilisation in certain circumstances. All he did was put an annex in his report which dealt with just a small part of the province regulations which relate to—
—Why don't you go to China?
—Senator Schacht is not listening.
—You are talking about this one.

—I am talking about the faults in the delegation's report and it is about time he listened. The report only included that aspect of the Sichuan province regulations which related to exemptions from the one child per family policy. That is not a proper or reasonable way to approach things. We want the facts of the situation because human rights issues are at stake.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht accuses me in an unfounded way of not being concerned about women's health. I am very concerned about women's health. Senator Schacht may not have been at the Senate Estimates committee hearings when I raised the very important issue of women's health in Africa. What has happened to the request for action to be taken by the Government in respect of that matter? I am personally involved in the area of aid for health, including women's health, in developing countries, but I am not prepared to demean myself to detail those matters here.

I then come to Senator Schacht's other point, which is also unfounded. Without any analysis at all, he seems to accept the population bomb crisis that has been advanced, largely by the international population control bureaucrats. The more they can build up that fear in people's minds, the more money they will get, irrespective of how it affects the health of women.

Many people have criticised population control measures—for example, in East Timor and Bangladesh. Some Bangladesh feminist group called the feminist population control program `anti-poor and anti-women'. To blame the fertility of poor women in poor countries for a range of problems as some people do is totally unfair. To suggest that we ought to become involved in some way in this `barbaric program'—and that is the only term one can use—by providing more modern IUDs or whatever, is to become embroiled in the coercive population control program itself.

Senator Schacht talked about the Chinese wanting to do something in the population area. It is the PRC Government and the State Family Planning Commission and their operators in the particular provinces that want to do something. Surely the Chinese people have a right to determine these issues. It is not as though people do not make responsible decisions; of course they do. How has Senator Schacht got the right to paternalistically pontificate here as to what ordinary Chinese parents should or should not do? The situation is well covered. I appeal to honourable senators to read and study the document that has been tabled because it deals with the population issues in a scholarly fashion on the basis of evidence and in a way which would demolish the points that have been made by Senator Schacht.

I will not delay the Senate further. I would like you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and all other honourable senators to look at the tabled document. It is an extremely valuable document. Senator Schacht accuses me of saying that the Hulls are devils incarnate. I have not reflected at all on the characters or the internal dispositions of the Hulls. Valerie Hull is head of the section in AIDAB. Dr Terry Hull, her husband, received the grant to do this paper. It was a substantial grant. Dr John Aird makes the following conclusion in the summary of the tabled document:

Pervasive euphemisms, misstatements of fact, inaccuracies in interpretation, and misrepresentations of the positions of opponents bias the Hull report in favour of the Chinese program. The report is essentially a whitewash and does not constitute an adequate basis for decision on the part of Australian policymakers.

SPEECH.PARA: Those are very serious statements and I think they should be taken on board by the Government. I repeat the challenge to the Government: if it is going to be open in this matter and if it really seeks the truth, will it ensure that AIDAB sends the Aird document to all of those to whom it has given or will give the Hull document? That is fair, is it not? I ask anybody: is it not fair that AIDAB should send the Aird document out to everybody who has received or will receive the Hull document? We will see whether that takes place. We will see whether some still have closed minds and are not prepared to face up to the evidence.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the further answer given by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator O'Chee on 26 May 1992 relating to Mr Greg Symons.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a matter of importance that relates to a question asked yesterday regarding the Marshall Islands affair. A search of the bankruptcy registry in New South Wales yesterday failed to disclose documents relating to Mr Symons's insolvency which should have been on the file and available for public scrutiny. I asked the Minister yesterday why those documents were not present. At that stage I was of the understanding that Mr Symons had entered into a deed of arrangement. At any rate, whatever his arrangement is with his creditors—it turns out that it was a composition—that document should have been on the file and the certificate of release, if any had been issued, should also have been on the file. I ask the question very clearly: why were these documents missing from the file and why was my search clerk told that these matters were confidential? Senator Tate subsequently issued a press release headed, `O'Chee gets it wrong'. It states:
Senator Tate this afternoon described the comments as wrong, vindictive and a grossly unjustified slur on Government officers and Ministers.

"The simple fact is that Senator O'Chee's staff member looked at the wrong file—failed to find the information he was seeking, and then the Senator rushed into the public debate with a completely erroneous set of allegations", Senator Tate said.

The fact is that my search clerk did have the right file. When I was in Question Time yesterday I had the statement of affairs that was sworn by Mr Gregory Bernard Symons on 27 September 1989. There is no more incontrovertible proof that these documents came from Gregory Bernard Symons's file. The correct file was searched, but the documents in question relating to Mr Symons's insolvency agreements, the documents relating to his possible release from those agreements, were not available for my search clerk. That is a breach of the Bankruptcy Act and a breach of the bankruptcy regulations. These are statutory public documents. Why were they absent from the file? Why were they not given to my search clerk?

PARA.TAB: Subsequently, yesterday evening Senator Tate advised me that he had the information I sought. He came into the Senate and tabled the information. I congratulate him; at least we have one Government Minister who wants to table information. Essentially, the document Senator Tate tabled and subsequent documents which have come into my possession vindicate my concern that those documents related to certain possible breaches of the Corporations Act which Mr Symons may have committed and, moreover, they are highly damaging to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

Mr Peacock in the other place today drew the attention of Mr Kerin to an advertisement in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette No. B48 on 12 December 1989. It was item NX227/89. Notice was given that Gregory Bernard Symons was to pay his trustee on behalf of his creditors the sum of $25,000 on or before 31 December 1989. That was the deal that Mr Symons did to be released from $1.5m of debts. It goes further. Had the documents I sought been available to me yesterday, it would have been possible to show that Mr Symons in fact did not meet those requirements, did not in fact pay the money until some time in October 1991 and that his certificate of release, far from being signed in December 1989 or early 1990, was not signed by his trustee until November 1991, almost two years after the due date for Mr Symons to pay the $25,000.

What is the significance of this delay? The significance of this delay is simple. The $25,000 payment made by Mr Symons to relieve himself of $1.5m of debt coincided with an export market development grant given by Austrade to Mr Symons in or about October 1991. In effect, not only has Mr Symons evaded $1.5m of debt by doing this cosy little arrangement with some of his creditors but moreover there is a very strong case to be put that the Australian taxpayer has provided Mr Symons with the money that he needed to get out of his bankruptcy obligations. I ask this chamber: is it reasonable for us to tolerate Austrade providing people such as Mr Symons, through export market development grants, with the money they need to meet their bankruptcy obligations?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an allegation by you.

—It is an allegation which I have proved ably this afternoon. If the Minister has any further doubt, I shall continue for his benefit. I spoke to the trustee this morning. The trustee told me that Mr Symons paid the $25,000 on 22 October 1991. If the Minister does not believe me, he can believe Mr Symons's trustee. He can believe the fact that the money was never paid on the due date. Mr Symons did not pay it by the end of December 1989. He did not pay it in 1990. He paid it towards the end of 1991, after he got the benefit of $131,443 of taxpayers' money for an export market development grant.

PARA.TAB: The argument could be made by those on the other side of the chamber, if they had enough wit or wisdom to try to put the argument, that Mr Symons first of all had to expend funds to get an export market development grant. Indeed, he would. But there is one little problem with that: when Mr Symons swore the affidavit verifying his statement of affairs on 27 September 1989 he said that his total realisable assets amounted to $10 cash at bank. The $10 millionaire!

While Mr Symons's total assets were $10, how could he expend enough money to be due a $131,000 export market development grant? Either one of two things occurred: either Mr Symons was due that grant at the time at which he swore the statement of affairs and he did not disclose it or he received funding from another source. That is a matter of which Austrade should have inquired and a matter of which Austrade should be cognisant. This Senate and the Australian people deserve to know how it was that $131,000 of taxpayers' money was made available to Mr Symons, and about that time he used $25,000 to pay off $1.5m of bankruptcy obligations.

If only all the poor indebted people of Australia could have the good fortune of Mr Symons, could have the good fortune to trip around the world whilst technically insolvent under administration. If only all the poor people of Australia could have the benefit of Mr Symons and the mates who are going to look after him, the mates to assist them get into arrangements with other governments and get appointments overseas when at the time they are totally incapable of being involved in the management of any company in Australia. That is the nub of the whole thing.

At the time at which Mr Symons saw Senator Richardson, at the time at which Mr Symons saw Senator Sibraa, at the time at which Mr Symons went to the US and used the facilities of our embassy there, at the time at which Mr Symons obtained the $131,000 export market development grant, he was an insolvent under administration and by virtue of section 229 of the corporations law he was barred from being involved in the management of a company. He could not legally be involved in the management of a company, yet Mr Symons, through all of this, seemed totally oblivious to the obligations of the law that applied to everybody else. Mr Symons continued to get his export market development grants. Mr Symons continued to get access to Australian embassies to do business on behalf of another government—whether personally or through a company is a matter that has yet to be revealed.

All of these things now require answering by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; all of these things require answering by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). It is wholly unsatisfactory for the Minister to say to this Parliament that he will withhold those documents because they are commercial in confidence or because they relate to some trial in another jurisdiction. We are concerned about this jurisdiction and we are concerned about the very serious problems that seem to have arisen in relation to this export market development grant and possibly others.

There is not a skerrick of doubt that Mr Symons has been involved in some very interesting transactions. There is not a skerrick of doubt that every thinking Australian should wonder where Mr Symons—the $10 millionaire—got sufficient funds to be entitled to a $131,000 export market development grant. Every thinking Australian should expect the Minister to provide those documents to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What allegation are you making? Don't be a coward.
—If Senator Cook does not like it, if he seems totally oblivious to all the things I have said this afternoon—

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order relating to relevance. Senator O'Chee is speaking on leave of the Senate to take note of an answer given by Senator Tate in Question Time yesterday—
—Today; wake up.

—Let me amend that; Question Time today. Senator O'Chee has the leave of the Senate to address that matter. I have not heard him address that matter. All I have heard him address is something to do with a businessman called Symons and his business affairs, which are not related—as I have heard him at some length now—to the honesty or veracity of the answer given by the Minister. If Senator O'Chee has allegations to make, he should make them and then they will be answered. If there is nothing Senator O'Chee can say about the Minister and the answer given—which he now has express leave to talk about—he should sit down.

—I wish to speak to that point of order. My questions related to this businessman, Mr Gregory Bernard Symons; they related to his insolvency; they related to the circumstances surrounding his insolvency; and they related to the fact that these documents revealed that at all material times Mr Symons was an insolvent under investigation. If Senator Cook does not have the intellectual ability to draw the relevance of these facts, I pity him. Everybody else in this chamber can clearly see that, if these documents had been provided yesterday, they would have been the subject of questions during Question Time.

PARA.TAB: Moreover, everybody in this chamber, barring Senator Cook, recognises that Senator Tate has said that this is a matter of ongoing investigation by his Department because he recognises how serious these documents are and how serious the implications are that such matters should not be available for public scrutiny as prescribed in the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the purpose of your heroic speech then?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Order! As I understand it, the main intention of Senator O'Chee's contribution this afternoon has gone to the availability of documents about which he asked the Minister earlier. I think Senator O'Chee has been ranging fairly widely. So long as he maintains the general focus on the question today, I guess that is relevant. I take Senator Cook's point that Senator O'Chee has certainly been making a number of assertions that would be more appropriate at some other time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I thank you for your wisdom. I agree with your comments that I have been speaking to the missing documents. To summarise the matter very simply, these documents should have been on the public record. They were not on the public record. Their absence from the public record in the files of the bankruptcy registry in New South Wales, wittingly or otherwise, served to obscure the fact that Mr Symons has entered into some very interesting business arrangements and seems to have had the benefit of an export market development grant—which no Australian would get—which he seems to have used to pay off his bankruptcy debt.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Cook does not like that, so be it, but they are the facts and that is why these documents are so serious. That is why, given the delays we have had, given the fact that we have had to sit here for an hour and a half before I could move that the Senate take note of this answer, it behoves Senator Evans, as Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, to come clean and produce all of the documents that his Department holds on this matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate:

(1) notes that today, 27 May 1992, is the 25th anniversary of the historic decision by the Australian people, voting in the referendum of 1967, to give the Commonwealth Government power to make laws about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and to include them in the national census;
(2) affirms that 27 May 1967 marked a turning point in the development of the Australian nation and acknowledges that the task commenced in 1967 is an ongoing one;
(3) reaffirms its commitment to the implementation of the Commonwealth's response to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody; and
(4) reaffirms its commitment to the process of reconciliation and calls on all Australians to participate in this process.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate the speech in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: On this day twenty five years ago, Australians voted in a referendum by a 91% margin to support change to the Australian Constitution.
Some would say that such a level of support for constitutional reform would be worth commemorating in itself.
On 27 May 1967, the Australian people gave the Commonwealth Parliament power to make laws with respect to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, and to include them in the national census.

As with many constitutional issues, the technical meaning of these amendments does not fully explain their significance. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and many other Australians see the referendum as a turning point in white and black relations.

The result of the referendum, the 91% endorsement of the proposition that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people were to be regarded as part of the Australian nation, signified the beginning of a new maturity of outlook and understanding of the position of indigenous Australians.

Importantly the passage of the referendum is the very foundation of Commonwealth action in Aboriginal affairs. Without the change to the constitution there would have been no legal or constitutional capacity for the national Parliament to make any laws directed towards Aboriginal people and in current times there would be no Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and no action by the Commonwealth Parliament to initiate the process of reconciliation.
Quoting from the YES case provided to voters twenty-five years ago illustrates the point. In clear terms, the pamphlet states that the constitutional change to Commonwealth powers would
"remove words . . . which many people think are discriminatory against Aborigines
"enable the National Parliament to make laws . . . relating to Aboriginals
and that
"the Commonwealth's object will be to cooperate with the States to ensure that together we act in the best interests of the Aboriginal people of Australia.

I believe it is important for the Senate to reflect on how the overwhelming endorsement of the constitutional change came about, and on the lessons that we can learn as we continue to work towards justice for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians.

I want to give five brief quotes from the debate in the House of Representatives on the Constitutional Alteration (Aboriginals) Bill 1967, as I believe that they raise important issues for us to consider today.

In introducing the Bill, the Prime Minister, Mr Holt recognised the effective public campaign which had been waged by Aboriginal people and their supporters in support of constitutional change. The Prime Minister said:

"A great deal of thought has been given, both inside and outside the Parliament, to the constitutional provisions relating to the Aboriginal people and there has been much activity by Government private members and organisations concerned with the welfare of the Aboriginals. In the light of this activity the government . . . has decided that an amendment to the Constitution should be put to the people.

I wish to take this opportunity to pay a personal tribute to the courage, tenacity and dignity of all those people who worked tirelessly to organise support for the 1967 referendum and who were the driving force for change.
Gough Whitlam, the Leader of the Opposition at the time, speaking of the Australian Labor Party's support for the Bill, said:

"Members of this Parliament will be able for the first time to do something for Aboriginals—Aboriginals representing the greatest pockets of poverty and disease in this country. . . . Hitherto it has been impossible for the Commonwealth to do these things directly itself. Hereafter it will be possible for the Commonwealth to provide the Aboriginals with some of that social capital with which most other Australians are already endowed.
Three other contributions to the debate are especially worth remembering, being contributions from three of the great Parliamentary champions of Aboriginal people.
The then Member for Mackellar, W.C. Wentworth, said:

"Some people say—I think wrongly—that no discrimination is necessary in regard to Aboriginal people. I think that some discrimination is necessary. But I think it should be favourable, not unfavourable. . . . It is not right to say to these people: `We will treat you as we would treat any other Australian.' To do this would submerge and destroy their culture.
The then Member for Wills, Gordon Bryant, said:

"When all is said and done, this is only the first of three steps that will have to be taken. The proposal must first be passed by the Parliament. Then we must get the support of a majority of the people in a majority of the States. Then we as a Parliament and as individual members must take up the challenge on behalf of the Aboriginal people and recover the last 180 years. . . . I hope honourable members will realise that it is not sufficient just to hope and pray that this referendum will be passed. We ought, in honour bound, to campaign with the full vigour with which we campaign to return ourselves to the Parliament.
My final quotation is from what I respectfully consider to be the most powerful and far-sighted contribution to the debate on that occasion, that of the then Member for Fremantle, Kim Beazley senior:

We have the problem that as self-government has advanced in this country, there is no question but that the status of Aboriginals has declined. . . . I believe that the Government of the Commonwealth, which is exposed to the conscience of the world and must answer to the world on these issues, should have this prohibition on legislating on Aboriginal affairs . . . deleted from the Constitution.

"I say that the Australian people must be deliberately responsible. I believe their very security is involved in their being able to say to the world that this community will ensure sane and just race relations.

Mr President, the Bill was read for a third time, and following a division, the unanimous support of the House of Representatives was recorded. Members of Parliament from both sides took up the challenge to join with community organisations and individuals, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal to campaign for a yes vote. The question was put to the people on 27 May 1967 and received the overwhelming endorsement I have referred to.
The essential lessons I want to draw from the debate and the results are these:

—that the combined activity of Members of Parliament and community organisations concerned with Aboriginal people profoundly shaped and influenced the Government's position and that of the Opposition;
—that the issues of justice for indigenous Australians ought to transcend party political pointscoring and that nothing less than our identity as a nation and place in the world is at stake; and

—that the Federal Parliament has a consequent moral and political responsibility to act to redress Aboriginal disadvantage, and to seek to meet Aboriginal aspirations. If we can put aside differences and speak with one voice that leadership of itself sends a powerful message to the wider community.
These lessons are of enormous contemporary importance.
I have said before that the desire to regain cross-party cooperation in Aboriginal affairs was one of my first goals as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.
Indeed, the desire to regain and re-build the overwhelming community support achieved in 1967 was fundamental to the strategy in developing the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act 1991.
Members will recall that that Act achieved unanimous support in both Houses of the Parliament, and that the Act included a powerful preamble:

"That as part of the reconciliation process, the Commonwealth will seek an ongoing national commitment from governments at all levels to cooperate and to coordinate with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission as appropriate to address progressively Aboriginal disadvantage and aspirations in relation to land, housing, law and justice, cultural heritage, education, employment, health, infrastructure, economic development and any other relevant matters in the decade leading to the centenary of Federation, 2001.
Unanimous support was achieved:
—for an Act which requires initiatives to promote a just reconciliation between Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders and the wider community;

—for an Act which requires extensive public education about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander history, culture, past dispossession and continuing disadvantage, and the need to address that disadvantage; and
—for an Act which places firmly on the public policy agenda of this country the question of whether reconciliation would be advanced by a formal document or documents.

All Australians must take up the challenge begun in 1967 and involve themselves directly in promoting a lasting reconciliation to the Australian community. A reconciliation which, as the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act commits us, is based on justice and which has a major focus in local communities across this country.

Over the last few days many Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people have asked the question, "here we are, twenty five years down the track, and what progress have we made in ending Aboriginal disadvantage?

It is not my intention to use this occasion to be an apologist for Governments around Australia for the things which remain to be done. Nor have I any intention of minimising the extent of outstanding injustice.
The Report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody brought home to us just how far we still have to go despite the great distance we have already travelled.

The Commonwealth has given support to 338 of the 339 recommendations of the Royal Commission which establish a practical and detailed agenda for change and the Government welcomes the support given by the Opposition to the Commonwealth response to that Royal Commission. The Government has announced new funding to implement recommendations of the Report and will be announcing further funding within the month to tackle the underlying disadvantages that the Royal Commission found give rise to overrepresentation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in custody.

Importantly, the Government has established a rigorous and thorough regime of reporting and monitoring mechanisms. The regime is centred around monitoring by ATSIC and an annual "state of the nation report" to ensure that progress can be measured and that the response of governments to the Royal Commission will not be allowed to gather dust on a shelf.

In this way we can keep our nation accountable for the implementation of the Royal Commission recommendations and for meeting those Aboriginal aspirations to which the Federal Parliament has unanimously committed itself to in the reconciliation process as a national objective leading to the centenary of Federation in 2001.

Support has now been forthcoming from the States and Territories for the reconciliation process and the Commonwealth will continue to seek to work with the States to give effect to the Royal Commission recommendations.

But the Royal Commission also made it clear how important attitudes of mind and heart are in underpinning the achievement of real social justice. As was the case with the referendum result of 1967, a lasting answer to achieving justice for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people requires a change in the attitudes of all Australians.

From that referendum 25 years ago grew the acknowledgment that Aboriginal people themselves could and should set the agenda, that Aboriginal political, economic and cultural values have their own validity and place within the diversity that is Australian society.

There has been an increasing recognition that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people must be able to make decisions for themselves on their own future as reflected in what is now the cross-party support for the existence of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people themselves can take the credit for changing the way we look at the issues, as they assert their Aboriginality, their right to be heard and to implement their own solutions to the issues they face.

Clearly, there remains much to do. Our speeches today, should not be read by Aboriginal people, by Torres Strait Islander people or by any other Australians as self congratulatory. It is more a matter of acknowledging that first but very necessary step in formalising equitable relationships.

The report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody brought home to us just how far we still have to go, and how important attitudes of mind and heart are in underpinning the achievement of real social justice.

The Prime Minister addressed the inaugural meeting of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation in February. He said that, in his view, the current status of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is awful and he suggested that the Council, and by implication, all of us, need to act in a practical and concrete manner to change the status quo. That, indeed, is the great challenge, and the great opportunity, facing the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, as it sets out on its historic task.

Experience since 1967 has shown us that there is more to social justice than carefully designed programs of assistance. And that is where the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation has an important role. The Council is to be the catalyst in seeking a better knowledge and understanding of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples—their cultures and experiences—so that there can be a fundamental change in attitudes, and therefore in relationships.

When we have achieved that attitudinal change we may have discovered the missing pieces of the jigsaw that prevents us from completing the picture of the Australia that we all want to see and be part of.

As with the efforts that produced the Referendum result of 1967, the lasting answer to the relationships issue rests with people—the ordinary people of this country—and their attitudes toward each other.

There can be no higher objective for our country and its people as we count down to the centenary of our Federation than that we achieve a just reconciliation between the wider community and the original inhabitants, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of this country, the first Australians.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—An informal arrangement has been made to limit the debate to one hour. The Government, the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and Senator Chamarette will be limited to 15 minutes each. With the concurrence of the Senate, I will ask the Clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1967 referendum is often referred to as a landmark in Aboriginal affairs. The 25 years since then represents a large chunk of this country's history since European settlement—nearly one-eighth. From the view of this land's indigenous people, that 25 years is just a blip in the tens of thousands of years of their history on this continent. From that perspective of time, the enormous changes and upheavals which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have had to endure are even more tumultuous than would at first appear.

PARA.TAB: The 1967 referendum is significant for the fact that it achieved easily the greatest level of agreement amongst Australians with 91 per cent of people voting yes to enable Aboriginal people to be counted as Australians and to enable the Commonwealth Government to make laws for Aboriginal people throughout the country.

In the 25 years since the referendum result there have been many more changes and developments. There have been concerted and generally well-intentioned efforts to redress some of the wrongs perpetrated on the indigenous people. As we all know, not all these efforts have met with success. In recent times the many failures and injustices which have been enacted by governments of this nation have been widely described and acknowledged in this Parliament: for example, at the time of the establishment of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and the bringing down of the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, as well as the more recent governmental responses to those recommendations.

However, it is clearly wrong to suggest that 1967 marked the end of discrimination against Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It is not as though suddenly and magically after 1967 everything was righted and it was all plain sailing.For a start, the horrendous act of removing Aboriginal children from their families continued. So too did the incredible restrictions which were placed on the lives of Aboriginal people living on reserves. The restrictive laws and practices placed over the lives of those people still have not been fully removed today. The legacy of those acts, and the many other brutal and appalling acts which went hand in hand with the colonisation of this land and the dispossession of its indigenous people, is still very much with us today and is even more strongly present in the collective and individual consciousness of this land's indigenous people.

Stacked up against this legacy of injustice, the 1967 referendum is a very small act of redress. Nonetheless, it is a powerful symbol. The occasion of the twenty-fifth anniversary is perhaps a good time to acknowledge some of the positive achievements that have occurred; but in making the acknowledgment I stress that I do not see it as some sort of ultimate checklist of how well we have done. I see these things as simply beginnings. We have seen the development of Aboriginal legal services, beginning in Redfern in 1970; Aboriginal health and medical services, starting again in Redfern in 1971; and land rights legislation in the Northern Territory in 1976, still seen by many of us as the best such legislation in this country. We have seen laws that go some way, although often not far enough, towards protecting sacred sites and significant areas and items that are part of the indigenous people's traditional heritage. We have seen the handing back of Uluru and Katherine Gorge to their traditional owners in 1985 and 1989 respectively. These actions were also a powerful symbol of correcting past dispossession and injustice. In 1990 we saw the establishment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, which was a significant move, I believe, towards enabling the goal of self-determination to be more achievable. The Australian Democrats believe that ATSIC is a body which must be supported and given the opportunity to work.

Another positive step in recent years has been a significant development of a number of indigenous media outlets. Imparja Television, which began transmissions in 1988 from Alice Springs, is perhaps the most well known of these. I am pleased to note that my home city, Brisbane, will soon see the Brisbane Indigenous Media Association being able to operate with its own licence. As well as the electronic media, magazines and papers such as the Koori Mail and Land Rights News are also in evidence. These media outlets provide a much needed voice for indigenous people. We are able to see the way in which they have been treated by mainstream media. These are not solutions; these are simply small steps.

Last year saw the establishment of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, a body of which I am proud to be a member. It has the task of rekindling the spirit of the 1967 referendum and of getting the whole of Australia to acknowledge the special position of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the history of this land. It is a history which is so ancient as to make the last 25 years seem a blink of the eye, but it is also a history which is still under threat.

Much of the ancient indigenous culture of this land has already gone forever, destroyed in the space of just 200 years, and sometimes far more quickly than that; yet the culture which remains—and I think we need to be reminded of it—is still a vibrant and living one. The need for committed action to recognise its worth and importance and to nurture its continuing development could not be more urgent.

This motion calls on the Senate to reaffirm its commitment to the process of reconciliation, and the Democrats wholeheartedly endorse and support that call. We similarly endorse the motion's call to all Australians to participate in this process. The few meetings the Council has had and the involvement of people and groups such as Mr Rick Farley from the Farmers Federation and Mr Ian Spicer from the Confederation of Australian Industry indicate the broad nature of community involvement in the reconciliation process.

This motion also calls on the Senate to reaffirm its commitment to the implementation of the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. The Commonwealth's response and the response of State and Territory governments to these recommendations is something which we in the Senate have not yet had the opportunity to properly debate. The State governments have made a lot of noise about supporting the recommendations and an equal amount of noise about how they will not be able to pay for them. It is to be hoped that we can find some solution to the impasse.

The Premier of my own State of Queensland, Mr Goss, has been particularly vocal in this regard, but his Government has been particularly slow in actually implementing many of the recommendations. This was tragically emphasised by the occurrence of yet another death of an Aboriginal woman in a watchhouse in Brisbane this week. If Queensland Government action had been less slow in occurring, this woman would not have been in a watchhouse; she would have been taken to a facility more appropriate for someone in her condition.

It was around the time of the 1967 referendum that interest in Aboriginal culture began to develop. It is obvious, though not yet widely recognised, that indigenous cultures are integral to an Australian identity. The notion of a national identity is something which has gained some attention of late, particularly because of Prime Minister Keating's remarks on the flag and republicanism. I would have liked to have seen him extend his remarks to make clear that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and their traditions, culture and heritage have a major part to play in the formation and composition of a true Australian identity.

I was interested to note in a speech made recently by the Chairperson of ATSIC, Lois O'Donoghue, to commemorate the 1967 referendum that she referred to an item which listed the things that Americans most associated with Australia. The top five items included Aborigines, koalas, kangaroos and the Great Barrier Reef. This is a simple example of how integral Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are to the very nature of Australia. Sometimes we use this culture in an exploitative way, particularly when we pick and choose to suit our own tourism demands.

The culture of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is one which we are starting to recognise has a value for all Australians. So, too, are we acknowledging its importance. As we tackle global environmental issues, we take time to reflect upon the approaches taken by those who lived in harmony with this land for so many years. We need to consider those approaches. We need to look anew for the lessons contained therein. The 1967 referendum is often seen as the time when Aboriginal people were finally acknowledged as being part of the Australian nation. I think that is far too generous an interpretation to place upon the significance of the 1967 referendum.

I would like to make a special mention of the role of Torres Strait Islander people. Torres Strait Islanders are still often seen as being indistinguishable from Aboriginal people and the reality of their own distinct culture and history is often overlooked. As a minority within a minority, being a group whose homeland is so far from where 99 per cent of Australians live, Torres Strait Islanders often find their culture and their needs ignored. Whilst this is a small group of people, their role in the future of this nation should not be overlooked.

The 1967 referendum signalled a decision by the people of Australia to make changes to the Constitution of Australia. As we move towards 2001, consideration is being given by many people to what changes should be made to our Constitution to make it more appropriate and more relevant to our nation as it enters the twenty-first century. The place of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in our nation must be a very important part of that consideration.

The actions of those who came to this land after 1788 have caused indescribable suffering and destruction. The actions of those people must now be focused on working in conjunction with indigenous people to redress these wrongs. Thus 1967 was important. It was a symbol. We have seen many steps taken since then, steps which I regard as small steps. We still have an awfully long way to go, but I still acknowledge the role of 1967 in the contemporary history of the last few decades of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition wholeheartedly supports the motion that is before the Senate today and, as I understand it, also debated in the House of Representatives. It is a motion which, on the twenty-fifth anniversary of this historic decision by the Australian people in a referendum, deserves the support of every member of parliament. I believe that today, with the adoption of this motion by both Houses, it will have the support of every member of the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: We commemorate a milestone of 25 years since one of the most crucial decisions that affected the Aboriginal people of Australia, some one per cent of our total Australian community. That one per cent had for 180 years been shut out of their own country. By the decision of the Australian people, 91 per cent of them voting in favour of the referendum to allow the Commonwealth to make laws for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, it was possible for the Commonwealth, by making laws and by adopting programs relating to health, housing, education and employment, to take the first substantial initiatives that have led to some progress in the development of the Aboriginal communities of Australia. It was a historic decision. That is the first part of this motion that we are adopting today.

The second part of the motion notes that this is a task which has begun and a task which is ongoing. I particularly support those remarks of politicians and members of the community who today are calling for all Australians to share in the task of seeing the development of the Aboriginal people. It is a matter of hearts and minds, not just a matter of laws and programs. It is a matter for all the Australian people—all 17 million of them—and not just for those politicians here in Canberra or in the States. In this ongoing task, there is every genuine, positive approach by the Liberal and National parties.

The third part of the motion reaffirms our commitment to the implementation of the Commonwealth's response to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. It has already been acknowledged in the speech of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Robert Tickner, in the House of Representatives today that the Opposition has been involved all along. In the past several years it has been involved in the conduct of the Royal Commission, especially in the assessment of the Royal Commission's findings. A genuinely bipartisan approach has been taken in this Parliament, with the Labor Party and the Liberal and National parties responding positively to the Commission's findings. The Minister, Mr Tickner, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government welcomes the support given by the Opposition to the Commonwealth response to that Royal Commission.

PARA.TAB: The fourth and final part of the motion reaffirms our commitment to the process of reconciliation and calls on all Australians to participate in that process. Again, wholeheartedly on behalf of the Liberal and National parties, I make that commitment in the Senate today.

It should not be overlooked that the initiative for this important referendum was taken by a Liberal-National Party Government. The Holt Government of 1967 initiated the debate and the passing of law in the Parliament that made the referendum possible. That initiative of the Liberal and National parties was fully supported by the Labor Party. At the time, Prime Minister Holt said:

SPEECH.PARA: A great deal of thought has been given, both inside and outside the Parliament, to the constitutional provisions relating to the Aboriginal people and there has been much activity by Government private members and organisations concerned with the welfare of the Aboriginals. In the light of this activity the Government . . . has decided that an amendment to the Constitution should be put to the people.

Shortly thereafter, under the Liberal Prime Minister Mr Gorton, the very first Minister responsible for the office of Aboriginal Affairs was appointed—Bill Wentworth, whom I still count as a friend and who was here earlier this month in the return of former members of parliament on Parliament Day.
