As the first Minister for Aboriginal Affairs he began a tradition of close, genuine sharing of ideas by both sides of Parliament, both in the House of Representatives and the Senate, that was continued under Minister Bryant who, in the Whitlam Government, set up the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. He was followed thereafter by a number of Ministers.

PARA.TAB: Let me recall part of that family, that community of politicians, in which I have shared for these 15 years: Senator Chaney, Senator Peter Baume, my good friend Ian Wilson from South Australia, Senator Alan Missen and especially—and I underline it—Senator Neville Bonner. Neville Bonner's portrait hangs proudly in this new Parliament House. As a Liberal senator, he was a party to all of the discussions about Aboriginal affairs and decisions, certainly during the Fraser Government period, and thereafter in the whole period of his service here in this Parliament as the first elected Aboriginal member of any parliament. He remains a close friend, as do the others I have mentioned.

I will not only mention those on my own side. I mention Susan Ryan, a Labor senator who became a Minister. She was involved with us in this chamber in the debates about Aboriginal affairs in my first five years here in the Senate. I also mention Mrs Kathy Sullivan, Mr Clyde Holding and Senator Reynolds. There are so many in this family who have shared ideas about what we can do in the Parliament to improve the environment of the Aboriginal people. You, Mr Acting Deputy President, have served on the council of the Institute of Aboriginal Studies, as I have for some five years. We in this community have all brought forward ideas.

The two people I particularly want to mention are the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Robert Tickner, and the shadow Minister, my colleague Dr Michael Wooldridge. The responses of these two gentlemen in the House of Representatives to the Royal Commission on Aboriginal Deaths in Custody were among the inspiring speeches of this Parliament. I endorse fully what was said by my colleague Michael Wooldridge. I find matters of only small difference with my good friend Robert Tickner.

I mention this because that one per cent of Australians who have been in contact with us these last 25 years, the Aboriginal people of Australia, have, through their dialogue with us and through our attempts to respond to them, created a community of parliamentarians who are in fact in a family together. That has perhaps been a little less distinct in the past few years because of the setting up of the successor to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in that we now have an independent and fully Aboriginal institute that, through its council, is to look after the affairs of and initiatives from the Commonwealth in Aboriginal affairs. That family began with the Liberal and National parties and it has continued with the Labor Party in government. It went again with the Liberal Fraser Government. All of us have succeeded and all of us have failed. None of us can say that we have made such progress that we can be satisfied.

In 1967 I was an undergraduate at the University of Adelaide and one of the activists who went out to try to get that 91 per cent support from the Australian people. At the time, I was the Director of the Aboriginal scholarship scheme at the university. The one person I was particularly tutoring on a weekly basis was Ken Wanganeen. Unfortunately, Ken died last year. I remember teaching him mathematics. Ken, a few years younger than I, and at school at the time, went on to become a director of the Aboriginal affairs department in at least one State. He was a most senior and respected Aboriginal leader in employment matters and in a wide range of Aboriginal initiatives. It was with real sadness that I learned that he died last year.

At that time in 1967, Charles Perkins became the first Aboriginal undergraduate. I worked with Charles Perkins at that time and I have counted him as a friend ever since. I have disagreed with many of his extreme statements but I have understood them and I still count him as a friend. I think that, overall, his contribution has been very positive for his people.

I especially wanted to remark on my friendship with Lois O'Donoghue throughout the whole of my time here in the Senate. She is now the leading Aboriginal decision maker in Australia. She does that in consultation with representatives of all the Aboriginal people of Australia. I remember when Lois was a nurse who used to look after the whole of the Pitjantjatjara community, single-handed, at the back of a truck. She used to wander from one community to the other. She was the only means of medical support to all of those people.

In my first 10 years here in the Parliament, I visited the Pitjantjatjara people regularly each year and I would stay at Ernabella, Amata, Pipalyatjara, Mimili, Fregon and Indulkana. In all those places now there are clinics. There is even the beginnings of a hospital at Ernabella. There is now access to the Royal Flying Doctor Service. There is a total hospital facility at Alice Springs, with outstation elements. What now costs millions of dollars and involves dozens of medically trained people, Lois used to undertake by herself.

One of the ironies is that I am not yet convinced that the people of the Pitjantjatjara are much healthier than they were when Lois was in charge and on her own. So many new factors undermining health have occurred in the past 10 years that we still have a most desperate health problem amongst Aboriginal communities in their traditional lands and even in the cities. It is still the case that the Aboriginal community in Australia is one of the most poorly served with health outcomes. Nevertheless, there has been progress. I note the article on the front page of today's Australian which shows the comparison between two Aborigines, 25 years apart in age. This indicates the kind of direction in which we are heading. We are seeing so many more young professional Aborigines. I seek leave to incorporate another article—one from today's Canberra Times—about this twenty-fifth anniversary.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: 1967-1992: Little gain by Aborigines

PARA.TAB: Twenty-five years ago today, an overwhelming majority of Australians voted in a referendum to give the Commonwealth Government power to legislate over Aboriginal affairs. Until then, Aboriginal policy, regarded as a welfare function, was the province of the states, although the Commonwealth had direct responsibilities in the Northern Territory. The referendum result reflected a clear view by most Australians that something more—and something better—had to be done; that the paltry efforts until that time had been a national and an international embarrassment. By almost any standard of well-being—health, education, employment, housing or socio-economic status—Aborigines were the worst-off of all Australians. They were only beginning to emerge from formal legal discriminations. Underfunded paternalistic rule—which tended to measure Aboriginal "advancement" in terms of complete assimilation into white society and abandonment of Aboriginal culture and traditions—coupled with decades of remoteness, public indifference and hostility, at last was overtaken by a belief on the part of most Australians that a prosperous and civilised society should, and could, do more.

Twenty-five years later, the situation in Aboriginal affairs remains a national and international embarrassment. Similar social and economic indices would show, at best, that Aborigines still lagged behind other Australians to at least the same extent; in many key areas, particularly health, there has been little improvement at all.

The problem now, however, is not primarily one of funds; nor, over most of the intervening period, has it been one of broad goodwill on the part of government or most Australians. More than $25 billion, in today's value, has been spent on programs specifically focused on Aboriginal advancement. A considerable bureaucracy was established, both at government level and in Aboriginal communities. Some of the investment has produced good results: in general terms, for example, Aborigines are now better housed, even if housing for too many Aborigines is still inadequate. Even acknowledging that progress takes time and that some programs, in education, say, yield results only after years of effort, it is clear that more of the same is not necessarily going to produce much better results. It is also doubtful how much longer the political will exists to maintain current levels of funding.

The real question is whether—assuming the will exists—more of the same is capable of producing necessary changes. There are increasing arguments that it is not. Two of the primary enemies of change—the collectivisation of Aborigines, and the bureaucratisation of their affairs—are increasing, and widening the gulf between Aborigines and other Australians. Aborigines are becoming increasingly dependent on government. That the form of government has a facade of Aboriginal control cannot mask the pauperisation and lack of effective service-delivery involved.

TOO FEW funds are devoted to creating capital that will enhance the capacity of Aborigines, individually or corporately, to make their own way; too much is spent creating local economies—remote from the wider community—based on everyone taking in each other's washing. Aboriginal initiative is still seriously stifled, far too much Aboriginal energy remains focused on notions that real change depends primarily on non-Aborigines doing something—whether changing the law or changing attitudes—rather than seizing the hour and the opportunities themselves. Aboriginal Australians, for many reasons, have a claim on the conscience of other Australians. But liberation from their disadvantage depends on their determination.

Twenty-five years ago most Australians believed that government—the Commonwealth Government in particular—ought to do more for Aborigines. It took time for that "more" to occur but, in the intervening period, most of the limits of what government could do have been reached. Aborigines are in a far better position in 1992 to take a very critical look at where the energy, resources and expenditures of the past 25 years have gone, what has been achieved and what has failed. The political will to help Aborigines still exists, though it has to some extent been diluted by disappointment. Whether by May 27, 2017—50 years after the referendum—Aboriginal Australians still stand out for disadvantage to the extent they did in 1967 and 1992 depends more on the way they redirect their energies over the next 25 years than on their building on the precarious base constructed over the past 25.

SPEECH.PARA: There are still enormous tragedies in the Aboriginal community in Australia, almost on a weekly basis. I note the death of Kingsley Dixon of South Australia. His death was one of the first Aboriginal deaths in custody that was investigated by the Royal Commission. I remember the enormous sadness that we felt at the death of this young man. I attended his funeral. Only a matter of a few weeks ago, his mother also took her life in their family home. I regard it as a terrible loss, and so too does her community. These tragedies continue day by day, week by week, and with all of our efforts, we still have not enabled the Aboriginal people to free themselves to a level of progress which would enable them to be a part of the full Australian community that we would wish. We want to press on to that now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today commemorates the twenty-fifth anniversary of the day white Australians voted overwhelmingly in support of Aboriginal rights. It serves as an opportunity to reflect on how far we have come or not come in the past 25 years. At a ceremony outside the old Parliament House building at the Aboriginal Embassy today, the Aboriginal flag was at half mast to mourn the latest death in custody of a woman in Brisbane who lost her life because of the failure of our society to meet her needs and those of her people. I think she also symbolises the death of Mrs Dixon whom Senator Teague has just mentioned. Those women stand as a symbol of the tragedy that white society has brought upon Aboriginal people over the past 200 years.

PARA.TAB: Mr Kevin Gilbert spoke movingly at that ceremony of the failure to give Aboriginal people their sovereign rights and true citizenship. He pointed out that the desperate health problems suffered by his people, the absence of national land rights, the deplorable health and living conditions and the continuing saga of over-imprisonment and deaths in custody prevent any words of reconciliation being believed by Aboriginal people. Distress flares were released during this ceremony as a symbol to Australia and to the international community of the distressing situation within this country whose first citizens, the Aboriginal people, are still experiencing the conditions of non-citizens.

There is no room for self-congratulation here as we look at the past 25 years. Neither can we displace the responsibility for Aboriginal well-being onto ATSIC, which itself is facing grave problems in trying to redress the injustice that has been suffered. In Western Australia, the ATSIC elections have been declared invalid and concern has been expressed that Aboriginal leaders employed in government agencies which had wasted millions of dollars have lost touch with grassroots Aboriginal people. Mr Collard, the Vice-Chairman of the Aboriginal Medical Service, was quoted in the West Australian newspaper of Monday 18 May as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: What we need is direct negotiation between grassroots Aborigines and the Government. Organisations like ATSIC no matter how well meaning, do not deliver change. We have to work from the grassroots up, not the political system down.

So while I agree with all that has been said by previous speakers, and while I, as a senator for the Greens, support the motion wholeheartedly, it is with deep sorrow that I recognise how little we have been able to achieve for Aboriginal people through our political system.

PARA.TAB: The problem of racism and racist-based violence is another indication of how far we still need to go in addressing true equality and justice for Aboriginal people in our community. The Louis St John Johnson trust has been set up in Western Australia and throughout Australia to expose the problem of racist violence, particularly in Western Australia. It challenges us to address the inherent racism within Australian society.

I would like to share with honourable senators the story of this trust and how it came about. One Saturday morning in January 1992 at about 3 a.m., 19-year-old Louis Johnson was walking home along a road in the quiet middle-class Perth suburb of North Beach. It was his birthday and he had been at a party. He stopped to lie down on the grass verge for a while. Some time later a car containing five other youths completely unknown to him pulled up alongside. The three boys and two girls got out of the car and Louis was viciously bashed by two of them while the others watched. He was then left lying beside the road. Moments later some of the youths returned in the car and deliberately ran over him at high speed. The five white youths then returned to observe their victim. The driver said to the group, `I have got him. I am glad I got the black sod'.

Louis lay beside North Beach Road with massive internal injuries and a shattered pelvis until a passing cyclist spotted him at around 7 a.m. and called for an ambulance. Waiting for the ambulance, Louis was still conscious and lucid enough to talk to the cyclist who, as a lay person, had formed the view that Louis was seriously ill.

Tragic ironies seem to attach themselves to this horrific affair. Louis's middle name was St John. He was a fully paid up subscriber to the St John's Ambulance fund. But, according to the cyclist, the ambulance attendants simply assumed, without any examination, that Louis had been sniffing petrol. Instead of taking him to hospital, they took him home, telling his younger sister that he was intoxicated, that it was not a hospital case and that he should sleep it off in bed. Later that morning the Johnsons found their son in bed. It was obvious that he was seriously injured and they called a second ambulance. Louis died before it arrived. His grieving father, Bill, described his son as dying with `dignity, courage and stoicism'.

In a taped confession to police after being arrested some days later, the driver of the car claimed that it had not been his intention to kill Louis, only to break his legs. Why had he done it? He answered openly, `Because he was black'. He pleaded guilty and was sentenced to seven years and nine months in prison. Another youth was awaiting trial at the time this material was written. He has pleaded not guilty to the charge of murder.

When the sinister circumstances became established, this killing should have attracted prominent media attention, given the fact that, according to a concurrent media campaign, Perth was in the grip of a spiralling youth crime rampage. Only nine days earlier, on Boxing Day, youths had stolen a car and, while under high speed pursuit by police, had collided with another car, killing a pregnant mother and her son. This was the latest of about a dozen tragic deaths during such high speed car chases in little over a year and it intensified the media and public campaign for a police and legislative crackdown on juvenile crime.

But somehow, Louis Johnson never achieved the status of an emblematic `victim of youth crime' in the way the previous fatalities did. With the sole exception of the weekly Sunday Times some two months after the killing, his case was not taken up by the media with equal fervour, despite being in some ways even more horrifying than those of car chase victims. For instance, where those deaths were accidental, Louis's assailants attacked him with premeditated and repeated violence. Moreover, Louis was killed because he was Aboriginal, and for no other reason. Thus, in Western Australia enormous emotional values were attached to accidental killings but they did not seem to apply to the cold-blooded racist murder of an innocent Aboriginal man.

The relative lack of media interest in the killing of Louis Johnson raises serious questions about the entire structure of news reporting in Perth and about the role of the media in shaping public attitudes towards crime, aboriginality and justice. The muted media response to Louis Johnson's murder was nowhere so quiet as on Perth's high rating morning radio program The Sattler File. It was not mentioned. This silence is noteworthy as Howard Sattler has established himself as the unchallenged champion of previous victims of juvenile crime. He used his show to mobilise a gathering of up to 20,000 people at Parliament House in August 1991 to demand stiffer gaol sentences for juvenile offenders—the so-called Rally for Justice. It was Howard Sattler who kicked off this crusade in April 1990 with a now notorious pronouncement on air about the deaths of three Aboriginal youths in a high-speed police chase. Sattler said:

SPEECH.PARA: I say good riddance to bad rubbish, that's three less car thieves, I think they're dead and I think that's good.
I might add that although criticisms have been made to the Australian Journalists Association and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, this matter has not been satisfactorily redressed.

PARA.TAB: Sattler went on to convert his program into one of the most effective public policy lobbies ever seen in Perth, with daily stolen car reports, interviews with victims of crime and promotions for the Rally for Justice. Balanced journalism got short shrift as Sattler deftly classified as `protectors of criminals' anyone who suggested that locking kids in gaol was not the best solution to juvenile offending. The do-gooder social workers, profiteering lawyers and lenient judges, the heads in the sand academics, the self-promoting Human Rights Commissioner, fringe groups and the Aboriginal Legal Service were given those adjectives by Saddler in order to discredit their genuine concerns about what was happening in Western Australia.

I have been quoting from a document called Gambling on the First Race, Racism and Talk-Back Radio—6PR, the TAB and the WA Government. It has been produced by the Centre for Research in Culture and Communication. At this point in my comments, I seek leave to table the document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the summary of this report and the recommendations for action.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: By Steve Mickler
Report Summary
The evidence assembled in this Report shows that:

PARA.TAB: The Sattler File and Radio 6PR are inciting racial hostility towards Aboriginal citizens in Western Australia.
The Sattler File promotes the most bigoted ideas about Aboriginal cultural heritage to the public.

The Sattler File broadcasts anti-Aboriginal jokes in which the Aboriginal community is not expected to join, and by which Aboriginal people are deeply offended. These jokes reinforce stereotypes of Aboriginal people that underpin racist and discriminatory treatment of them, in some cases with deadly consequences.

Racist meanings result from The Sattler File, even when individual utterances do not fall within ABT definitions of `gratuitous vilification'. This is because, like any media program, each edition of The Sattler File constitutes a single unity which includes not only words spoken, but also editorial strategies, turn-taking, tone of voice, and framing of the subject matter.

`Public opinion' all too easily becomes what Howard Sattler says it is. He represents the views of those callers who agree with him as reflecting public opinion in general. In fact, Sattler is manufacturing `public opinion' out of a tiny section of a non-representative audience.

It is virtually impossible to put a point of view on The Sattler File contrary to Sattler's in relation to Aboriginal issues. Callers who succeed in getting on air with such views are routinely interrupted, contradicted, or treated with disrespect by Howard Sattler—and framed as being outside `public opinion.'
The only person to exercise freedom of speech on The Sattler File is Howard Sattler.

Media regulatory authorities, most importantly the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, have consistently failed to find breaches of program standards with respect to complaints by Aboriginal people about The Sattler File.
Politicians have failed to respond to pressure from Aboriginal individuals and organisations, and from other citizens, to act against racist broadcasts.

The WA Government and State politicians continue to support The Sattler File by their ready availability for interviews, despite knowing that this program is offensive to Aboriginal people. As a result they are complicit with and appear to support the positions taken in this program.

The State Government, which is directly linked with 6PR through the TAB's ownership of the station, has made no visible effort to stop its racist practices despite many complaints by Aboriginal citizens and others over many years.

Advertisers actively tolerate 6PR's racism by sponsoring The Sattler File. This report shows advertising and editorialising to be conflated, by the practice of having sponsorship messages read on-air by Sattler himself.

Recurring acts of racist violence against Aboriginal citizens do not elicit the same public concern from the State Government as afforded `victims of juvenile crime'. The Police Department and the Police Minister do not mount public initiatives to curb racist violence in the way that they have done in relation to juvenile crime.

Media coverage of racist murders and racially-motivated attacks tends to treat them as `isolated incidents.' They are rarely given lead story status and never integrated into an overall picture which shows the continuing genocidal pressure against Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: 1.The WA Government must either relinquish its stake in Radio 6PR through the TAB, or ensure that the station institutes and maintains a non-racist, non-discriminatory broadcasting policy.

2.Media regulatory bodies, specifically the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, must recognise that current regulations on program standards are inadequate. They seek to pinpoint specific racist words, but they fail to regulate against overall program structures and editorial practices which amount to `gratuitous vilification'—broadcasters who know how to frame issues and control callers can flout the regulations with impunity.
3.Advertisers on 6PR must consider their complicity with a radio station whose reputation for racism makes it deeply offensive to a large proportion of the WA public.

4. 6PR itself has a responsibility to clean up its act and recognise once and for all that Aboriginal people are part of the same community and deserving of the same respect as everybody else in this State.

TALK.START.PARA: —These issues are not being addressed in any other context that I am aware of. The report addresses the problem of racist violence. We have seen the way in which radio talkback has, in one instance, promoted racism within a community. It has also led to a government knee-jerk response in providing juvenile justice legislation which I believe is rightly considered by the Federal Government to be in breach of international human rights treaties.

PARA.TAB: We have not come very far in 25 years if we can sanction broadcasting which promotes racism and condones values that violate Australia's participation in the international treaties of human rights. It is an indictment of the 200 years of European occupation of this country that its original inhabitants who have thousands of years in this land, only 25 years ago, received minimal recognition.We still have not corrected the historical lie at the base of Australian common law—the lie of terra nullius, empty land, which Captain Cook proclaimed on landing in New South Wales. Until that lie is acknowledged and the issue of national land rights is addressed, there can be no future for reconciliation.

We have a responsibility to address racism and injustice. We have a responsibility to address the lie on which our country has been based. We also have much to gain from addressing these problems. We are unaware of the spiritual contribution of Aboriginal people because of our inability to accept them within the full ambit of our society. We have much to gain from the equality and spiritual recognition of Aboriginal people. Their respect for the land and their care for family and community have much to teach us.

I would like to conclude by referring to a symbol of Aboriginal spirituality and of how much we have to gain: the Aboriginal flag that was hung at half-mast today and which I believe was a fitting symbol and ceremony to mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of enfranchisement.The Aboriginal flag is divided horizontally into equal halves of black at the top and red at the bottom with a yellow circle at the centre. The black symbolises Aboriginal people and the yellow is the sun, the constant giver and renewer of life. Red depicts the earth; it also represents ochre which is used by Aboriginal people in their religious ceremonies.

The flag was first flown at Victoria Square, Adelaide on National Aborigines Day on 12 July 1971 and was later used at the tent embassy in Canberra in 1972. Today the flag has been adopted by all Aboriginal groups and is flown or displayed permanently at Aboriginal centres throughout Australia.

At the ceremony today there was another flag, which was a contribution by a South Australian group. It was a design which incorporated both the Aboriginal flag colours and the Southern Cross. While the spirit underlying the design is commendable, it exposes the sad reality of how far we are from such a point. This deep significance deserves to be considered. There can be no genuine talk of reconciliation until the day the Aboriginal flag has equal status on our flagpole with the Union Jack. It would have been a fitting symbol for today to share our flagpole with the Aboriginal flag. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today a very historic anniversary, the twenty-fifth anniversary of a most significant change to the Australian Constitution. It is important to note that I very much regret that the contributions that have been made here in this place and, I am sure, in the other place could not have been longer and that more people could not have participated.Certainly my colleagues have made a very important contribution in this place this afternoon. I acknowledge the contribution by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) and equally that of the Opposition spokesperson, Michael Wooldridge, in the other place this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: It is clear that the 1967 referendum was a major turning point in Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal relations in this country. In the time that I have this afternoon I would like to speak about the past, briefly about the present but, more importantly, about the future.

Like a number of my colleagues—and Senator Teague has spoken of his involvement in the 1967 referendum campaign—I too was involved in the referendum campaign in North Queensland. In North Queensland in 1967, as I am sure many honourable senators will understand, I had no concept of a 91 per cent acceptance of that constitutional change. It was a major victory. It was a very pleasant surprise to us when that vote was announced from around the nation.

It is important, however, to acknowledge the work of the people who were involved so closely in the pioneering work amongst Aboriginal and Islander people at that time in 1967. People like Faith Bandler, John Newfong, Joe McGuiness, Charles Perkins and Pat O'Shane—names that then did not mean anything very much to anybody, I am sure they will agree, but names that have become very significant names in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community over the years.

After the referendum in North Queensland a number of us got together and said, `Really, what is needed now is some follow-up to the referendum'. We were involved in a major conference that was called, `We the Australians, what is to follow the referendum?' At the time some of us thought the name was a little quaint and that perhaps it did not go all the way to emphasising the crucial significance of the referendum passing, but we wanted to ensure that governments of whatever political persuasion did actually act on that very historic reform.

Our conference was addressed by people like Dr Colin Tatz, Professor Charles Rowley, Joe McGuiness and Faith Bandler. At that time, again, in North Queensland it was regarded as a somewhat sinister conference. It was a conference that did not have the support of many people in the community. It did not have the support of the National Party Government of the day, but it was an important conference for our community. I believe that it was an important conference in terms of the participation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and other Australians who, for the first time, came together—in that part of the world anyway—for a conference to debate the issues and to look at the future agenda.So I am very happy to be in a position to now speak in this debate 25 years later and acknowledge the work of those people 25 years ago.

I would like to talk briefly about the present and then move on to what does need to be achieved in the future.In talking about the present it is important to acknowledge that, while the passing of that referendum was historic, while there have been so many changes in social policy, in social attitudes and in opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, there is certainly no cause for what I would call celebration.

It is appropriate to commemorate and to mark this significant milestone, but despite all the best efforts—and Senator Teague spoke about Ministers and governments—all have succeeded and all have failed in some respects. That is a tragedy for all Australians in that yes, there have been tremendous social reforms; yes, there has been good intent on behalf of governments and Ministers; and yes, a great deal has been achieved; but we are only a short way down the track with regard to fundamental change in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander policy in this country.

I think that we will have an opportunity to understand just how far we have yet to go down that path of changing attitudes if we look at some of the attitudes that are available through opinion polling about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Australia in 1991. Whereas in 1967 we were able to achieve that magnificent 91 per cent support, now, when we look at some of the statistics, there is some cause for concern, but equally some cause for optimism. For example, with regard to the question, `Should Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders take more responsibility for their own lives?' there was an overwhelming 96 per cent yes vote, according to the opinion poll. But in the same opinion poll, when asked, `What about self-government for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people?' the vote was only 35 per cent.

Clearly, there is a very real double standard here. On the one hand the Australian community is very quick to blame Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, and tell them that they should get out and do things in the way that other Australians do. On the other hand, when we say in the next breath, `What about land rights? What about self-government? What about autonomy?' immediately the answer is `Oh no, we don't mean that. We mean that Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders should do more, but we are not prepared to give them the autonomy with which to do so'. That is a fundamental conflict that has to be resolved.

It is interesting, on a more optimistic note, however, that in regard to questions relating to strengthening Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island culture, and more funds being made available for doing so with regard to education and employment training, the statistics go up into the 70s and the 80s: 88 per cent for strengthening culture; 76 per cent for special education programs; and 78 per cent for special employment programs. However, when it comes to Australians who would support a formal recognition that Australian Aborigines and Islanders were the first Australians in terms of being here before colonisation—a treaty or some other form of document, declaration, compact; the name does not matter—then only 55 per cent support such a treaty.

Clearly, I come very much to the future. We can mark the anniversary today with this admirable motion, we reaffirm our previous commitments, we emphasise the work that needs to be done on the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, but I believe that the most significant work that has yet to be done is the speeding up of a change of attitude in Australia. We do not have another 25 years, frankly. We have had 25 years to get to where we are today. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people have been extremely patient, but I have to say to honourable senators without being alarmist, I hope, that I just wonder how long their patience will last.

I think I said something similar in a debate leading up to the Bicentenary in 1988. I say again, in the lead up to 1993 as International Year of Indigenous People, that as the Government, the Opposition and the Australian community, we all have a responsibility to speed up that attitude change and that commitment to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people.

I was interested to read what Lois O'Donoghue, the Chairperson of ATSIC, said in her final remarks at the National Press Club. She spoke very clearly about what she and ATSIC expect in terms of the future. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: Any new constitution had to abandon the doctrine of terra nullius—
and Senator Chamarette has touched on this. She said:

. . . that assumption that Australia was unoccupied in 1788, and recognise Aborigines as an essential part of the popular sovereignty from which the new document would derive its authority. This recognition would not threaten the wider population. It would be used as partnership and reconciliation.

That, of course, brings me to those words that frighten many politicians—not the politicians, I am sure, who have spoken today—such as `sovereignty', `self-government' and `autonomy'. Even `national land rights' terrifies some politicians in all parts of this chamber and the other place.

PARA.TAB: I believe that we have to come to terms, first of all, with our history. As has been said, terra nullius is the ultimate historic lie. This is acknowledged in our own current Year Book Australia. Our own current Year Book states quite clearly that Aborigines have lived in Australia for at least 40,000 years, and that before European settlement Aborigines left no written records, so deduction is from archaeological and anthropological evidence. It details more recent research suggesting that the length of occupation by Aboriginal people has been much greater. That is what the Year Book states, but our legal system still pretends that terra nullius is a fact of life.

There is, of course, a very significant case in the High Court at the moment that I believe will, once and for all, I hope, deny the lie of terra nullius. Maybe then, together with Aboriginal Australians and Torres Strait Islanders, we will be able to get down to the serious business of negotiating a treaty, a pact, an agreement. One of the reasons for the significant areas of racism that we are all aware of is that people do not understand why there needs to be special programs, special conditions and special arrangements for our indigenous people. I believe that with the focus on Australia in 1993, we will need to work much more quickly and much more strenuously to ensure that we do give genuine recognition to our indigenous Australians. One of the starting points in that process is to override the lie of terra nullius.

As I said earlier, I do not believe that we have another 25 years to work through these issues. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people have been very patient. They are being very patient about our reconciliation process, which is a process of education and change in the Australian community. I believe that we really must finish that process by the year 2001.(Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That regulation 35 of the AUSTUDY Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 480 and made under the Student Assistance Act 1973, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of student financial assistance has been brought into the spotlight once again. The release of the Chapman report entitled Austudy: Towards a More Flexible Approach, and today being the National Union of Students national day of action on student financial assistance, highlight the need for re-evaluation and reform of the current system. The student financial assistance scheme, Austudy, remains a restrictive and inequitable system. It is a mass of inconsistencies. Today's debate deals with one of those inequities.

PARA.TAB: I have moved this disallowance motion today in order to rectify one of the many problems with the scheme. Regulation 35 deems that the recoverable amount of interest payable on late repayment of overpayments shall be 20 per cent per year. That is, the Government seeks to prescribe a 20 per cent interest rate on the late repayment of Austudy overpayments. While the Student Assistance Act 1973 allows for an interest rate to be charged on these payments, the amount the Government has prescribed in this case is exorbitant. The figure of 20 per cent bears no relation to current market rates, but is loosely based on what the Government has deemed a corresponding provision in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

The role of Austudy is to alleviate financial hardships and to assist participation in education, not to add to these burdens or to cripple students with debts and charges. A 20 per cent interest rate is a punitive measure. It is a measure designed to scare students who have failed to repay or to make arrangements to repay their debts within a three-month period. However, we know the realities of the administration of the Austudy scheme, and it is common knowledge that information such as changes in circumstances leading to overpayments is often not received or is delayed by the Department. The Department of Employment, Education and Training does not deny that many of the students who will incur this excessive amount of interest are simply victims of circumstance, as one DEET official has described them.

The Government's intention to prescribe an interest rate on late repayments of overpayments is understandable. It is both necessary and financially sensible to recoup these financial losses, and is a move reflected in many pieces of legislation dealing with the payments of benefits of various kinds. What the Democrats object to is the amount of interest that will be charged in this case. Twenty per cent is an unnecessarily high and punitive amount. I have to say that the measure to disallow this regulation has considerable support amongst both academics and students. On 26 May I received a letter from the Society of St Vincent de Paul. I quote from the letter:

SPEECH.PARA: In line with the Society's deeply held desire for a more equitable Australian community, your move in the area of AUSTUDY is an attempt in the direction of securing a more sustainable and secure financial future for Australia's students.
I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
