TALK.START.PARA: —The situation of overpayments must be examined more closely before this interest figure is determined. We cannot overlook that fact that some of the overpayment cases are the result of administrative difficulties and that many students receive overpayments through no fault of their own but due to the Department failing to respond quickly to or failing to process information. Although as much as $52m per annum was paid to ineligible students last year, over half this money has been recouped and arrangements have been made to recover most of the outstanding funds.

PARA.TAB: Contrary to the Opposition's belief, students receiving overpayments are not perpetrators of fraudulent deeds or guilty behaviour. It is also necessary to identify the types of people we are talking about. Students are not part of a well off socio-economic order. Typically, students live on incomes that are below the poverty line and may face low living standards. It seems a ruthless move and one that shows a complete lack of understanding of the realities of student life which allows the Government to hit students with an interest rate of 20 per cent on overpayments that may not even be their fault at a time when they may be attempting to find employment or may be without a job.

It is all very well for Dr Kemp and the coalition to accuse students who incur an interest rate on overpayments by saying that they have brought it upon themselves. What the Government has failed to do in determining this interest rate, and what the Government and the Opposition consistently fail to do when dealing with financial assistance for students, is examine the realities of student life.

The Democrats oppose regulation 35 on legislative and financially sustainable grounds. We oppose the excessive amount of interest that is proposed, but base this objection also on legal precedent in the income tax legislation. The rationale behind the interest rate is somewhat misguided. Although there are allowances in corresponding legislation for a 20 per cent interest charge on overpayments such as those contained in the Social Security Act and the Income Tax Assessment Act, the latter is currently under revision.

New taxation legislation introduced in Parliament yesterday seeks to clarify the existing Income Tax Assessment Act. The new income tax legislation reviews the legislative penalties and, in so doing, differentiates between the types of actions resulting in underpayment of tax. Currently, section 3 of the Taxation (Interest on Underpayments) Act prescribes an interest rate of 14.026 per cent. This figure is more appropriate financially and illustrates a compatibility with market rates. This figure is the interest rate attached to underpayments of taxation which are the equivalent of Austudy overpayments. In the new tax legislation, for the purposes of recouping tax which is innocently or inadvertently underpaid, the Government nominates a charge which is equal to the 13-week Treasury note average yield plus 4 per cent, and currently this works out to about 10 or 11 per cent.

Today's debate about student financial assistance coincides with the National Union of Students national day of action on Austudy and on the state of the higher education system. NUS is the peak student representative body in Australia, with over 340,000 members. NUS has declared today a national day of action in protest against regressive changes in the higher education system over the last five years that have seen a move towards user pays education. Today's national day of action also anticipates further negative policy changes by this Government.

Today students are registering their disapproval with the education policies of this Government. They are signalling their objection to the prospect of loans, increased HECS debts, high levels of unmet demand, and the fact that Austudy payments are below the poverty line and are based on false assumptions about student life. Students are also protesting about their work and study conditions.

The release of the Chapman report, entitled Austudy: Towards a More Flexible Approach, has highlighted the role of student financial assistance once again. The Chapman report outlines a variety of options for the reform of Austudy. Many of these recommendations deserve serious consideration if we are to make the scheme more flexible and a more appropriately targeted one. However, the Chapman report also considers some aggressive measures such as the introduction of a loans scheme. The Democrats believe that this would have a devastating effect on participation rates in higher education and we are unanimously opposed to its introduction. The notion that grants should be replaced by a system of loans has alarmed and outraged the student, academic and wider community. They quite rightly see this as formally entrenching user pays education in this country; nor can we expect students from traditionally disadvantaged backgrounds—this includes women, mature-age, part time, and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students and those from lower socio-economic backgrounds—to face the prospect of debt with equanimity.

Another proposal is the concept of a `mix and match' loans and grants scheme. To many this represents the thin edge of the wedge and would set a precedent for an erosion in the value of grants. In this scheme students would be able to trade in their grants for twice the amount in a loan form. This loan would then be repaid through the taxation system in a manner similar to that of the higher education contribution scheme. The rhetoric promotes this as increased choice for students. It claims that this represents a more flexible approach in a hitherto restrictive system. The reality, of course, is that many students would be forced to take out the doubled loan amount due to desperate economic circumstances. Thus, the concept of choice is farcical.

Despite a proliferation of Government reports into student financial assistance in the past three years, we have yet to see any substantial reform of the system. There are some changes in the current set of regulations we are debating today that the Democrats do welcome. The increase in the personal income tax threshold from $4,000 to $5,000 is a small step towards defining a realistic personal income threshold so that students are no longer heavily penalised for attempting to earn an income above their meagre Austudy benefits. Until the Government recognises $8,000 per annum as the minimum personal threshold, its commitment to providing a realistic means of student financial support is questionable. It is worth noting that this was a recommendation of the Chapman report.

In these regulations the minor relaxation in the academic progress rules is also a desirable change. Nevertheless, there remain glaring inequities in the scheme. The definition of `independence' at the age of 25 years has been considered arbitrary and ridiculous for many years. Despite the fact that young people are deemed eligible to vote, to drink, to marry, to bear arms and to drive at the age of 18 and earlier, they are still considered dependent upon their parents until the age of 25 by virtue of being a student. This defies all logic in today's world.

The assumption that young students up to the age of 25 receive material support from their parents reveals the Government's lack of knowledge about the situation for many young people in society who, despite total financial independence from their families for the purposes of Austudy, are judged to be supported by their parents' incomes. This myth has been exposed many times. Material support for students and young people is not always forthcoming from their parents for many reasons. In fact, young people are often expected to contribute to their families to assist with living costs such as rent, utilities and food. Despite evidence that refutes the assumption that under 21-year-olds are assisted by their parents, Austudy still bases its method of payment on the parental living income and assets.

The change in the independent status from the age of 25 to 21 years is strongly supported by a range of groups in the community, including NUS and the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, and has been reinforced in reports, including the Chapman report and the report of the Government's own House of Representatives Standing Committee on student financial assistance. This week, the AVCC has publicly supported changes to the age of independence. In its report for the 1993-95 triennium entitled Australian universities in a changing world, Austudy is described as `a scheme of fundamental importance to students and especially to fair and equitable access to universities.' It then recommends an increase in Austudy payments to the level of unemployment benefits, a lowering of the age of independence, an increase in the personal income threshold and a review of the parental assets and income test. The AVCC recognises that students are the foundation of our clever country.

Despite these wide-ranging suggestions for reform, the Chapman review was also established. The Chapman report does make some positive recommendations, including increasing the parental and spouse income tests and lowering the age of independence. I urge the Government to implement these reforms.

Students cannot be expected to live and study on a full time basis on very low levels of income, nor can it be expected that they be provided for by their parents. It is time to re-examine our commitment to education and to re-evaluate the concept of student financial assistance as a vital part of this commitment to education. The Government must decide whether Austudy exists as a form of income supplement. If it does, it must allow students to earn additional money without punitive levels of taxation or a low income tax threshold. If Austudy is considered an income in itself, we must provide for a realistic living allowance.

In Australia, our concept of education seems to be a narrow one. Our commitment to education does not end when students gain access to an institution. We must ensure that our places of learning are well resourced, adequately staffed and that students' lives are conducive to achieving the best possible standard of education. This means access to places where study conditions are adequate and living standards are sufficient, not a life of poverty and hardship.
The AVCC points out in its recent publication that:

SPEECH.PARA: an important complementary aspect of issues relating to quality assurance and learning and teaching relates to equity of student access to universities and, in particular, the existing student support scheme, Austudy.
The AVCC has drawn the vital link between quality of education and the support services available. Our support services for students are sorely lacking.

PARA.TAB: A recent ABS survey showed that the average student weekly income was $119.80. This confirms that students are living on payments substantially below the poverty line. This figure is startling and betrays the fact that, while we claim the future rests with our best and brightest, we are happy to see them struggle and starve. Not only do we expect students to forgo earning income in favour of increasing their skills and knowledge, which is in the nation's interests, but we also penalise them every step of the way.

Apart from income forgone, students are expected to live on meagre amounts of financial support and are faced with punitive taxation measures if they attempt to earn money in excess of the personal income threshold of only $5,000 per annum. On top of this, students are saddled with a HECS debt, which is a disincentive to participation in higher education for many groups.

We have all heard the horror stories about students turning to prostitution, crime and, as reported in Adelaide, marrying as a way of obtaining increased Austudy benefits. Yet the Government and the Opposition fail to acknowledge this reality, even when it is presented to them in a statistical form.

The Government has demonstrated an unwillingness to make much needed changes to the Austudy regulations. I might add that these debates about student financial assistance in the past have resulted in an unholy alliance between the coalition and the Government. Our recommendations for reform have received widespread support from the student movement and members of the public. The clever country rhetoric is tiresome. We must demonstrate a realistic commitment to those aspiring to undertake education and training. That means that we cannot afford to lock out of higher education institutions those students who are eligible for places—certainly not 50,000 of them—nor can we expect students to survive below the poverty line once they are in education.

The Government has an opportunity to make lasting and significant change to this area of the education budget. The Price report and the progressive options of the Chapman report have paved the way for this reform. I challenge the Government to make the necessary and long overdue changes and, until then, to stop placating the student movement with false hopes and promises in the form of additional reports.

In the meantime, attempts to recoup funds by hitting those most in need with an interest rate of 20 per cent defies all logic. It is another short-sighted measure that has little basis in legislation or welfare. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not support the Australian Democrats' motion of disallowance. The extravagant words of Senator Sowada, my good friend, do not justify the motion that she has brought to the Senate today. The Senate knows that the Austudy regulations that were brought down in April were open to disallowance by either chamber over the 15 sitting days that have followed.

PARA.TAB: So it is that we now come to that very small part of the total Austudy regulations that Senator Sowada has addressed in her remarks today. It involves a single innovation of a 20 per cent interest rate to be applied as a penalty to overpayments or wrong payments of Austudy if those amounts are not repaid within a three-month period.

I know that all of us who are concerned about the circumstances of students in education in Australia are familiar with the perennial problem of the trainee doctor or engineer or the trainee in whatever profession who dies on the way to his or her graduation for lack of funds or support. We are aware of the need for students to be able to be sustained in their progress through their studies before they are able to reap incomes.
Fifteen to 20 years ago I was responsible for student services at the University of Adelaide. I used to run the loan program for students in need. I used to be the adviser—

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't give me enough.

—Did I give Senator Bolkus a loan? I used to run the advice system for the equivalent of the Austudy scheme then. Before Austudy, it was called TEAS—the tertiary education assistance scheme. Before that, and back to the mid-1950s, there was the Commonwealth scholarship living allowance scheme. Commonwealth scholarships became TEAS, and TEAS has now become Austudy. In fact, the Minister who introduced TEAS, the then Minister Kim Beazley Snr, asked me to be on the advisory committee for the setting up of the original regulations for TEAS.
—One more mistake.
—Although it may have been a mistake, I have felt somewhat familiar with the scheme throughout that time.

PARA.TAB: I am aware that 20 to 25 per cent of all tertiary students have dire financial problems that lead them to withdraw from some of their studies, to take on part time work beyond what may well be sensible or to just suffer in silence with inadequate nutrition, clothing and so on. It is a desperate question that must be, and has continued to be, addressed by governments of all persuasions.

The Opposition happens to think that the present Austudy scheme has grave inadequacies and that it is wrongly targeted. The Chapman report on Austudy was tabled in the Parliament today—or at least the Minister has sent me a copy; I do not know whether it has actually been tabled. I received this copy today, which is entitled Austudy; Towards a More Flexible Approach—an Options Paper by Bruce Chapman.

The Chapman report roundly calls for a whole range of new initiatives for Austudy, many of which are in tune with the views of the Opposition—the Liberal and National parties—over the last five and even 10 years. He contemplates a more flexible Austudy scheme that would allow students to opt to forsake some part of their grant in order to gain double that amount in a loans scheme that would be repaid under the higher education contribution scheme.

The Chapman report calls for more precise targeting of those students who are in need. That has been the cry of the Liberal and National parties. There is a call for reviewing the family income assessment so that the present inequities that arise are overcome. Again, the Liberal and National parties have called for that. Above all, there is a call—a proposition that the Liberal and National parties have been putting for some time—that no student in Australia should be prevented from taking a course of study through a lack of financial resources alone. The Chapman report finds that a minority—something like 20 per cent; I cannot find it immediately as I have only been able to look at the report in a cursory way this afternoon—of students would not have proceeded to tertiary study if there had not been the Austudy payments.

We have been seeing for the first time, whether from the Commonwealth scholarship scheme, the tertiary education assistance scheme or the Austudy scheme, that when there is an overpayment or a wrong payment the student has with proper notice three months to repay that overpayment. From 1 January this year there has been 20 per cent per annum interest on that amount of overpayment.

At the moment, $1.171 billion is paid out in the Austudy scheme. The amount of overpayment or wrong payment is about 4 per cent of that figure. In the last financial year, $42m in overpayments or wrong payments was paid out by the Department of Employment, Education and Training in Austudy benefits. Of that amount, unfortunately, only $19m has been recovered. In summary, $1.2 billion is paid out in Austudy; 4 per cent of that amount is in wrong payment; and only 2 per cent, half of that, is recovered. It is clear that by this new regulation the Government wants to give a direct penalty as an incentive for those overpayments to be returned into the program so that the students for whom Austudy is rightly targeted should receive the benefit and not those for whom it is not targeted.

Senator Sowada has said that this is an excessive amount. It happens to be exactly the introductory penalty interest rate for those who are at fault in not paying due taxes under the income tax system. Income tax penalties can greatly exceed 20 per cent. I am sure that the parallel between the penalty rate for tax in the Taxation Office and the penalty rate for these payments—there being such a harmony these days between payments such as Austudy and the tax system—is appropriate. It is not arbitrary, it is not excessive and it has two buffer periods. First, there is the buffer period of three months before that interest rate begins and, secondly, there is a period in which a student who thinks that this payment ought to be reconsidered, or for which he thinks there is a claim, can appeal through the appropriate appeal mechanisms. In many cases it would be a matter of some six months before that interest rate penalty would begin.

The Opposition does not support the attempt by the Democrats to eliminate that interest rate penalty; rather, we think it is appropriate. I note that one of the main reasons for overpayment or wrong payment is that an incorrect statement on an application may be discovered when that application is being audited and as a result the assessor within the Department of Employment, Education and Training will review and change the eligibility for all or some of the Austudy payment. Some of it will be backdated to the beginning of the year and some will be backdated to a particular event in the year.

Another reason is where a student changes circumstances but those circumstances are not brought to the attention of the Department until some later period. For example, if a student is enrolled in less than three-quarters of a year's workload, they are no longer defined as a full time student, and Austudy is only available to full time students. If by withdrawing from one half subject a student moves over that line, they may even not be aware that they have moved into a position where they are no longer to receive Austudy from the date of that change in their enrolment. From that date, they are no longer eligible to receive the Austudy payments and a repayment is required of them. The three months in which they are to make the repayment of that amount starts at that time. At the end of the three months they may well have a continuing period arising from their appeal. But, in any event, the interest rate begins only after those two buffer periods.

Today I received a letter from the South Australian President of the National Union of Students. Being a South Australian and having been a student at the University of Adelaide and an adviser to students—in fact, I was responsible for student services at the university—I give very real attention to such a letter. The letter says that we should knock out this 20 per cent interest charge. It gives examples of the kinds of reasons why overpayments arise. The second paragraph of Carla Stacey's letter of today's date states:

SPEECH.PARA: Overpayments of AUSTUDY are a result of either a bureaucratic mistake in the amount eligible for a recipient or an AUSTUDY recipient failing to indicate a change in financial situation.

I honestly say to my good friend Carla Stacey, and to any other students, that these are two of the lesser reasons for there being an overpayment under Austudy. I ask them to reconsider it and more comprehensively address the kinds of circumstances that lead to overpayment.

PARA.TAB: If it were only what was said in this letter—that this was the result of bureaucratic mistakes and, as such, students will get 20 per cent interest penalties—I can imagine the storm of protest that may have excited students in campuses as they gathered in various demonstrations around the country today. It is wrong of the National Union of Students to misrepresent the situation to students and it is counterproductive vis-a-vis their credibility if they move the Government or next year's government—the Liberal-National Party government—to rightly respond to those credible requests that are to be made for improvement of the system.

Let me refer to two other matters. One is the approach of the Democrats generally in this area, which I do not accept, and the other is the improvements to Austudy that the Liberal and National parties have already announced as part of the Fightback package. It has now become well-known in this chamber that the Liberal and National parties will, on coming to office, spend more than $3 billion of additional money on tertiary, secondary and primary education. A considerable proportion of that additional $3 billion for new education programs will be spent on students who are receiving Austudy, both at the tertiary and secondary level. All educational services will be free of the goods and services tax.

In addition, the higher education contribution scheme will be retained. There will be an increase in the discount for that portion which is eventually subject to HECS and which can be avoided by an upfront payment. Under the present Government, there is a 15 per cent discount if the HECS liability is avoided by an upfront payment. We will increase that discount to 25 per cent. It will give a genuine benefit to many students who will take the option of paying upfront that portion of what is required of them for their academic enrolment.

We will review the student assistance arrangements to ensure that assistance is provided equitably and that no-one is shut out of higher education purely on financial grounds. I repeat: a guiding light of the approach of the Liberal and National parties is to have an Austudy scheme which ensures that nobody is shut out of higher education purely on financial grounds. We will better target Austudy by including only those receivers of it who are eligible for $30 a week or more. The actual benefit under Austudy will increase by 6 per cent, which will occur automatically at the time of the introduction of the new taxation arrangements, targeted for 1 October, 1994. This increase in Austudy amounts exceeds the 4.4 per cent increase in costs estimated to flow from the introduction of a GST.

I will not take the time of the Senate now to reiterate the more substantial matters which relate to the higher education system or to schools and which affect the receivers of Austudy. But, in broad, we will give complete freedom. We will return autonomy to the education institutions of Australia. We will stop the bureaucratic monopolies of decision-making that have been arrogated by the Labor Government in Canberra and that have been a block to so many good initiatives that otherwise would have happened at the local institutional level for the benefit of students.

I refer to the context of Senator Sowada's remarks. Senator Sowada has a genuine interest in education and the well-being of students. So do we all. I do not think Senator Sowada will be offended when I say that she comes from a bleeding hearts party—a party that wants to greatly increase social welfare payments, greatly increase research commitments, greatly increase overseas aid, greatly cut the tax on low income receivers, abolish payroll taxes—which we will achieve next year in conjunction with the States—and not just knock off a 20 per cent interest rate on penalties for Austudy overpayments, but give Austudy to every student. Every single student would qualify for the full amount; there would be no targeting on the basis of family incomes. The Democrats want to give Austudy to everybody. They want to make sure that it is increased to 120 per cent of the poverty line, and that it is indexed. This is the bleeding hearts party of the Democrats.

This is the context in which Senator Sowada wants to see 20 per cent lopped off the penalty on overpayments. Let me tell the Senate what it would cost to do just those few things that the Democrats have promised. To see the tax threshold indexed to inflation and increased to at least the poverty line will cost $10 billion. Where will that come from? The Democrats want to increase the funding for national research to 2 per cent of gross domestic product. That will cost $4.5 billion. It will mean that there will have to be $6.7 billion for research.

I refer to overseas aid. It is the aspiration of the Opposition to go to 0.7 of GNP for the level of overseas aid. I think that even Senator Evans might still have in the back of his mind that that would be an aspiration of the Labor Party; it certainly is of the Liberal and National parties. But that is not enough for the Democrats. They will go immediately to one per cent. An article written by Richard Farmer, dated 21 February 1990, states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . immediate allocation of 1 per cent GNP in international aid, increasing gradually to 2 per cent.

It will cost $5 billion extra for overseas aid. Let us talk about the abolition of payroll tax. We have costed that already—it will cost $6 billion. Everyone who has read Fightback knows that it will cost $6 billion. Then we come to the education matters. The Democrats want no tertiary taxes or fees—that is, no HECS—and Austudy to be increased to 120 per cent of the poverty line, and indexed, and available to all students. That will cost at least another $1 billion, probably $2 billion. In just those five items from the bleeding hearts, the Democrats, who are all heart and no responsibility—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where do they get the money?

—I do not know where they are going to get the money from. These five items alone will mean a 25 per cent increase in the Commonwealth's expenditure. Where will the money come from? I have to complete this story by saying that only $5 billion has been identified as coming from new taxes. The Democrats would have a capital gains tax which would be extended to the family home; death duties would be introduced; negative gearing would be abolished and there would be a 10 per cent duty imposed on luxury imports.

PARA.TAB: These new taxes of the Democrats will raise $5 billion, but they will still be $20 billion short, and that will be added on to the deficit and it will ruin the economy of Australia. I have gone into no more than five areas in their long list of bleeding heart promises to help the people of Australia. I have not even mentioned social welfare, where they want to spend more money. It is no wonder that we have my good friend Senator Sowada coming in here and not admitting to any of that, but out of that context coming up with the abolition of a 20 per cent penalty interest on overpayments, which represents only 4 per cent of the $1.2 billion presently spent on Austudy.

The Democrats want to be able to say, `We are the champions who stood up in the Senate to get that penalty knocked off. This unholy alliance'—the extravagant phrase Senator Sowada used—`of the Government and the Opposition stood in our way or we would have brought it to you. So, students of Australia, vote for the Democrats.' They might get one more candidate elected and make a little more noise, but they know that they will never have to deliver. They will never have to make sure that the books balance; that there is the taxation revenue to pay for all of these extravagant claims.

There has been not one reference by Senator Sowada to what the cost will be of even this small proposal she is backing today. The Democrats are not worried about the bottom-line cost to the taxpayers of Australia. They do not take into account the basic matter in the Chapman report on Austudy—the reference to a lifetime consideration of the situation of students. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: In general, this report offers a more favourable assessment to policy perspectives that consider the distribution of income in a lifetime context.

Poor students become rich graduates. The Chapman report, like the Liberal and National parties, tries to take that into account by adding more flexible arrangements to HECS and by ensuring the capacity of students to be successful in their studies, thus ensuring their incomes as graduates. There has been no reference by the Democrats to that kind of approach. All they can think of is taking a populist and irresponsible line that will make them heroes with an element of students.

PARA.TAB: I conclude—perhaps making the situation all the easier for my opponent Senator Bolkus—by saying that in my contact with students these days I find that the majority do not take the NUS line. A majority of them say, `There must be a user-pays element. There must be a contribution. HECS is something which is basically justified. We have social consciences as students and we must be seen to be making an appropriate contribution to the cost of our studies'.

I put to the Democrats that they will get only a minority of students to support them with their populist approach. They will not get the best students supporting them—those with a social conscience who understand that they should pay their way and accept the necessity to repay any overpayment or any wrong payment. The Democrats should appeal to the responsible students, who have a quite different approach. The Opposition will not support the disallowance motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly on behalf of the Government and indicate that we too will not support the disallowance motion. I say at the start that the Senate seems to be caught this evening between the bleeding hearts and the bleeding bores.
—The bleeding what?

—The bleeding bores. But if I were to say that, it would be unfair to Senator Teague to a certain extent. I will not go into a long debate about this matter. I think it is sufficient to say that the Government's position on these measures has been spelt out by the relevant Minister. I think it is also sufficient to say that much of the argument I would embark on has been put forward by Senator Teague.

PARA.TAB: There is a reason for the regulation and for the rate of interest of 20 per cent. It is inappropriate to compare the rate of 20 per cent to the commercial rate, and I think Senator Sowada understands that very well. From the smile on her face, it is quite apparent that she does. As Senator Teague and Senator MacDonald said in the last half hour, it is a populist approach and we can understand why the Democrats are doing it.

We are talking about an area that has had major and exponential increase in terms of support to students over recent years. But we are also talking about an area which has been subject to criticism in the past from, for instance, the Australian National Audit Office. The Department was criticised for not implementing the penalty provisions relating to debts. The regulation that is the subject of debate this evening is a regulation that will apply to those who are not paying their debts promptly. As Senator Teague said, it does not apply to all students who have moneys outstanding in this area.

No interest charge applies to debtors who repay the overpayment within three months of the notification of the debt. That point needs to be made in this debate because it was not recognised sufficiently by Senator Sowada. We should also make the point that those who repay their debts by instalments in accordance with acceptable arrangements with the Department will also not incur interest. Students who continue to be entitled to assistance will not be penalised as their debts will be recovered by withholding a portion of their entitlement. Debtors without financial resources to repay debts may also have their debt considered for write-off action. So the regulation is not as stringent, not as hard, as the Democrats would have it appear.

The reason we have fixed on 20 per cent is that what the Government recognises is needed here and what the Opposition also recognises is needed here is a powerful inducement to encourage former clients of the Department to repay their overpayments promptly. There are mechanisms in place—there are pressure valves—to ensure that those suffering hardship and those who do pay are not penalised. However, it is important to ensure that there is a powerful inducement in the process. It should be recognised that the 20 per cent rate of interest is consistent with the charge that applies to taxpayers with outstanding liabilities to the Commissioner of Taxation.

We on the Government side say that there needs to be a powerful inducement. That has been recognised by the Australian National Audit Office. The inducement has to be 20 per cent. That is consistent with other inducements, such as in the taxpaying area. We also ask the Senate to recognise that there are mechanisms to ensure that those suffering hardship or who do pay their debts or arrange to pay their debts will not incur that 20 per cent inducement to pay.

The debate has gone on long enough. I do not really need to go into a whole litany about the assistance that has been provided in this area, whether by way of assistance to students or by way of funding the education process. In an effort to wind up this debate quickly, I indicate that the Government does not support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue boils down to whether we judge the 20 per cent that is now in the regulations and which we seek to disallow to be a just interest rate to apply to overpayments and to impose on the students. That is really what it boils down to.

PARA.TAB: The question also is: who will pay that money? It may well be the student. The student normally, under those circumstances, does not have the money to pay for it. The obligation to pay then goes back to the parents. They are the ones who, all along the line, have been disadvantaged by a number of government decisions in the last seven or eight years—even further back. The position is that an unjustifiably heavy tax burden is placed on those parents who are keeping their sons and daughters at university without any assistance or with minimal assistance from the Government.

I take issue here with a point made in the Chapman report. The Chapman report, which was referred to by Senator Teague, indicates that the most important consideration for an income support scheme which is designed to remove financial barriers to participation in education by the disadvantaged lies in ensuring that the right amount of support goes to the right people. Although I have not completely read this paper—it came into my possession only today—the point is that that is only one aspect. It is true that it is a very important aspect but it is only one. It does not go to the question of horizontal tax equity; that is, tax equity for those families at whatever level of income who have sons and daughters going through universities and whose university related expenses are paid for by those families. Compare such a family with another family whose sons and daughters are not going through university and therefore does not have the burden of paying for fees, books, transport and so on. To be quite frank, that is an issue which has to be considered and faced up to, but it is not being faced up to.

Before 1976 one could claim a taxation deduction in respect of the expenditure from the family income on the education of one's sons and daughters. Now one cannot. It can be done by a company, it can be done by a business, but the most important business in Australia, families, cannot claim. I agree that, under the particular rules, if there is an overpayment there should be an incentive for it to be paid back. Creating the incentive surely is action that can be taken by the Government for crying out loud.

The report of the House of Representatives standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Student Financial Assistance at page 74 talked about benefits control units being established by DEET across Australia. What are the benefits control units doing? The report then indicated on that same page what is proposed to be done by the benefits control units. It is their job to get the money back.

If a particular rate is to be levied in respect of that particular overpayment, it should be made a reasonable rate, on the basis of justice, not on the basis of incentive. The incentive, surely, should apply to the benefits control units, in terms of getting the money back. Indeed, I am not so sure that the description of the situation given by the Minister and by Senator Teague is adequate. I am not saying that what they said is incorrect, but the overall rate for underpayments as I have it in the tax rates and tables 1991-92—that is, the underpayments by the taxpayer to the Taxation department, which is the equivalent of overpayments by DEET to students—appears to be 14.026 per cent. Of course, even that figure is well above the commercial rate.

Let us agree to and fix a just rate rather than have this very severe penalty rate of 20 per cent applying across the board to all students to whom overpayments have been made for a range of reasons. It comes down to whether or not one considers 20 per cent too high. In my view, 20 per cent is too high. It is not just. I support the motion for disallowance as moved by Senator Sowada.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I wish briefly to exercise my right of reply on this issue, especially after listening to Senator Teague's rather gratuitous criticisms of various aspects of Democrat policy. It is quite clear that he had not read the Chapman report in any detail. If he had, he would have noted that one of Chapman's recommendations was that Austudy be indexed to the CPI. He would also have noted that Chapman himself noted that Austudy is below the dole. What incentive is there for students to continue their education when they can in fact receive a higher level of benefits on the dole? On those two elements alone, it is clear Senator Teague is simply talking off the top of his head. Quite clearly he had received the report only this afternoon and had not had a chance to read it in detail. Certainly Chapman himself recognises that the inadequacy of current Austudy benefits is a major problem and is a disincentive for many students to continue their education.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bolkus referred to criticism about DEET and its administration in respect of Austudy. It is well known that DEET has been very heavily criticised for its administration of Austudy, for the fact that many students receive overpayments to which they are not entitled, and for the fact that many aspects of student requests for changes to their benefits take a long time to feed through the system. It is not only simply a matter of students failing in their responsibilities but also a problem of administration in DEET which has been recognised by the Auditor-General and by this place.

Senator Teague also mentioned Democrat policy in relation to a significant increase in funds for research activity. I think it would be widely recognised by higher education institutions, by business and, in fact, by this Government that there must be a significant increase in Australia's research and development activities if it is to become internationally competitive. It is absolutely critical that we develop new technologies, that we develop market niches and that we can hold our heads high on the international stage as our markets for our traditional exports fall and as income from those exports falls. We must significantly increase research activity for high-tech products. If Senator Teague believes that this is an inappropriate activity for universities and for business to be engaged in, he is obviously not in touch with what is going on in the marketplace and with what Australia needs to become internationally competitive.

I think it is worth noting that the Korean Government has recently announced that it will fund environmental technologies and environmental waste management technologies to the tune of over $700m. That is a significant public investment directly into an area of technology which will yield significant benefits to that country over a long period. We will be left behind if we simply believe that Australia can carry on its merry way by simply ripping minerals out of the ground, ripping wool off the sheep's back and continuing to grow wheat and so forth. We must become internationally competitive by improving our technological base and using the intellects that we know we have in Australia's scientific community.

We should also look at what the Opposition plans to do to education. This is a very important point because Senator Teague referred to a number of elements of the Democrat policy. He said that we were being populist. Senator Teague is obviously not aware that his own Party's policies are in fact not widely supported within the academic community and especially amongst students. The Opposition has every reason to be extremely concerned about its education policies and how they may well be received over the coming 12 months. Once the people of Australia find out what those policies will actually do, I think they will be extremely worried about the prospect of a coalition government.

It is worth noting that the Opposition proposes fees for university courses. It proposes to introduce student vouchers. There will be a set amount of money for a student to be able to go along to an institution and enrol in whichever course they choose, and then universities will be allowed to charge a fee in addition to that voucher. It is worth noting that we have seen significant deregulation of course fees for postgraduate study. In the past 12 months we have seen universities take advantage of and grasp in both hands this deregulatory mechanism that has been offered to them.

What has in fact happened is that, for a variety of course work programs at various institutions which will involve postgraduate degrees to help people improve their professional qualifications, many institutions have chosen to charge most exorbitant rates for those courses. For example, an institution in Melbourne now charges $26,000 for an MBA program. That is under this Government's current policies. I ask you, Mr Deputy President, to consider what would happen under the Opposition's policies if this particular method of deregulation was extended across the entire university system and applied to undergraduate degrees as well.

The AVCC has said that it is extremely concerned about the kind of mechanism that this would introduce into tertiary institutions in Australia. We could see the cost of a medical degree reaching the level of $130,000, given the fact that it is a five year degree and given the level of capital works and the level of equipment that is needed for degrees of that nature. We could find that many degrees such as medicine, veterinary science and other science degrees become totally out of reach for the average Australian simply because universities took advantage of market driven policies. That would price many courses out of the reach of average students. It is quite clear that many of the Opposition's education policies are not widely supported. People are very concerned about them. The Opposition will have a great deal of difficulty in trying to sell an education policy to the electorate where excellence in education actually equals elitism.

To get back to the Austudy motion for disallowance, which is what this debate is actually about, I reiterate that the Democrats do not object to the notion of charging an interest rate for a late repayment of an Austudy overpayment, but we do object to punitive interest rates and an interest rate that bears no relationship to the current level of market rates. For example, Senator Teague referred to much higher interest rates applicable in tax legislation, and certainly that is very true.

I seek to clarify my earlier comments in relation to tax. I mentioned earlier a tax Bill that is currently being considered by this House—the Taxation Laws Amendment (Self-Assessment) Bill 1992—which was introduced into the Parliament this week. This legislation actually reforms the legislative penalties and differentiates between the types of actions resulting in the underpayment of tax, remembering of course that the underpayment of tax is equivalent to an Austudy overpayment.

This particular legislation provides for a dichotomous system consisting of separate penalty provisions and separate interest provisions; that is, a system that deliberately takes into account the circumstances leading to the underpayment of tax and imposes penalties according to the actions of the taxpayer. Where there is no fault on behalf of the taxpayer there is no penal component, although there is an interest component. Where the taxpayer is at fault there is a penal charge plus interest imposed. This differentiation is supported by the Democrats and we ask the Government why it does not institute a similar system for Austudy. Notwithstanding this superior system, the tax legislation I have cited also proposes to change the existing interest rate component which will be charged at 4 per cent above the Government's short term borrowing rate. That change to the interest rate for tax underpayments is currently before the Parliament and will in fact reduce the level of interest payable to tax underpayments.

We ask the Government why it is, on the one hand, introducing a piece of legislation which will affect the interest rate on this aspect of the tax system and, on the other hand, introducing a punitive 20 per cent tax rate for Austudy overpayments. It is a totally inconsistent position that, once again, we have seen the Government put before this Parliament. We are not saying to the Government, `Simply disallow this regulation and let us have a zero interest component on Austudy overpayments'. We are saying, `Go back to the drawing board and have another think about this in light of legislation you are currently passing and come up with something more reasonable'. I commend my motion of disallowance to the Senate.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Sowada's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: WOOL TAX (Nos 1 to 5) AMENDMENT BILLS 1992WOOL TAX (ADMINISTRATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1992PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No.2) 1992

PARA.TAB: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
That these Bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: WOOL TAX (Nos. 1-5) AMENDMENT BILLS 1992

PARA.TAB: These Bills amend the Wool Tax Acts (Nos 1-5) 1964 to increase the maximum rate of wool tax that can be imposed on carpet wool from 4 per cent to 6 per cent.
The Acts continue to provide for lower rates to be prescribed by regulation. The current prescribed rate for carpet wool is 3 per cent.

Given the current moves within the wool industry to recommend an increase in the component of the prescribed rate of wool tax that is to be directed towards promotion for all types of wool from 1 July this year, the Australian Carpet Wool Council has recommended that the maximum rate for carpet wool be lifted from 4 per cent to 6 per cent.
I commend the Bills to Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: WOOL TAX (ADMINISTRATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Wool Tax (Administration) Act 1964 to correspond to amendments concerning rebates being made to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991.

The amendments in this Bill come into play if the Minister determines that surplus funds of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission are to be distributed in the form of a rebate against wool tax payable in the following financial year. If such a determination is made, then persons liable to pay the tax in that following year need only remit to the Australian Taxation Office the net amount of tax—that is the prescribed rate of tax less the rebate.
The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has already announced that a rebate against wool tax for 1992/93 will be the mechanism to distribute any AWRC surplus this year.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL
This Bill is an Omnibus Bill containing minor administrative amendments to the following legislation administered within the Primary Industries and Energy Portfolio,
the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977;
the Australian Wool Corporation Act 1991;

the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991; the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989; the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991; and the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act 1949.
Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Act to correct a deficiency in the Act in relation to the giving of evidence of analysts in court proceedings by way of a certificate.

The AMLC Act currently provides that a certificate of analysis (for example, analysis of product for residues) is prima facie evidence of the information it contains. The deficiency arises, however, in that the certificate fails to establish that the substances which have been analysed were those found in the possession of the accused, seized and passed onto the analyst for analysis. The Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions believes that this deficiency requires the analyst to attend court to give evidence in support of other continuity witnesses.

The amendment proposed in this Bill will allow the certificate of the analyst to contain information as to the date of receipt of the substance, the name of the person from whom it was received and a description of the substance. This will directly link the substances analysed with those found in the possession of the accused and overcome the gap in the chain of evidence, obviating the need for the analyst to attend court to give evidence, unless called by the defendant.
Australian Wool Corporation Act 1991
Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991
Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989

The major part of this Bill is to provide for amendments to legislation for the wool industry. The amendments relate specifically to the Australian Wool Corporation Act 1991 (the AWC Act), the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991 the (AWRC Act), and the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 (PIERD Act).

In addition, as part of the overall package of changes to the wool industry legislation, proposed amendments to the Wool Tax (Administration) Act 1964, and to the Wool Tax Acts (Nos 1-5)1964, will be introduced separately.

The primary purpose of the package of amendments to the wool legislation is to provide mechanisms for distributing surplus Australian Wool Realisation Commission (AWRC) funds to wool growers and to introduce more flexibility into the current debt reduction arrangements. Both of these initiatives were recently announced in the `One Nation' statement. The package will also provide for other relatively minor amendments to the wool industry legislation, most of which are at the request of those involved in aspects of its administration.

Mr President, the wool industry represents yet another case which clearly demonstrates this Government's capacity to work with industry to develop sound public policy. The Government's position has always been clear: we will accept advice from a variety of sources, we will consult with the industry and jointly develop a policy base that will take those industries forward. What we have also made clear is that we will not be driven by ideological approaches that fail to recognise the concerns and requirements of industry.

Mr President, Honourable Senators will be aware of the radical changes to the statutory industry framework and marketing arrangements for wool which came into effect in July last year. The new statutory authorities (the Australian Wool Realisation Commission (AWRC), the new Australian Wool Corporation (AWC), and the Wool R&D Corporation (WRDC) have taken up their respective roles with enthusiasm and commitment.

The AWRC, in particular, has a significant challenge in selling the stockpile and discharging the industry debt. At the same time it must have regard for the overall impact of its activities on the market. While ever there is a large stockpile there is a potential for that stockpile to overhang the market in such a way as to create uncertainty and affect demand.

Twelve months ago the stockpile stood at 4.7 million bales and the debt was around $2.7 billion. At the time we expected that the AWRC would only be able to pay off a small amount of the debt in 1991/92 and the debt schedule therefore set the repayment target for the year at $20 million.

Since July the AWRC has been affected by a range of factors combining to enable it to achieve a higher income from sales from its stockpile of wool than was anticipated at the start of the season. The reasons for this include lower levels of wool production, the quality of the wool in the stockpile being different to recent drought affected production, increased demand for stocks to replenish the wool processing pipeline, and higher prices than expected. As a result, the AWRC is now well ahead of its required debt repayment target for this year.

To build on that better than expected outcome for the AWRC, the Government decided it was appropriate to change the AWRC debt reduction schedule from an annual to a cumulative basis as announced in the `One Nation' statement. This provision will give the AWRC more flexibility in adjusting its operations to market conditions. In the event of a market downturn the flexibility to pay off more debt in some years will give it the capacity to pay off less if returns are lower in others. It will however, need to ensure that the maximum debt balances at the end of each year do not exceed the limits set within the cumulative debt schedule.

It is possible in some years that funds might be generated by the AWRC which are not prudently required for the debt repayment program. Therefore, recognising that most growers are currently receiving low incomes, the Government believes that a way is needed to distribute to growers any such surplus funds generated by the AWRC. In the `One Nation' statement it was indicated that any surplus funds not prudently required by the AWRC may be used as a rebate to growers in the form of a cash payment.

Mr President, the government also gave a commitment to consult with the wool industry on the distribution of such funds to growers. Following those constructive discussions and with the agreement of the Wool Council, I announced in April that I propose to use any surplus funds generated by the AWRC during the current year as a rebate against the wool tax in 1992-93. My intention is that this will enable a reduction in the effective rate of the tax for next season while maintaining the prescribed rate of the tax at the existing 12 per cent. The Wool Council support this position.

The amendments proposed in the Bill will provide the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy with the flexibility to distribute surplus AWRC funds as a rebate of wool tax, as a cash payment to wool tax payers, or to determine that the surplus should remain in the Stockpile Fund to pay off more debt. A determination would be made after the Minister had been advised by the AWRC if it holds surplus funds which are not required for the prudent management of the debt repayment program and the operation of the Stockpile Fund. Before making a decision, the Minister will be required to consult with the Wool Council of Australia about the distribution of the surplus.

Mr President, I am optimistic about the future for wool. However, it is difficult to accurately predict what the market might do in the years ahead and therefore whether the AWRC will generate a surplus in future years. I am particularly mindful to also ensure that the objective to prudently manage the debt and stockpile sales must remain clear and uncompromised. To this end I will continue to strongly resist calls for a reduction in the overall prescribed wool tax rate.

The Government does not believe, on the basis of one year's performance, that it would be prudent to lower the prescribed rate of tax at this time. To do that might result in having to put the tax rate up again in a later year if the market suffers a downturn. The Wool Council of Australia endorses this position.

The level of the tax rebate to apply in 1992-93 will be decided in June this year and I will be considering the advice I receive from the AWRC on the size of the surplus when making that decision. I will also be consulting with Wool Council on the matter.

Mr President, as I mentioned earlier, this Bill also contains a number of other amendments which have been made at the request of the AWC, the AWRC and the Australian Wool Industry Council (AWIC) in the light of experience with the legislation to date. Generally these amendments are intended to fine-tune some of the administrative provisions. Three of them warrant some explanatory comment.

The AWC has requested modifications to the way in which the register of wool tax payers entitled to vote at general meetings, is maintained. The proposed amendments will provide for grower registration and voting entitlements to be specified in a 3 year rolling register. Growers will be able to update their details each year if they wish. If they considered that the details previously provided were still relevant, then their entry on the register would be maintained for 3 years. In making these changes, the administration of the register will be simplified, and growers will be relieved of the annual requirement to make a formal application to be registered.

As well, an addition is proposed to the types of motions which can be put and voted on at an AWC annual general meeting. Under the current legislation woolgrowers are unable to put forward motions on general business matters within the AWC's responsibilities. The proposed amendment will mean greater accountability between woolgrowers and the AWC by allowing a wider range of motions to be debated and voted upon.

Amendments to ensure that the AWRC has the appropriate and well defined powers to deal in hedging has been requested by them following discussions with financial institutions and in the light of legal advice. The changes will ensure that the Commission has the commercial flexibility which is consistent with its functions. The proposed changes are similar to recently made provisions for other statutory authorities and in essence, ensure that the AWRC has the power to use hedging contracts to manage risks of variations in the cost of borrowings as well as risks of adverse variations in foreign currency transactions. In addition the AWRC will be able to use hedging to manage returns on investments. Similar amendments have also been made to the AWC legislation at the request of the AWC.

At the request of the Australian Wool Industry Council (AWIC) an amendment has been made to the AWC Act to provide additional flexibility in the registration authority for wool sampling sites, testing laboratories and showfloors. Currently the National Association of Testing Authorities (NATA) is the sole registration authority. The proposed amendment will provide for the possibility that an alternative registration authority to NATA may be prescribed at some time in the future.

Some minor amendments have also been made to the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 (the PIERD Act). These amendments are required as a consequence of amendments made to the AWC Act regarding the establishment and maintenance of a register of woolgrowers for the purposes of voting at an annual general meeting.

All of the proposed amendments which make up the package of changes to the wool legislation are responsible decisions which fine tune the statutory arrangements and show that the Government is sensitive to ensuring there is an appropriate and flexible framework for the industry.
Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991
The proposed amendments to this Act are to rectify minor anomalies concerning the allowing of minimum quantity or minimum monetary levels for small producers.

In most levy or export charge schemes about 85% of levy income is paid by only 15% of the levy payer population, whereas 40 to 50% of the population would pay less than the limits proposed. The intention is to allow small producers a threshold before having to pay levy. Once the threshold is reached, levy would become payable on the total quantity or amount. The basis for setting the threshold is not linked to the actual levy rates but is related to the estimated collection cost per levy return. These provisions will permit different thresholds to be prescribed for future levy years according to changing economic circumstances.

With full cost recovery for levy collections operating since 1988-1989 there has been increasing pressure from participating industries for more economical collection techniques to be adopted by the Department.
These measures have the support of participating industries. As there are no changes proposed to the operative rates of levy or export charge in this Bill there will be no net effect to revenue.
Snowy Mountain Hydro-electric Power Act 1949

The amendment to this Act increases the Ministerial contract approval level from $0.5 to $2 million. It empowers the Authority to enter into contracts valued under $2 million without the requirement to obtain prior Ministerial approval for each contract up to this level.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: COAL MINING INDUSTRY (LONG SERVICE LEAVE FUNDING) BILL 1992
These Bills form an important part of the Government's Coal Industry Reform Package.

They provide for the amendment and (ultimately) the repeal of the States Grants (Coal Mining Industry Long Service Leave) Act 1949 which, together with complementary state legislation, establish the present scheme for the funding of long service leave in the black coal mining industry in New South Wales, Queensland, Western Australia and Tasmania.
The current scheme is funded by way of an excise on coal production levied at 20 cents per tonne. Under the proposed arrangements, long service leave will be funded by a levy on payroll.
The new scheme has been agreed to by the relevant states and all elements in the industry affected have been consulted in relation to the proposed reforms.

On 2 December 1991 the Government announced a range of initiatives in relation to the coal industry. These were announced in the Government's coal industry policy statement jointly issued by the Minister for Industrial Relations and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The statement presents the most far-reaching changes to coal industry policy since the immediate post-war period. Reform of the industry's long service leave arrangements is part of those initiatives.

The policy statement followed a review of long service leave funding undertaken by Mr L J Willett, then chairperson of the superannuation fund investment trust, and was delivered to the Minister for Industrial Relations in November 1990. The report recommended changes to the present funding scheme. It also proposed that the scheme should be fully funded so as to facilitate the portability of long service leave in the industry and to ensure the preservation of benefits in the event of companies going out of business.

The Government agrees with the general thrust of Mr Willett's report and believes that responsibility for administering the fund should be returned to the industry. It recognises, however, that in the short run this may impose significant cost burdens on sections of the industry.

Existing arrangements have operated on a "pay as you go" basis, and a substantial unfunded liability for long service leave has accrued. Moreover, large scale, highly productive producers (largely represented by the Queensland Mining Council) raised concerns that they presently cross-subsidise the operations of more labour intensive mines, predominantly the underground coal mining industry in NSW.

In commenting on the Willett report's recommendations, industry parties and State Governments agreed that outstanding liabilities and future accruals should be funded on a more equitable and rational basis related to employment costs. The Government believes that the new arrangements safeguard the public interest in maintaining a viable coal mining industry whilst representing an appropriate balance between the principles of efficiency and equity and the interests of the disparate parties.

The Bills terminate the present excise funding arrangement and implement a new industry-managed fully funded scheme. With the co-operation of the States, it is envisaged that the new funding arrangements will become fully operational from 1 January 1993. The principal features of the scheme are as follows.
There is to be a single national scheme under Commonwealth legislation, and its management is to be the responsibility of a board of directors made up of employer and union representatives.

The legislation will establish a Coal Mining Industry (long service leave funding) Corporation. The corporation will be wholly self financing and will have two functions. The first will be to manage the Coal Mining Industry Long Service Leave Trust Fund for the purpose of reimbursing participating companies for long service leave taken by coal miners and other eligible employees. The second will be to collect levies from companies for the purpose of funding long service leave and meeting the costs of the corporation.

The corporation will be constituted by a board of six directors whom the Minister for Industrial Relations will appoint and who will hold office on a part time basis. The Minister will appoint two of the directors to represent the companies engaged in black coal mining in New South Wales, Queensland and Tasmania, and one director to represent companies engaged in black coal mining in Western Australia.
The Minister will appoint one director to represent the United Mine Worker's Division of the Construction, Forestry and Mining Employees' Union, and one director to represent:

PARA.TAB: .The Electrical Trades Union of Australia;
.The Federated Engine Drivers' and Firemen's Association of Australia; and
.The Metals and Engineering Workers' Union.

SPEECH.PARA: Another director is to represent:

PARA.TAB: .The Australian Collieries Staff Association;
.The Colliery Officials Association of New South Wales; and
.The New South Wales Mine Managers Association.

SPEECH.PARA: In the first instance, the Minister will appoint one of the directors to be chairperson of the board and another to be deputy chairperson. Subsequent appointments of chairperson and deputy chairperson will be made by the board. The directors' remuneration will be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal.

The corporation will have all powers necessary to carry out the functions I have described. It will have the power to enter into contracts, including contracts with other organisations to collect levies, manage funds and make payments in relation to long service leave on behalf of the corporation. It will have the power to invest moneys so as to maximise the return on funds in the interests of contributors, to borrow moneys subject to ministerial approval, and to employ staff and engage consultants under terms and conditions determined by the board.
The scheme is to be independently reviewed at regular intervals and once it is fully funded responsibility for its operation will be devolved to the industry.

Assets and liabilities of the existing fund are to be transferred to the new scheme and the legislation provides that the rate of levy is to be prescribed by the Minister acting on the advice of the board.

The levy is to be collected from participating companies only, with the formula for reimbursement set to reflect national minimum industry standards in respect of long service leave. Claims for reimbursement may be made in relation to all award-based entitlements payable during long service leave (including production-related bonuses).
Reimbursement may also be claimed where an obligation to pay long service leave arises from any, or any combination of, the following:
—A certified agreement under made under relevant State or Federal Legislation

—An agreement registered or approved by a specified industrial authority (this includes any relevant enterprise agreement that may be made under the New South Wales Industrial Relations Act 1991); and
—An individual contract of employment which attracts the requisite entitlement to long service leave.

It should be noted that paragraph (b) the definition of "eligible employee" in clause 4 makes it plain that payments made to a number of employees who are "award free" will also be covered by the scheme.

In view of the erroneous comments made by the opposition spokesperson on industrial relations in another place, I would also like to make it abundantly clear that the funding arrangements do not discriminate between unionists and non unionists. Union membership is simply not a criteria for determining whether a person is to be regarded as an "eligible employee" for the purposes of the scheme.

For constitutional reasons it has not been possible to cover certain non award-based entitlements payable in certain states or by individual firms by tailoring the rate of levy to the circumstances in each participating state. There is nothing, however, in the scheme to prevent firms paying higher long service leave benefits where they see fit. In such cases they will not be able to claim reimbursement from the fund for payments in excess of normal entitlements.

Since this Bill was introduced in another place, representations have been received from the New South Wales Coal Association and the Queensland Mining Council about the meaning of the words used in paragraph (b) of the definition of "eligible employee" in clause 4.

The paragraph is co-extensive with five other paragraphs in clause 4 which together provide the basis for determining which employees in the Black Coal Mining Industry are to be covered by the National Scheme for securing funding of long service leave entitlements in the industry. Here, I note in passing, that the legislation does not itself create an entitlement to long service leave. The legislation merely provides for the creation of the fund upon which employers will be able, as the need arises, to draw to obtain reimbursement for payments made to eligible employees in respect of long service leave entitlements.

Concern has been expressed that the absence of the words "in the Black Coal Mining Industry" from the definition of eligible employee in paragraph (b) may be construed as having the effect of widening the definition to include persons not presently covered under long standing arrangements within the industry.

This is not the intended effect of the legislation. The words already appearing in paragraph in question, when read together with the objects of the act, which are set out in clause 3 of the legislation, limit the classes of worker who may be regarded as "eligible employees" for the purposes of the act to persons employed in the Black Coal Mining Industry. The addition of the words "in the Black Coal Mining Industry" to paragraph (b) accordingly serves no useful purpose.
The Government wishes to make it clear it is not its intention to extend the coverage of the scheme beyond persons who are currently regarded as being engaged in the Black Coal Mining Industry.

What may be described as the "boundaries" of the Black Coal Mining Industry vary within and between states and are to a significant extent determined by custom and practice reflecting a range of considerations.

The Bill accordingly provides for a means including or excluding limited numbers of workers from the scheme (but not from entitlements to long service leave) by regulation as is provided for under paragraphs (d) and (f) of clause 4. The Government will, reflecting the provisions of the legislation and the co-operative nature of the scheme, consult with representatives of all interests likely to be affected by the making of any such regulation.

This will allow the industry some flexibility in regulating its affairs, whilst safeguards to protect the interests of any individuals who may be affected are retained as regulations made in respect of the coverage of the scheme will, of course, be disallowable.

It is envisaged that the scheme is to be fully funded over a period of ten years including the unfunded liability for leave accrued prior 1 January 1993. Presently, it is estimated the initial levy will be in the vicinity of 6 per cent of payroll. The actual rate of levy will be precisely determined by an actuarial review conducted under the auspices of the corporation.
As I have already indicated, there are compelling reasons for continuing government involvement through a statutory corporation.
First, the new arrangements will substantially increase long service leave funding costs for many companies, especially by reason of the requirement to fully fund accrued liabilities.

The formation of a statutory corporation, rather than a private company, has enabled company income tax deductibility of contributions to the fund. The rates of payroll levy that are required to finance ongoing accruals of long service leave and to fund the accrued liability will impose significantly increased cost burdens on the industry. These rates of levy will, for some companies, equate to a cost of about 60 or 70 cents per tonne compared with the present 20 cents per tonne. The burden will fall most heavily on relatively labour intensive mines.

In view of the potential cost impact of the new arrangements on sections of the industry, particularly the requirement to achieve full funding, it is appropriate that the tax treatment of levy contributions to the new scheme should be as favourable as the tax treatment of payments under the current excise funding arrangements. As excise payments are deductible for company income tax purposes it is anticipated that there will be no additional cost to revenue.

The provision of tax deductibility for levy contributions also recognises that unlike most other employers, coal companies are being compelled to contribute to a long service leave fund. Other employers who make provision for their long service leave liabilities in the normal way retain the funds so provided as internal working capital. Deductibility of contributions will help offset the cost of replacing that working capital.

Secondly, the new long service leave scheme removes the inefficiencies and inequities associated with the present arrangements, and its full funding will ensure the portability and preservation of benefits. It is an important complementary component of the Government's Coal Industry Policy Reforms, which are designed to respond to changed circumstances and help secure the industry's future into the next century.
Thirdly, continuing Commonwealth involvement provides a guarantee of continuity and for a smooth transition to the privately funded scheme (or schemes) with a minimum of industrial friction.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.
