COAL RESEARCH ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1992

The purpose of this Bill is to transfer responsibility for coal research and development in Australia from a Commonwealth Government-run system to an industry funded and managed scheme. This new arrangement was announced by the Government on 2 December 1991 as part of a major package of institutional reform in the coal industry.

The principal Commonwealth Government mechanism for directing and coordinating energy research and development has been the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration Council. Coal research has been funded through the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration Council by the Coal Research Trust Account which was established by the Coal Research Assistance Act 1977.
Current funding arrangements for the Coal Research Trust Account is through the collection of a 5c per tonne excise on black coal production by the Excise Tariff Act 1921.

The new coal research and development (R & D) arrangements had their origins following a review of all Commonwealth-funded research arrangements within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy conducted in 1989. The aim of the Review was to define improvements which could be made to ensure that research programs continued to produce results that are relevant to industry requirements. A statutory research and development corporation model was chosen and has been adopted in most cases, however the coal industry opted to administer its own research and development.
There have been a number of the disadvantages associated with the existing Government imposed arrangements:
.the levy rate has tended to be regarded by some firms as a ceiling on research and development investments, rather than a minimum guaranteed level
.opportunities for firm-specific competitive advantage which might otherwise have been pursued through research and development have been obscured
.some firms have expressed a feeling of disenfranchisement from their R & D
.management's responsibility for each firm's R & D has been implicitly transferred to external authorities, making R & D less relevant in day-to-day-business decisions.

Agreement has been reached with the coal industry, through the Australian Coal Association, to transfer responsibility for coal research and development from the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration Council and the Coal Research Trust Account, to a new Coal Research Council to be run by the Australian Coal Association through the incorporated company Australian Coal Research Ltd.
This will involve Australian Coal Research Ltd assuming all financial and contractual assets and liabilities and obligations associated with the Coal Research Trust Account.
A detailed Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) has been signed between the Australian Coal Association and the Commonwealth to provide for the industry to fund and manage its own research.
In the MOU the Australian Coal Association undertakes:

PARA.TAB: (a) to maintain the total level of collective research funding in the coal industry at the same level per tonne as would have been collected each year under the current coal industry research levy of 5 cents per tonne produced;

(b) in raising this level of research funds, to take every measure to ensure that monies raised are not substituted for specific company-funded research expenditures. The research expenditures will be additional to those outlays undertaken by individual companies;
(c) to allocate research funds so raised, including interest earned, exclusively for the administration and execution of coal research and development activities;
(d) to administer funds in accordance with commercially acceptable and prudent practices, including provision of an annual audit by a certified public accountancy firm;

(e) to establish a body with the appropriate legal status (now Australian Coal Research Ltd) to assume from the Commonwealth all financial and contractual assets and liabilities associated with the Coal Research Trust Account, including responsibility for unfunded commitments;

(f) to liaise with other relevant research administrative bodies such as the Energy Research and Development Corporation, to ensure suitable collaboration and a reduction in unnecessary duplication where this arises. This may also result in joint funding of projects and sharing of results where appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: The aim of the amendments to the Coal Research Assistance Act 1977 is to put into effect the transfer of coal R & D from the Commonwealth to the coal industry. These amendments involve:
.Transferring to Australian Coal Research Ltd the monies, assets, liabilities and commitments (including unfunded commitments) associated with the Coal Research Trust Account.
.The transfer of existing research grant agreements and those completed projects for which there remain obligations including associated intellectual property rights
.Providing for the Commonwealth to take back responsibility for coal R & D in the unlikely event that for some reason or other, the industry is unable to fulfil its obligations.
In relation to the financial impact of the transfer, this involves the transfer of:

PARA.TAB: —the balance of the Coal Research Trust Account of around $8 million, with the coal industry taking responsibility for outstanding commitments of around $17.2 million of which about $9.2 million will be met from future revenues collected from the coal industry by Australian Coal Research Limited

—Commonwealth-owned equipment used by grantees until the completion of research contracts (this is then sold and the monies earned are reinvested in further research). Based on initial purchase price this equipment cost around $7.2 million
—computer equipment, data base and software (valued at around $35,000) currently used in grants administration.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Excise of 5c per tonne of coal produced, which funded the Coal Research Trust Account to the value of around $8 million per year, is being suspended through consequential amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921.

I would like to say how pleased I am to see such productive cooperation between the coal industry and the Government in organising the transfer of coal R & D from Government control to self management by the coal industry. This type of cooperation is another example of where the Government can encourage positive research in industry. I look forward to working together with the coal industry and to seeing the implementation of commercialisation of R & D in the industry.
The National Energy Research Development and Demonstration Program has done very good work in the past and this new legislation will add to the effectiveness of its work.
I believe this legislation sets the basis for collaborative industry-government approaches for the future.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
COAL TARIFF LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

The purpose of this Bill is to repeal the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Act 1975 and to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 which will put in place the reform measures for the coal sector announced by this Government on 2 December 1991.

One of the reform measures announced by the Government is the abolition of the Coal Export Duty. The duty was originally introduced in the early 1970s as a tax on windfall profits. Over the years the duty was modified and at present, coal which remains dutiable is high quality coking coal mined from depths no greater than 60 metres in open-cut mines which were in production before 30 June 1980. In practice, the duty affects six open-cut mines in Queensland operated by BHP Australia Coal Limited. This Government acknowledges that the duty is an anomaly in the current coal industry tax system.

The Government has therefore agreed to repeal the Coal Export Duty in return for BHP's commitment to invest $248 million in new capital expenditure, enhanced research and development and additional coal mine rehabilitation activities over the next five years. The program of commitments by BHP will have significant efficiency gains, improve regional employment opportunities and provide environmental benefits for Queensland.
The commitments will also add to the competitiveness of export operations of Australian coal at a time when Australia needs to explore all avenues of improved export performance.

This Government's decision to abolish the duty as part of a package of micro-economic reform for the Australian coal industry underpins the facilitating role this Government is prepared to play in working with industry to overcome sectoral impediments and promote industry development.
This Bill also amends the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to give effect to the Government's decision to reform the coal research and development arrangements and coalminers' long service leave arrangements.

The Commonwealth excise of 5 cents per tonne on coal produced which currently funds the Coal Research Trust Account to the value of around $8 million, will be suspended. The remaining Commonwealth excise of 20 cents per tonne on coal produced, which currently funds coalminers' long service leave will continue until a new payroll levy based scheme comes into effect.

There is a potential loss of gross revenue from abolition of the Coal Export Duty of $44.8 million in 1992-93 and $40.5 million in 1993-94. Suspension of the levy for research and development and the ultimate abolition of the long service leave levy will reduce Commonwealth receipts.

Legislation providing for the establishment of an industry-based coal research and development arrangement and a new national scheme for coalminers' long service leave are being introduced into the Senate as part of the Government's coal industry policy reform package.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
COAL INDUSTRY AMENDMENT BILL 1992
The purpose of this Bill is to reform the functions and activities of the Joint Coal Board.

This reform measure is part of a package of major policy reform measures for the coal sector announced by this Government on 2 December 1991. The aims of the reform package are to promote growth, employment and investment in the industry through the removal of unnecessary impediments to growth and change. The other reform measures to be considered by Parliament are :
—a new industry-based coal research and development arrangement;
—a new national scheme for coalminers' long service leave; and
—abolition of the Coal Export Duty.
This Bill will give effect to the Government's decision to refocus the functions and activities of the Board.

The Board was established under Commonwealth and New South Wales Coal Industry Acts of 1946. The New South Wales Government will be introducing its parallel bill to the State Parliament in the current Parliamentary session.

At the time that it was established, the Board was given extensive powers over industry development, mining, employment, and marketing to ensure adequate coal supplies in the post-war reconstruction era. Many of these powers have long since been unnecessary, and unused. The New South Wales coal industry has undergone extensive changes since 1947, moving from a domestic oriented industry to a premier coal exporter.
In October 1990, the Commonwealth and New South Wales Governments engaged Mr Bryan Kelman to undertake an independent review of the powers, functions and activities of the Board.

Based on Mr Kelman's review and subsequent consultations with industry parties and the Construction, Forestry and Mining Employees Union, both the Commonwealth and New South Wales Governments agreed that the Board's functions and activities would be rationalised and refocussed to concentrate on those areas where it has a demonstrated record of performance.
The decision to refocus the Board's powers and role in the industry will remove unnecessary duplication of functions between the Board and the State department responsible for mining matters.
The Bill provides for the Board to continue its powers, functions and activities in the following areas :
. administration of the Coal Industry Workers' Compensation scheme;

. provision of coalminers' occupational health and rehabilitation services, including the provision of preventive medical services, monitoring workers' health and investigating related health matters;
. promotion of the welfare of current and former workers in the industry, their families and communities in the coal mining areas;
. collection, collation and dissemination of accident and other statistics related to the health and welfare of workers engaged in the coal industry;
. provision of advice and information to Ministers and others on coalminers' health and welfare;
. report to Ministers and the Chief Inspector of Coal Mines as it thinks fit on matters of safety;
. provision of international training/educational courses in coal under the auspices of the Australian aid program and international development agencies; and
. collection of industry statistics until such time as both the Commonwealth and State Ministers otherwise direct.

The Board will also continue to monitor, promote and specify adequate training standards relating to health and safety for mineworkers until such time as effective alternative arrangements are operating to the satisfaction of portfolio Ministers.

Both Governments have recognised the very valuable work which the Board has done in relation to coalminers' health and welfare. The Board will therefore continue to monitor dust levels until the industry parties can satisfy Ministers with portfolio responsibility that there are suitable and effective alternative arrangements which may warrant a transfer of this function.

The effect of the Bill is to remove unnecessary duplication of functions between the Board and the State, and to bring to an end the Board's powers, functions and activities in a number of areas, namely :
—control over the rate of development of the coal industry in New South Wales, particularly attempts to match supply and demand; and
—coal resource utilisation, mining, marketing and management issues within the State.

Future Board membership will formalise the current arrangement which is, an independent Chairperson, an employees' representative and an employers' representative. However, the terms of appointment will be changed. The Act provides for a maximum term of appointment of seven years on a full-time basis for all Board members. The Bill will amend this to a maximum of three years on either a full-time or part-time basis.

As it stands now, policy direction to the Board can only be issued from the Prime Minister in agreement with the Premier of New South Wales. The Bill will place the Board under the direct control of both Commonwealth and State portfolio Ministers responsible for the coal industry. Provisions have been made in the Bill to improve the Board's standards of accountability in line with contemporary practice.

From 1992/93, the Board will become largely self-funding for its continuing operations. The workers' compensation insurance, health, and welfare activities will be funded from existing resources accumulated by the Board and from future premium and other income. The other functions will be operated on a cost recovery basis. In 1991/92, the Commonwealth share for the Board's operations is $2.463M. This includes funding for the Coal Industry Tribunal which has previously been provided through the Board. Funding for the Coal Industry Tribunal will continue, and is estimated at $570,000 for 1992/93.

The reforms to the Joint Coal Board embodied in this Bill ensure continuation of its high standard of delivery of services to employees in the New South Wales coal industry. The health and welfare of industry employees will in no way be compromised by this reform. Both Governments believe that the elimination of overlap with State activities and bringing the operations of the Board into sharper focus will assist the efficient operation of the State's most important export industry.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL 1992TERRITORIES LAW REFORM BILL 1992AUSTRALIAN SPORTS DRUG AGENCY AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: That the following Bills be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the National Crime Authority Act 1984; a Bill for an Act to reform the law of the Territory of Christmas Island and of the Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands, and for other purposes; a Bill for an Act to amend the Australian Sports and Drug Agency Act 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL 1992

The purpose of the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill 1992 is to amend section 37 of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 to allow the chairman and other members of the Authority to be re-appointed, up to a maximum period of appointment of four years. At present, while all categories of members of the Authority may be initially appointed for up to a maximum period of four years, only a member appointed for the purpose of dealing with a particular reference or references, may be re-appointed.

In its report "Who is to Guard the Guards?", the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority recommended, at paragraph 3.89, that the Government should ensure that the terms of appointment of members allow for an overlap of membership and that a complete change of membership of the Authority at one time be avoided. The Government can act to implement this recommendation by taking account of it when making appointments and determining length of appointment. However the current situation facing the Authority shows that there is a need for greater flexibility in the legislation controlling appointments.

Mr Justice Phillips resigned his position as Chairman of the National Crime Authority on 17 December 1991 to take up his appointment as Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Victoria. Mr Tom Sherman took up the position of Chairman on 26 February 1992. In accordance with section 7 of the Act the Authority has two other members (Mr Greg Cusack QC based in Sydney and Mr Julian Leckie based in Melbourne) and one member specially appointed in relation to particular references (Mr Malcolm Gray QC based in Adelaide). The terms of appointment for Mr Cusack QC and Mr Leckie end on 30 June 1992.

It would create serious problems for the Authority to lose both Mr Cusack QC and Mr Leckie on 30 June 1992. Both members are heavily involved in current references. Mr Sherman has only recently been appointed as Chairman and Mr Gray QC, although he has been a member for almost twelve months, has necessarily been confined to a limited aspect of the Authority's operations. The further complication is that, as a result of Mr Justice Phillips' unexpected resignation, the Authority (in the absence of Messrs Cusack QC and Leckie) would lack members with any significant tenure and experience.

It is Government policy, reflected in the National Crime Authority Act 1984, that no member of the Authority should serve for a period longer than four years. That policy is currently enshrined in section 37 of the National Crime Authority Act 1984, and this Bill makes no change to that.

However, as the Act presently stands, it is not possible to re-appoint members of the Authority, except for members specially appointed in relation to particular references, even if the initial term was for a period less than four years.
The fact that one class of member can be re-appointed while others cannot is an anomaly which the Bill will correct.

In spite of best planning, the current circumstances facing the Authority show that it is not possible to give a guarantee that continuity and overlap of membership can be provided for administratively. The Bill provides the Government with additional legislative flexibility to assist it in ensuring continuity and loss of expertise.

This Bill has been brought on as a matter of urgency, as the Government wishes to re-appoint both Mr Cusack QC and Mr Leckie for additional periods as members of the National Crime Authority, and that will have to be done before 30 June. The initial appointments of both members was for a period of three years, and the additional appointments will be such as to ensure that the total period of appointment is no more than four years.
Financial impact
The proposals put forward in this Bill will have no impact on Government expenditure.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
TERRITORIES LAW REFORM BILL 1992

Mr President, this Bill represents a substantial portion of the legislative action flowing from the Government's response to the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in its report Islands in the Sun—The Legal Regimes of Australia's External Territories and the Jervis Bay Territory.

For Australia's Indian Ocean Territories of Christmas and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, this Bill represents a giant step forward in the task the Government began in 1984 of bringing standards and living conditions in these Territories into line with those of comparable communities elsewhere in Australia.

Mr President, the inadequacy of the existing legal regimes in the Indian Ocean Territories derives from the fact that when the Territories became Australian Territories in the 1950s, their Imperial and Singapore-derived laws were largely left in force. To this base were added local Ordinances and a small number of Commonwealth Acts.

It is widely recognised that the resulting legal regimes are seriously deficient, unfair and inappropriate. These bodies of law have been severely criticised by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, the Federal Court, the Territories' Supreme Courts, Human Rights Australia, the Director of Public Prosecutions, and the Commonwealth Grants Commission. The regimes as they stand also obstruct the Government's objectives of extending to Territories' residents the same rights and opportunities as other Australians enjoy.

Mr President, in 1984 the Government invited the United Nations to supervise an Act of Self-Determination in Cocos. The Cocos Islanders were given three choices—independence, integration with an existing country, or free association with an existing country. They voted overwhelmingly for integration with Australia.

The United Nations definition of integration requires that the people of Cocos receive the same treatment and have the same obligations, rights and benefits as mainland Australians. In the lead-up to the Act of Self-Determination, the Commonwealth promised that living standards would be brought to mainland standards not later than 1994. The Government is well on track to meet that timetable.

The Commonwealth Grants Commission has been used as the arbiter over the changes required. In August 1990 the Government generally accepted the Commission's recommendations to bring government programs, works, services and taxes into line with those on mainland Australia.

The proposed changes were discussed in detail in extensive consultations with the Cocos Malay community leaders. They were incorporated in a Memorandum of Understanding, which was formally signed by the then Prime Minister and Cocos community leaders in March 1991. The M.O.U. provides for upgrading of Government works and services, restructuring of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council and the Cocos Islands Co-operative, financial assistance to the Council, major law reform, extension of taxation and introduction of mainland employment conditions. These changes are being introduced over three years to be completed on 1 July 1992.
Mr President, the application of a contemporary body of mainland law is fundamental to the changes which are being put in place.

In 1984 the Government also began the process of bringing conditions on Christmas Island into line with those in mainland Australia. Since then, a form of local government has been extended to the Island and mainland wages and employment conditions have been aligned progressively with mainland standards. Mainland social security benefits and health care arrangements now extend to the Island.

As with Cocos, a Package of Changes has been developed in consultation with the local community to extend to residents of Christmas Island rights, opportunities and obligations equivalent to comparable mainland communities, including similar local and State-type government structures, assistance programs, taxes and charges.

Again, Mr President, the application of a living body of mainland law is fundamental to the changes to be put in place. Not only will it give Island residents the rights and protections under the law enjoyed by their mainland counterparts but it will provide the legal infrastructure necessary for development and economic growth in the Territory.

The process of bringing standards and conditions in the Territories into line with those on the mainland has been developed and implemented in close consultation with the Islands communities. A great deal of effort has been devoted to informing the communities about the new legal arrangements and encouraging public debate with the aim of ensuring that the special circumstances of the Islands are accommodated by modifying laws where necessary. Western Australian government departments and agencies are helping with education programs. Information about the new legal regime is being disseminated through newsletters, radio and television broadcasts, visits by experts and public meetings. Independent legal advisers are also being attached to each of the communities.

It should be understood that while this Bill will replace the essentially Singapore based regime with a Western Australian based body of law, this regime will still be subject to modification by Ordinance under the Christmas Island Act and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act. A number of Ordinances are to come into force in conjunction with commencement of this Bill. The most important will deal with interpretation of Western Australian laws in their application to the Territories, and modification of those laws to suit the particular circumstances of the Territories. A further Ordinance will be introduced for Cocos to abolish the Trust under which land is currently held by the Cocos Council, which will enable mainland-style land dealings to take place. The abolition of the Trust in favour of freehold title has the strong support of the Cocos Community.
Additional Ordinances may be required in the future as the consultation process continues and modifications are required to overcome unforeseen problems or situations peculiar to the Territories.

This Bill applies Western Australian law, as in force from time to time, as Commonwealth law. That is to say, the laws will be in force by virtue of Acts made by this Parliament, rather than by force of the Western Australian Parliament. As such the political responsibility for the applied law will continue to rest with the Commonwealth.

The communities in the Territories will be able to influence these Commonwealth processes through their Members of Parliament. They will also be able to make representations direct to the Commonwealth Minister responsible for the Territories. In addition, mechanisms are being developed to facilitate the Islands communities' awareness of the passage of legislation through the Western Australian Parliament and access to more detailed explanation of the effects of legislation on the Territories.

Non-judicial powers and duties under the applied Western Australian laws will be vested in the Commonwealth Minister administering the Christmas Island Act and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act. The Minister will be able to direct that particular powers be vested in other persons or authorities, provided they fall within a range of classes specified in this Bill. The Minister will also be able to delegate powers to such persons or authorities.

Judicial powers and duties will initially be vested in the existing courts of the Territories. (The Family Court of Western Australia will exercise jurisdiction under the Family Law Act 1975 from 1 July 1992, as a result of extension of that Act to the Territories; it will be the only Western Australian court having jurisdiction in respect of the Territories at that date.) The Government's preferred position, for a series of reasons including consistency, is for all Western Australian courts to have jurisdiction. It is anticipated that the courts of Western Australia will have the jurisdiction of the Territories conferred on them in the near future—that is, when formal agreement with Western Australia has been reached. This Bill sets out provisions, to commence on a date to be proclaimed, to allow the jurisdiction to be transferred to Western Australian courts. This conferral of jurisdiction will allow the abolition of the courts of the Territories other than the Supreme Courts. The Supreme Courts will continue to exist, though with truncated jurisdiction, until there is no longer any serving judge.

Mr President, there are some 700 Acts of Western Australia. It is expected that some 350 Western Australian laws can be applied in full from 1 July 1992 without adverse impact. Approximately another 140 laws will have noticeable impacts but the on-Islands changes required can be readily accommodated from 1 July 1992. These two categories include the bulk of criminal law which was the source of much concern in the Islands in the Sun report.
A small number of Western Australian Acts will be repealed in their application to the Territories, where they are completely inappropriate or contrary to Commonwealth policy.

A further body of Western Australian Acts will have their operation suspended by Ordinance. The Bill specifically provides for suspension of applied laws by Ordinance, to enable further assessment and consultation, with either or both the Island communities and the Western Australian authorities, on any modification required. This course of action accords with the thrust of the Islands in the Sun report that consultation should occur to ensure the particular circumstances of the Indian Ocean Territories and their residents are not adversely affected by the extension of the laws.

It is expected that some 120 laws may fall into this category. The intention is that they be suspended in their application until 1 January 1993 to allow individuals and organisations time to consider them in more detail and to prepare themselves for the impact of these laws. However, it will be possible to further suspend these Acts at 1 January 1993, or to repeal or modify them in their application in the Territories.

The remaining Acts will be modified in their application to the Territories by Territories Ordinances. Some are changed permanently in their effect so as to better suit the Territories. Amendment of others is temporary to allow the residents and businesses of the Territories a reasonable opportunity to make adjustments necessary to comply with new requirements under some laws.

The choice of Western Australian law, rather than some other body of State type law, was made as it is clearly the most appropriate to be applied to the Territories. The proximity of Western Australia to the Territories and the existing linkages were key considerations. Shipping and air services originate in Perth. Western Australia is the main source of the Islands food, medical and other supplies. But most importantly Western Australia is now the home of many former Cocos and Christmas Islanders. More people of Cocos and Christmas Island origin have chosen to live in Western Australia than remain on the Islands.

Federal law is also being generally extended to the Indian Ocean Territories by this Bill by reversing the current rule that a Federal Act only extends if it is expressed to extend. From 1 July this year a Federal Act will extend unless it is expressed to not extend.

This Bill will also amend the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 so that `Australia' and `the Commonwealth', when used in the geographic sense, will include the Christmas and Cocos Islands, unless the contrary intention is specified. As part of making this change, this Bill amends a number of Federal Acts, to ensure they extend, or prevent their extension at this time. After 1 July only a small number of Federal Acts will not extend to the Islands.

Apart from the matters relating to the Indian Ocean Territories, another significant recommendation of the Islands in the Sun report was that Australian citizens resident on Norfolk Island be given the right of optional enrolment for the purposes of representation in the Federal Parliament.
I am pleased to be able to inform the Senate that agreement has been reached with the Norfolk Island Government on implementation of this recommendation.

Unfortunately, however, it has not been possible within the time available to include the necessary amendments to give effect to the agreement in this Bill. However, I understand that the appropriate legislative amendments are being prepared by the Minister for the Arts and Territories for introduction into the Parliament in the near future.

This Bill will, in Part 4, regularise payments of additional salary received by certain executive members of the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly during 1989. The full Federal Court has held that as a result of a technical deficiency in the relevant Remuneration Tribunal Determination, the executive members concerned were paid additional salary over a period of approximately six months which was not authorised. There is no suggestion of personal dishonesty or impropriety by the members involved. They merely accepted the additional remuneration in accordance with what they understood to be their legal entitlement.

Consistent with the policy of the gradual transfer of further powers to the Norfolk Island Government, schedule 5 to the Bill seeks to remove the requirement that the remuneration and allowances of members of the Legislative Assembly be determined by the Commonwealth Remuneration Tribunal.

The Norfolk Island Government has established its own Public Sector Remuneration Tribunal which, subject to these amendments, will assume the role of fixing the remuneration of MLAs, executive members and other Assembly office-holders.
The Norfolk Island Government operates its own fiscus and these proposed amendments will have no effect on Commonwealth revenues or expenditure.

The direct cost of changing the legal regimes of Christmas and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands is negligible. However, indirect costs, especially over the first five years are substantial. These indirect costs are associated with the Government's commitment to bring the conditions on the Islands up to a standard comparable with the rest of mainland Australia.

The costings have two components—recurrent costs and capital works. Under the new legal regime, while total net recurrent costs will increase over the next two years, they will then reduce to below the 1991-92 level. In fact, net recurrent costs (1991-92 values) should reduce from $18.707m in 1991-92 to $14.825m per annum by 1996-97, and should remain at about that level in subsequent years.

A substantial capital works program is required on the Islands to bring infrastructure up to mainland standards. Approval has been given for the allocation of $37m for the most urgent of these works on Christmas Island from 1992-93 to 1996-97. Those works and the remainder of a Christmas Island Rebuilding Program worth $132.85m over 10 years are currently being examined by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works.
Proposals for capital works for the Cocos (Keeling) Islands are currently being prepared.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN SPORTS DRUG AGENCY AMENDMENT BILL 1992
Mr President, it is with a great deal of pleasure that I introduce the Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill in the Senate.
PURPOSE OF THE BILL
This Bill is for an Act to amend the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990. These amendments have become necessary due to recent developments overseas and in Australia.
BACKGROUND

Honourable senators are no doubt familiar with the recent publicity concerning an Australian cyclist who tested positive for anabolic steroids and subsequently was able to avoid sanctions on a legal technicality. This has made the Government determined to ensure that athletes who cheat on their fellow competitors, their sport and themselves are not able to escape the sanctions they justly deserve. The amendments to the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act proposed in this Bill will do just that.
The Bill also makes provision for a co-ordinated and national approach to the elimination of drug abuse in sport.

Honourable senators may not know that over the past eighteen months there have been extensive discussions on the subject of complementary State and Territory anti-doping legislation. At the meeting of all State and Territory sports Ministers last year, Mrs Kelly was able to achieve unanimous agreement that such complementary legislation is desirable, and each State and Territory sports Minister gave a commitment to introduce such legislation. This Bill enables the Commonwealth to honour its undertaking to provide for that complementary legislation.

Mr President, Australia is at the leading edge of international developments in the fight against drugs in sport. Before this year, it had executed international antidoping arrangements with Canada and the United Kingdom. This year New Zealand and Norway have joined Australia. A strategy to expand the list of participating countries is being developed. One of the Australian Sports Drug Agency's functions is to ensure Australia's compliance with these arrangements. This Bill will ensure that the agency has the necessary authority to perform this function.
MAJOR FEATURES OF THE BILL
I would like to spend a little time advising honourable senators of the details of the proposed amendments.

As I have indicated this Bill makes provision for the Australian States and Territories to confer broader powers on the Australian Sports Drug Agency through complementary antidoping legislation currently proposed by all States and Territories. It will also allow the Agency to work more closely with the States and Territories to ensure a consistent and comprehensive approach towards the elimination of prohibited drugs and doping methods in sport.

The Australian Sports Drug Agency will now test, both in Australia and overseas, a wider range of athletes for the presence of prohibited drugs. This will include foreign athletes when the test is sought by an overseas anti-doping authority, or when the test is conducted under a contractual arrangement which the Australian Sports Drug Agency may now enter into.

The Agency must be able to recognise procedures adopted by foreign anti-doping authorities which conduct tests on its behalf so it can act on the result of those tests. These amendments will enable the procedures followed by such an authority to be recognised for the purposes of the Act, even if these procedures do not precisely mirror those set out in the Australian Sports Drug Agency regulations. The minimum standard to be adopted and recognised in such cases will now be that provided for in the International Olympic Charter against doping in sport. This does not mean that there is anything wrong with the current regulations; it is merely an amendment which acknowledges that the Australian procedures are stricter and more precise than the internationally accepted standard of the Olympic Charter.

Mr President, the Bill also provides athletes with the opportunity to make a submission to the Agency challenging the validity of a positive test result, if the athlete considers that procedures in the following specified areas were not complied with:

PARA.TAB: sealing of the container holding the sample;
testing of the sample by an accredited laboratory; or
evidence of tampering with the sample.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Agency decides the test was valid, the competitor will be entitled to apply to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) to have the decision reviewed. If the AAT reverses the Agency's decision, the competitor's name must be removed from the register.

Even if the athlete does not make a submission, the Agency will be required to verify that all procedures relating to these specific matters were followed before validating a positive test result. It will no longer be required to check procedures where noncompliance would not cast doubt on the test result.

Other amendments provide for written notification to approved sporting and anti-doping organisations of a positive test result or a refusal to provide a sample. Where this is not possible, alternative arrangements have been provided so that athletes cannot hinder the process by purposely avoiding the notice.

Many international sporting federations require advice of a possible positive test result to satisfy their own doping policy. This Bill will enable the Agency to satisfy such requests in certain specified circumstances.

The name of the register will be changed to `Register of Notifiable Events'. This will reduce the misconception that the entry of a person's name on the register implies some finding of `guilt'. The notion of guilt was never intended to be associated with the entry of names on the register. The question of guilt and application of sanctions is and has always been a matter for sporting organisations, not the agency.

Mr President, this Bill recognises the need to give minors special consideration, by providing for the removal of a name from the register once the period of any sanction imposed by sporting organisations has elapsed, if at the time of the request to provide a sample the person was under 18 years of age.

The Australian Sports Drug Agency is increasingly being recognised overseas and domestically as having the professional expertise to arrange for the collection and testing of samples to detect the presence of prohibited drugs, and therefore will be called on more and more to arrange such tests overseas and in Australia, at the request of both overseas and Australian authorities and sporting organisations. This Bill includes amendments which will give it the power to enter into contracts or arrangements with overseas governments and other sporting authorities and antidoping authorities to arrange for the collection and testing of samples.

Under the current international anti-doping arrangements with Canada, the United Kingdom, New Zealand and Norway each country has agreed that in another country, their athletes will be subject to the domestic testing regime of the host country. As a result, there will be occasions when, even though the agency has made no request for a test, it will receive information on the results of tests on Australian athletes conducted by overseas anti-doping authorities. It may also receive similar information from other foreign anti-doping bodies. The Bill includes amendments which enable the Agency to pass this information to the same persons or organisations that it would pass similar information to if it had conducted the test. These include the athlete, the sporting organisations of which the athlete is a member and, if Commonwealth funding through the Australian Sports Commission is involved, the Commission. However, it may only pass this information on if it is satisfied that, at the time the sample was requested, the anti-doping body was following procedures which were in accord with the Olympic Charter.

There are many anti-doping bodies throughout the world. For example, as international sporting federations arrange for the collection and testing of samples for the purpose of detecting prohibited substances, each could be regarded as an anti-doping body. As more and more countries adopt similar anti-doping regimes to Australia, the number of anti-doping bodies will increase dramatically. Some may not be as meticulous and thorough as the Australian Sports Drug Agency. To ensure the interests of Australian athletes are protected, the Agency will have to screen these anti-doping bodies to ensure that their procedures accord with the international accepted standard, that is, the Olympic Charter. The amendments allow the Australian Sports Drug Agency to approve foreign anti-doping bodies which adopt at least standards provided for in the Olympic Charter and will be required to maintain a list of such bodies. The Agency will also be given the power to request such an approved body to take a sample from a competitor who is an Australian citizen or permanent resident when that competitor is overseas.
FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT

There will be no additional financial obligations imposed on the Commonwealth by this Bill. Any additional costs arising from the Agency entering into contracts or arrangements with overseas sporting organisations or anti-doping bodies will be fully recovered, while the cost of additional tests, resulting from complementary legislation passed by States and Territories, will be borne by the States and Territories.
Mr President, I commend this Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO COMMERCIAL ACTIVITIES AND OTHER MATTERS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a resolution from the Legislative Assembly of Western Australia requesting access by the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities and Other Matters to Australian Taxation Office records.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The receipt of the resolution of 14 May from the Western Australian Legislative Assembly squarely points to the dismal record of this Labor Government, and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in particular, in a desperate campaign of bluster and prevarication seeking to deny vital information to the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government in Western Australia. The significance of these actions is not diminished by the enforced retreat of Mr Keating on 15 May, by the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) that amendments to the Taxation Administration Act have `accommodated the WA Royal Commission's particular reporting requirements' or the fact that the principal solicitor of the Royal Commission has stated that the commissioners believed that the proposed amendments would satisfy their requirements. One only has to look at exactly what they have had to go through to get these particular amendments.

PARA.TAB: What this resolution from the Legislative Assembly calls for, no more and no less, is a repeat of the action taken in December 1987 when the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill amended both the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Taxation Administration Act to enable, as it was stated by the then Attorney-General, the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct to have access to taxation information on the same basis as applies to taxation information disclosed to the Commonwealth royal commissions.

The amendment then also gave the Commissioner authority to disclose the information to State as well as Commonwealth law enforcement agencies. The purpose of these amendments was very simple and very direct. Mr Bowen stated on 8 December 1987 that there was `genuine public interest' in the provision of Commonwealth assistance to the Fitzgerald Commission. But we can only ask why, until now, this public interest has not been applied in regard to Western Australia in the mind of the same government. Could the overriding consideration be that, on this occasion, mates are involved?

The fact remains that until 14 May, the Western Australian Labor Government and the Keating Labor Government were stating falsely that the Royal Commission could have obtained access to tax records under provision for such information to be disclosed to senior law enforcement officers under section 3E of the Taxation Administration Act 1989. It is a fact that this Labor Government sought to enforce one rule for a royal commission that was investigating the misdeeds of its political opponents and another for an inquiry seeking to uncover the incompetence and corruption that occurred under Labor governments in Western Australia.

It is a fact that the resolution of the Legislative Assembly in Western Australia does more than simply ask the Federal Parliament to facilitate necessary access to Australian Taxation Office records by the Royal Commission. Quite properly the Assembly insists that the Royal Commission be given the same right as was the Fitzgerald Royal Commission through the 1987 Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill. That eventually has been the Labor Government's position in Western Australia, asking the Labor Federal Government to actually do something. But it has taken its time. It has taken the State Labor Government all its time to ask for this and it has taken the Federal Labor Government all its time to deliver. But this is the principle that is at stake—the right of the people and the Parliament of Western Australia to be sure that there is no diminution whatsoever of the rights of access given to another inquiry in a State in 1987. This is a clear signal that the legislation promised by this Government must not in any way be more limited than that carried in 1987 when of course Mr Keating was Treasurer.

The legislation was supported by the Opposition and during debate it was noted that the same cooperation should be extended to future similar inquiries involving State Government actions. We in the Liberal and National parties supported the Government's action in providing the information to the Fitzgerald Royal Commission in Queensland, and yet here we have a situation where this Government simply closed the door, put on the blinkers and tried to blame the Public Service for the lack of access to the information for Western Australia.
It was as Treasurer that on 21 May 1991 Mr Keating replied to the request of the Western Australian Royal Commission for access to tax records:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . for reasons of good tax administration the Government is strongly of the view that the current level of secrecy of income tax information should not be disturbed.

Good tax administration indeed! He insultingly stated that a request could be made when related to a specific offence when in fact the information had been sought because of the difficulty encountered by the Commission in determining illegal conduct in relation to the Rothwells saga and money trails were disappearing overseas. We are not talking about $50 or $100 in these money trails going overseas; we are talking about $500m that has disappeared from Rothwells, and this Labor Government prevaricated on whether or not it would give access to Australian Taxation Office records.

PARA.TAB: It is also a fact that has been glossed over by Mr Keating that such requests should refer to the availability of tax records after a commission has completed its inquiry and subsequent criminal investigations are being made. Is that not handy? He says that we can have it after the event but not before. The fact is that in section 3E of the Taxation Administration Act 1989 allows only an officer of a law enforcement agency to divulge or communicate taxation information for the purpose of investigation of a serious offence. The Prime Minister and his Government well understand that a royal commission's inquiries go to a far wider sense than this and that that is the royal commission's right and proper role.

How convenient also for a Government determined to protect its mates to hide behind the advice of public servants who, quite predictably and quite correctly, wish to preserve secrecy. Who was Mr Keating trying to bluff, con or cajole when he stated that people were more likely to disclose information voluntarily when they were satisfied that the use of the information would be limited? That is hardly an attitude that anyone would expect from people desperately seeking to avoid investigation.

And let us not forget the selective amnesia that Messrs Brian and Terry Burke have had, along with Mr Peter Dowding and Mr David Parker; all either former Premiers or senior Ministers. Who would be silly enough to believe that they would suddenly tell all? They have no recollection of most of the events that have happened about which they have been questioned in the Royal Commission, yet the Prime Minister tries to say that they would be quite happy to voluntarily disclose the information that is required. Clearly, it was the duty of a responsible Federal government to make the decision to ensure that highly comparable inquiries receive the same degree of cooperation from the Australian Taxation Office.

Who can be fooled by the subsequent letter of the Hon. Ralph Willis as Acting Treasurer, responding to a further request from the Commission of 29 August last year—which I might add was never answered by Treasurer Kerin—that the granting of access to the Fitzgerald Commission should not be seen as a precedent for all State royal commissions? Nothing better illustrates the determination of the Government as a whole in blocking necessary access to information to protect its mates. That is the clarity of the whole matter that we are dealing with. Indeed, it is just as true to state that a new precedent was created by the refusal of this Labor Government to follow the example taken with the Fitzgerald Commission and other Commonwealth royal commissions where access to income tax records has been granted.

Under section 16 of the Taxation Assessment Act, the Commissioner of Taxation has authority to pass on information to a royal commission acting in respect of letters patent issued by the Governor-General.

The resolution tabled today from the Western Australian Legislative Assembly seeks the same rights for the Western Australian Royal Commission. It is not asking for anything more; it is simply asking for the same treatment. That can never be considered unreasonable. In turn, the Royal Commission, under section 16(4A) has the right to communicate the information to a special prosecutor. It must be emphasised that this request from the Royal Commission has not arisen through some peripheral question. Investigation into the collapse of Rothwells was one of the most significant tasks of the inquiry, as it is well understood that it is a central matter of WA Inc that directly involved two former Premiers and leading Ministers.

The stalling by Mr Keating and successive Labor Treasurers last year is every bit as serious as the outburst of the Prime Minister on 14 May, as the time available for the Commission to complete its investigations is now severely limited. I suppose if one can hold off for long enough and hope that no-one twigs to it, then one gets away with it. But, unfortunately, on this occasion the Government has not got away with it.

It was an insult not only to the Royal Commission but also to the Western Australian Parliament and to the people of Western Australia when Mr Keating poured scorn on the Commission for engaging in a fishing expedition. In some respects, a lot of people in the Labor Government, when it so suits them, would say that that is the real role of a royal commission. It suited them with the Fitzgerald Royal Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct to have a fishing expedition but, of course, on this occasion when it comes to the Western Australian investigation into WA Inc. it does not suit them.

The Prime Minister made a personal attack on leading counsel assisting the Commission in describing his submission as `offensive and self-serving'. He advanced the spurious excuse that 1989 legislative changes would have allowed police attached to the Commission to seek information from the Tax Commissioner. What rot! He does not understand—and of course the Premier obviously does not understand—that today that is what it is all about.

Police attached to the Commission did not of course include the Commissioner and did not, therefore, have the seniority to request or indeed pass on any such information. Once the four police officers work with the Royal Commission, they become Royal Commission investigators and have no entitlement to seek taxation records under the Tax Administration Act.

Ignoring this fact, Mr Keating sought to erode the public standing of the Commission by alleging that these officers were feuding with Commission staff, which they were not, and accused the Commission of provoking political controversy for having the temerity to finally make public a major impediment to its investigations nearly 12 months after their initial request had been denied. Here we have a government talking about provoking political controversy. If that is not what this Government is doing about this issue, then I ask what is it doing.

Again, there was not much respect shown to the Western Australian Parliament when Mr Keating stated that the request of the Premier, Dr Lawrence, for the information was `not worth taking seriously'. The Prime Minister just dismissed out of hand the requests by Dr Lawrence, the Labor Premier of Western Australia. Of course, he also absolutely ignored the Labor member Ron Edwards who himself has admitted that he knew more than he told at the time. He has admitted that to the Royal Commission. Why did he not come clean up-front about what he knew about a lot of the funds?

While Mr Keating may have bowed to the public pressure the next day, I certainly do not recall any statement of apology for the aspersions cast on the competence and integrity of the Royal Commission. He just cast those aspersions against that Royal Commission, which has been doing a fine job under extremely difficult circumstances—little did we know how difficult until a couple of weeks ago—and he has not had the decency to even apologise. I am certain that that is not just a further case of bad manners but a deliberate hope that some doubt would remain in the public mind as to the authority of the Commission.

I can tell the Senate that there is no doubt about the authority of the Commission by people in Western Australia. They hold the Commission in the highest regard. They know what they have unearthed. They know what they are dealing with. They know where the money has gone. They know the people who have been involved in corruption. They will decide for themselves. In short, Mr Keating was not simply engaged in an exercise of denying information to the Royal Commission but also in politicising it and undermining its credibility.

The State Labor Government cannot escape its share of blame when on 13 May the Premier had defended Mr Keating in State Parliament by repeating the Keating line that the Royal Commission could obtain direct access to files through the police. Why did she not check that that was possible before standing up in the Western Australian Parliament and just repeating Mr Keating's lines for the sake of it? If she had bothered to check, she would have found out that those police officers would have faced imprisonment had they done what she and Mr Keating suggested. But that was not significant enough for her either. She suddenly obviously realised the error of her ways the next day but did not bother apologising, did not bother explaining; she just decided that maybe she had better join the public request of making sure that the Federal Labor Government made this information available.

We are entitled to ask whether Dr Lawrence and Mr Keating knew of the difficulties encountered by the Commission over the previous 12 months and what actions they took in seeking access to tax records. What a difference a day makes, though. Recognising that a government that cannot rely on Assembly numbers must bow to the inevitable, the resolution before the Senate today went forward one day later, on 14 May. It was purely and simply based on the number of Independents now in the Western Australian Parliament. They could not rely on them sticking by them, and they certainly could not rely on the people of Western Australia sticking by them.

The Premier also stated on 14 May the obvious fact that the interests of the Royal Commission transcend those of the privacy of the tax records. She, of course, has said nothing about the part that the public outrage played in the reversal of her opinion. Quite clearly, that was a pressure that was put on her that she could not ignore. We may question, of course, the commitment of Mr Keating to the cause of privacy when a senior Minister in his Government, the current Minister for Social Security, Dr Blewett, once belittled privacy as a bourgeois right when he was seeking to impose the horrendous Australia Card.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—Yes, it is disgraceful, and it goes right the way through this Government. Privacy is okay as long as it has something to do with one's mates, but when it has something to do with one's political opponents privacy just goes straight out the door. But, of course, again there is one set of rules for Labor mates and there is another set of rules for everybody else.

PARA.TAB: The resolution of the Western Australian Legislative Assembly is crystal clear. The Royal Commission may now feel satisfied with the access that it expects to obtain, but it is essential that the Federal legislation gives it no less access than was granted to the Fitzgerald Commission in 1987. I believe that failure to so act will be further confirmation of the bias and cynicism shown by this Labor Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a few occasions in the past I have taken the opportunity of the adjournment debate to present to the Senate an account of the use or misuse of chemicals in Australia. Tonight I add to that portfolio with the documentation of an incident of spraying insecticides which has had a devastating effect on a school in Hobart.

PARA.TAB: The D'Alton Special School in New Town has 64 students from kindergarten to grade 7, all with a variety of physical disabilities. On Sunday, 4 August 1991, the inside of the school was routinely sprayed for Argentine ants. Two commercial brands of spray were used, Cislin 10, containing deltamethrin, formaldehyde and propylene glycol, and Insectagas D, containing dichlorvus and liquid carbon dioxide. The school had previously been sprayed on two occasions earlier in the school year.

On the following Monday school began as normal, and at 10.30 a.m. a phone call from the Douglas Parker Rehabilitation Centre, to which the school is annexed, asked that the children not be allowed contact with the floor. At about 11 a.m., after children had been picked up from the floor—remember that most of these children suffer from a variety of physical disabilities—the first toxic reactions began, with some people's throats closing up, severe headaches being suffered and eyes also being affected. Over the next few days these symptoms became progressively worse, until almost all of the staff were affected, some to the point of requiring time off from school duties.

On 9 August, Neocid 200, containing diazanon in a coarse spray, was sprayed around the outside of the school building, including alongside the walls, with the school windows open. From that point in time the severity and frequency of the reactions began to increase and a few people became quite frighteningly ill. So many people at the school were affected severely that officialdom finally decided to conduct an investigation.

The Director of Public Health announced to the victims and the media, which had become interested at this stage, that everybody at the school was suffering from some form of the winter virus that was prevalent at the time and that the coincidence of the insecticide spraying had simply produced an emotive reaction. When the problem continued, the school was eventually evacuated, not because of a problem with the environment but to allay peoples' concerns.

However, what made this virus particularly interesting were the unusual variety of features displayed in the one strain as those features were collated by the Director when interviewing personnel. These features included the symptoms of headache, irritability, disorientation, oedema, incontinence, severe depression, teary, sore eyes and blurred vision, dermatitis, muscular weakness, inflamed larynx, lost voices and premature menstrual haemorrhaging in five of the women staff. Also fascinating was the fact that this so-called virus confined itself to the D'Alton site and D'Alton people. It did not transmit itself to families or associates. The little beast would go away in milder cases shortly after the people left the building, only to ambush them again when they returned to the site, with a renewal of the same symptoms.

In the course of the Department's investigation, staff were told that there were no tests available in Tasmania to assess the possibility of exposure to insecticides. It was small consolation to the victims when Health Department representatives apologised profusely for this misinformation long after tests would have been of value. Even more disgusting was the fact that in the initial investigation nobody bothered to interview the pupils at this school and the volunteers who were working there.

After the event, victims were told that advice from the National Health and Medical Research Council was that testing was inappropriate in the absence of individual baseline levels. In fact, they commented that such testing is not only inappropriate but unethical. At this point I would like to say that I am particularly concerned about these comments from the NHMRC. In the absence of any collections of real data about the on-ground real life effects of chemicals, I would have thought that such tests might have proved useful in the long term. If they were requested by the people involved, how on earth could they have been unethical?

The health authorities now gave the school a clean bill of health. The staff went back and there was a fresh outbreak of the symptoms already described. During the school holidays the school was thoroughly cleaned and the air-conditioning vents wiped, although no air analysis or testing of the system was carried out. The person who did the cleaning got sick. Again staff and students returned to the school and again the symptoms reappeared.

An inquiry was called for. Visiting VIPs, and even those doing the testing, were affected but still had no clue what to test for. The odds-on favourite was still a virus, but new theories began to emerge like flies on a summer's day. First there was pollen from the wattles—remember that we have reached springtime now—and then mould along the skirting boards was introduced as a theory. Perhaps it was even the urine-soaked carpet tiles combining with chlorine fumes from the swimming pool some distance away at the Douglas Parker Centre. All these theories have been disproved and discounted. The air-conditioning was eventually extensively tested on 19 September 1991, after everything had been cleaned. The subsequent report suggested sick building syndrome as a possible cause of the illnesses suffered by staff and students.
However, the D'Alton Special School remains closed today. Students who attended

SPEECH.PARA: the school are now bussed to other schools. The problem with the building remains unsolved but active. The toys that have been removed from the building since its closure have caused skin irritations and blisters when handled, and photographs collected by a staff member have caused headaches, rashes and sore eyes. Staff members who were severely affected right back at the beginning of this saga have had recurrent health problems.

PARA.TAB: Whilst acknowledging that something is definitely wrong at the D'Alton school, authorities are still refusing to consider the possibility of insecticide poisoning. When public health is affected so severely and so suddenly, surely there is a responsibility to investigate all possible causes of the symptoms without any fear or hesitation. What I have described to the Senate tonight is just another example of the strange attitude we have in this country of `don't want to know' or `too hard to handle'—an attitude that seems to be particularly prevalent when it comes to the use of chemicals.

I will continue to bring to the Senate examples that can be documented, examples that have dates, times and places attached, examples that should concern those of us who are making decisions about what it is appropriate to do with regard to chemical use in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Foreign Affairs and Trade: Staff Training

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 31 March, 1992:

PARA.TAB: How many training courses has the department already undertaken, or planned, for staff personnel under the Training Guarantee Act 1990 in 1991-92, please provide: (a) name, purpose and duration of the course; (b) number of participant officers (both trainers and trainees); (c) trainee officer level; (d) details of how course participation is assessed, and whether the trainees' branch undertakes its own assessment of the benefit of the course to the participants' post-training performance; and (e) estimated costs of running each course.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: It is not possible to respond to the questions asked in the detail sought within the time available for the task. The relevant departmental computer databases have been structured to provide information in the formats required for the department's statistical purposes and for the purposes of other agencies, notably the Public Service Commission which prepares the annual Human Resources Development Survey. To provide the very specific information in the format required by the honourable senator's question would require the development of new computer programs. That exercise would be both expensive and labour intensive and in my view could not be justified.

Statistics covering most of the information sought are immediately available in formats that comply with the department's existing reporting obligations. Attachments "A" to "G" are a compilation of "General Training" statistical information covering the period 1 April, 1991 to 18 March, 1992 detailing training undertaken and for the period to 31 December, 1992 in respect of proposed training. This information was prepared for and included in the Department's briefing for the Senate Estimates Committee hearing of 31 March, 1992. Attachments "H" to "J" relate to the Department's Language Training activities over the period 1 July, 1991 to 30 June, 1992. Further statistical information is available in the department's Annual Report.

Not included in the above are details regarding the two in-house tertiary-level courses taught under contract by the ANU. These are the two-year Graduate Diploma in Foreign Affairs and Trade and the three-year Associate Diploma in Policy Studies (Foreign Affairs and Trade). Both courses are designed to provide Departmental officers with an up-to-date background in Economics, Public Policy, International Relations, International Law and Administrative Law, in order that they may carry

ANSWER.PARA: out their Departmental duties effectively. The Graduate Diploma is a two year part-time course which commenced in 1990. It has a maximum of 50 students in each annual intake. Approximately half the students are Graduate Administrative Assistants, for whom the course is compulsory. The rest of the students are experienced departmental officers, selected on a competitive basis from applicants ranging in rank from ASO 3 to SOG B. The Associate Diploma is a three year part-time course which commenced in 1991. It has a maximum of 30 students per annual intake. These are selected, on a competitive basis, from applicants from all areas of the department, and range in rank from ASO 2 to SOG B. Most have no previous academic qualifications.

PARA.TAB: The assessment of proposed, current and completed training is undertaken as a continuing on-going process. Work performance indicators and objectives are negotiated and agreed upon between each staff member and his/her supervisor. The training needed for immediate and anticipated duties is identified and agreed upon. The supervisor's specific approval is required before any training is undertaken and work performance and revised training needs are jointly reviewed at six monthly intervals. Staff of the Personnel Development Section regularly conduct follow-up evaluation interviews with a randomly selected sample of participants between two and four weeks after the completion of each course. In addition, written evaluation reports are sought from the participants of the majority of formal training courses. In the case of language training, once training has commenced fortnightly report forms are submitted by tutors and proficiency target levels are set to ensure programs are achieved. Regular language proficiency exams are required of officers and the results are maintained on a central data base and monitored for departmental use.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation, upon notice, on 6 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it standard practice that the maintenance of aircraft flight records is the responsibility of the aircraft owner, regardless of whether or not he is also the pilot; if so, what is the justification for this.
(2) In the case of flight records being inadequately maintained, is the penalty enforced on the aircraft owner or the pilot.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) It is assumed that the term "flight records" means an aircraft's time in service and the keeping of the aircraft maintenance log books. The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) follows accepted international practice whereby the registered owner, that is, the holder of the certificate of registration of an aircraft, is responsible for the airworthiness of the aircraft.

The justification for this is that, for the purposes of sending out airworthiness documentation, including Airworthiness Directives, it is essential for the CAA to have one contact point, namely the registered owner. Furthermore, the maintenance of records of flying time against the aircraft itself and its major components, is an important aspect of maintaining its safety.
(2) This responsibility is reflected in the Civil Aviation Regulations which make the registered owner responsible and liable for prosecution for failure to comply with the requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation, upon notice, on 8 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it intended that cost sharing for private pilots be a means to allow them to act as Charter Operators; if not, what guidelines exist to distinguish private pilots involved in cost sharing from commercial pilots.
(2) Why has inspection for private pilots been changed to annually instead of every 100 flying hours given that some of them are taking paying passengers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The distinction between private and commercial operations is set out in the Civil Aviation Regulations (CARs) and CAR 2(7A) (attached) adequately defines the parameters for private cost sharing flights. The intent of the legislation is clearly set out and allows persons undertaking a private flight, including the operating crew, to share equally in the costs of the flight. By the very nature of the operation, the people who engage in private cost sharing flights should be either friends or acquaintances of the pilot.

(2) As the average private aeroplane flies considerably less than 100 hours a year, the new maintenance requirement introduced recently by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) does not affect the majority of private aeroplanes. Furthermore, those aeroplanes nominated as private aircraft for maintenance purposes are not permitted to be used in commercial operations for the carriage of fare paying passengers.

It is because of the different standards that are required for private and commercial operations that the CAA is actively pursuing any allegations of illegal charter operations being conducted under the guise of private cost sharing operations.
(7A) An aircraft that carries persons on a flight, otherwise than in accordance with a fixed schedule between terminals, is employed in a private operation if:
(a) public notice of the flight has not been given by any form of public advertisement or announcement; and
(b) the number of persons on the flight, including the operating crew, does not exceed 6; and
(c) no payment is made for the services of the operating crew; and
(d) the persons on the flight, including the operating crew, share equally in the costs of the flight; and
(e) no payment is required for a person on the flight other than a payment under paragraph (d).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 5 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS) and the decision to retain the agency, National Advertising Services, for a 12 month trial period to devise and test advertising sales including promotion, sales, billing and accounting:
(1) Were tenders or expressions of interest called for from other agencies.
(2) Was the decision to employ an agency made as a result of other advice given from consultants employed by AGPS to look at their overall management or business; if so, who were the consultants.
(3) Has the department or AGPS contracted any other consultants to advise on the running of AGPS; if so, who were they.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. Control of advertising in Commonwealth publications rests with the author departments not AGPS. National Advertising Services is an arm of Neville Jeffress Advertising which currently holds the Commonwealth wide contract for non campaign advertising placement. AGPS accepted an offer from Neville Jeffress to utilise the comprehensive computer billing and accounting services which underpin this contract to trial an advertising sales service to client agencies. The trial is currently being evaluated.
(3) My department recently contracted with Ernst & Young Management Consulting Services, following competitive bidding, to conduct a Business Review of AGPS.
